fields.headline: A shadow at my shoulder
fields.standfirst: Novelist Patricia Duncker tells Nicholas Wroe about her secret sharer
fields.trailText: Novelist Patricia Duncker tells Nicholas Wroe about her secret sharer
fields.body:
Unlike many writers who claim that they avoid reading other people's work when they are creating their own, Patricia Duncker says her voracious reading habit is entirely unchanged whether she is writing or not. "I simply couldn't write if I wasn't reading," she explains. "It would be like working in a void." But that said, it was not her love and admiration for books that set her on a literary career. Instead it was rather less straightforward love and admiration for a writer. The poet Patricia Beer, who died last year, was her aunt. The two women had a difficult personal relationship, but Beer was undoubtedly Duncker's main influence. "Not in terms of what I write but in how I think," Duncker says. "If you look, a lot of writers do seem to have another writer somewhere in their lives. She was the writer in mine."

Duncker was brought up in 1950s Jamaica, where her mother was English and a teacher, and her father was Jamaican and a businessman. She remembers her "sexy aunt" visiting and representing everything that Europe stood for. "She was glamorous and widely travelled and extremely well read. I showed her my poems when I was about 12 and she was the first person to take me seriously. She told me, very politely, what was good and what was nonsense."

Childhood reading was idiosyncratically colonial. Along with the obligatory Kipling, by the age of 10 Duncker had also read Winston Churchill's History of the Second World War and Fitzroy Maclean's Conversations with Tito . "I read them as adventure stories," she laughs. "But when I went to school in England aged 13 I had to catch up pretty quickly with Malory Towers and things like that."

She went on to read English at university and then did post-graduate work on English and German romanticism. She now teaches English and writing at the University of Wales in Aberystwyth but she always "had it in my head that I wanted to be a writer. I had been instructed by Patricia that this is what I should do, so it was a little like a Mission: Impossible assignment where, once I had accepted, I just had to get on with it".

Duncker says that Beer, who was her guardian when she arrived in England, never actually liked her, and certainly didn't pass comment on her mature writing. "But even if we didn't talk together about writing, I read everything she wrote and she has shaped my mind. I hugely admire her ruthless imagination. There is a real ice-queen chill in her writing. And she taught me a commitment to excellence: never be sloppy, go to the sixth, seventh, eighth revision, leave your best scenes on the cutting-room floor. Work work work."

This stringent approach has contributed to Duncker still having an unpublished three-volume novel in a drawer at home, as well as bundles of unseen poetry. She thinks more novels that do see the light of day should be kept in drawers, and claims even if she never had anything published she would continue to write. "Some of the people I most admire were never published in their lifetime, like Emily Dickinson. Even Emily Brontë didn't want to publish."

Duncker's first novel, Hallucinating Foucault , was eventually published in 1996. Part thriller, part love story, part philosophical exploration, it was widely acclaimed and picked up a series of first-novel prizes. She says that while it is obviously gratifying to win prizes, the most exciting thing is to have more readers. "I know how thrilling it is for me to read a book that excites me, so to think I might have given that pleasure to someone else is wonderful."

Her collection of short stories, Monsieur Shoushana's Lemon Trees , was published in 1997 and the paperback edition of her second novel, James Miranda Barry , comes out this month. Duncker had initially used the true story of the 19th-century military doctor who lived her life as a man in her very first piece of published writing. It appeared in a 1989 anthology of short stories, but her subsequent attempt to write a novel based on the character stalled after 100 pages when she couldn't resolve the problem of saying "him" or "her" in the narration. In 1997 she tried again and, using both first and third-person narration, cracked the technical problems. The resulting book is an absorbing literary-historical novel that probes with an exuberant intelligence the complex relationship between what things are and what they seem.

Duncker's next project is editing a volume of short stories written by women in Wales, and she will then complete a new novel. "It's set in the contemporary world but will be very gothic and very scary. I love the horror genre. I think the reason crime fiction has become so respectable is that the French literary establishment has thrown its weight behind it, but this hasn't happened yet with horror. There are so many possibilities and resonances."

Not least in her own life. She says Patricia Beer was something like a doppelgänger for her. "I was named after her and people say we sound the same. She has been a sort of shadow, and I think I have always written both for her and against her. While I didn't get on with her as a person, I really, really admired her as a writer. So much so that it has been a pain to me that I have never been able to say so. She was quite a dangerous person to know and she would have taken it as a sort of attack. But I can't overstate how much she goes on being important to me."

webTitle: Steven Poole's non-fiction pick of the month

fields.headline: The List
fields.standfirst: The Information Bomb | Sounding Out the City | Wicked Etiquette
fields.trailText: The Information Bomb | Sounding Out the City | Wicked Etiquette
fields.body:
The Information Bomb, by Paul Virilio (Verso, £16)
Buy it at BOL

Perversely enjoyable exercise in philosophic melodrama: it is not enough for Virilio to claim that the world is going to hell in a hand-basket, but he must italicise and embolden every other word in case we fall asleep. Apparently the world is racing towards techno-scientific doom, thanks to an upcoming "information war" threatening "the very principle of all individuated life". Virilio gets sadly confused on the subject of computers and much else, but his rhetoric thunders awesomely on, built largely from those nice French sentence constructions that imply analogies without having to argue them.

Sounding Out the City: Personal Stereos and the Management of Everyday Life, by Michael Bull (Berg, £14.99)
Buy it at BOL

Launching off from cyberguru William Gibson's comment that "The Sony Walkman has done more to change human perception than any virtual-reality gadget", Bull constructs a forbiddingly cult-studsy but nonetheless fascinating phenomenology of the personal stereo. Its users reimagine the changing spaces around them, inhabiting a journey as if it were a soundtracked aesthetic experience and "repossessing time" by gluing together interludes as a cultural continuum. The most passionate aficionados of this technology are also all going stone deaf, of course, but maybe that's a small price to pay for a "denial of contingency embedded in the experience of time".

Wicked Etiquette, by Sarah Kortum, illus. Ronald Searle (Collins & Brown, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

We troglodytic, squinting, pasty-faced literary hacks don't get out much, so I found precious advice in this piquant compendium drawn from etiquette handbooks of the last 150 years. Mainly good for knowing what to do at parties: "When asking questions about persons who are not known to you, avoid using adjectives; or you may enquire of a mother, 'Who is that awkward, ugly girl?' and be answered, 'Sir, that is my daughter.'" We've all been there, haven't we, readers?

webTitle: Guardian review: In A Dark Wood by Amanda Craig

fields.headline: Lost in the woods
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  on Amanda Craig's thin psychodrama, In A Dark Wood
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on Amanda Craig's thin psychodrama, In A Dark Wood
fields.body:
In A Dark Wood by Amanda Craig 276pp, Fourth Estate, £14.99
Buy it at BOL

The journalist Amanda Craig achieved a certain notoriety about five years ago when her satire on literary London, A Vicious Circle , apparently drew rather heavily on real life in its portrayal of the wickedness of critics and canapé munchers. The result was passably witty but, as one often feels about coterie novels, of limited interest to anyone outside Soho and N1 who doesn't care that Reviewer A is copping off with Writer B.

In her fourth novel Craig has again made use of a literary theme, although far more obliquely and with less possibility of comeback, as Sylvia Plath, like her fictional counterpart here, a children's illustrator called Laura, committed suicide more than 30 years ago. As well as this violent end, Laura shared with Plath a streak of psychosis, an unruly talent and a faithless husband. And she left behind a child, Benedick, who has matured into a grade-A disaster: at the novel's opening, his wife Georgie has abandoned him and taken their two children with her; his acting career has dwindled to walk-on parts in unheralded low-budget Britflicks; and he is slowly engulfed by a depression that renders him virtually incapable of leaving the room loaned to him by old family friend and maternal stand-in, Jewish shrink Ruth.

Benedick's one lifeline appears to be a burgeoning interest in his mother, stimulated by a book of her fairy tales that he discovers when divvying up the marital spoils. "I picked it up," he tells us. "I didn't know then, how dangerous fairy tales can be." By the end of the novel, however, the reader will feel more than fully versed in the perils not only of creepy woods and wicked witches but of paper-thin psychodramas too.

"Isn't absolutely everything a symbol of the unconscious to you lot?" rails Benedick to Ruth, with whom he has been discussing the imagery of his mother's fairy tales. "Well - not absolutely everything," she replies calmly. "And I'm a psychotherapist, not a psychiatrist." That almost comic error (psycho-therapists tell you why you direct traffic naked when you're asleep and can't get a boyfriend; psychiatrists peer at rats in mazes and dole out big shiny pills) is characteristic of the kind of clichéd over-simplification on display here, which sees Benedick getting madder and madder. As we survey dead mother, awful dad, absent wife, terrible career and life going nowhere, it's hardly surprising that the man can't cope.

But there's far more grimness in store when Benedick sets off to North Carolina, where his mother's ageing sister resides in fading splendour . Gripped by the manic depression that did for his mother, he has several nasty things waiting for him in the woodshed. It's unfortunate that, largely because he is so vile to his own small son, our sympathy is fast converted to antipathy. Therein lies Craig's biggest problem, as the reader struggles to find a single character to like in any decent measure. It's a shame, because one doesn't care to be flippant about mental illnesses or the legacy of suicide. But to portray all this in fiction is a challenging business, and on the evidence of In a Dark Wood , something for which we will have to wait a little longer.

fields.headline: Strathfarrar
fields.trailText:
If I could believe my ears I'd
hear the clamour of battle
in the hammering stones...
fields.body:
If I could believe my ears I'd
hear the clamour of battle
in the hammering stones

in the water's veins
which are clear of blood;
or the keening pines

in the arms of the wind, like
mothers wrapping their sons
in rough purple shawls;

or I'd hear the drums and pipes
in the crags where the clan trees
rise like steps, or years, or generations.

If I could believe my ears
I would keep the old sayings close,
a carpet of blaeberry, cowberry, moss

on the steep slopes
springing under my feet,
the slow, wet sobs of the bog

on the cross-leaved heath,
the purple moor grass
loomed by the breeze.

If I could believe my ears
the old stone songs
of the moine schist rocks are singing

me on, the high folk songs in the glen,
a silver stone in the brown river
calling the tune, where I turn

to the ancient stare
of a shy red deer.
The past believes it is still here.

 This poem was specially commissioned by BBC Poetry Proms, which are broadcast on Radio 3 during the interval of every Wednesday's Prom.

webTitle: Guardian review: Guilty Victim by Hella Pick

fields.headline: Mislaying Hitler
fields.standfirst: Martin Woollacott  explores Austria's struggle to forget in Hella Pick's Guilty Victim: Austria from the Holocaust to Haider
fields.trailText: Martin Woollacott explores Austria's struggle to forget in Hella Pick's Guilty Victim: Austria from the Holocaust to Haider
fields.body:
Guilty Victim: Austria from the Holocaust to Haider by Hella Pick 235pp, IB Tauris, £24.50
Buy it at BOL

In the late summer of 1943, British and American intelligence analysts thought they had detected signs that Austria was turning against the Germans. Italy had surrendered, Austria was being seriously bombed for the first time, the casualty lists from the eastern front were lengthening and there was much complaining in what the Nazis called the Ostmark. In an attempt to induce a rising - or at least to cause trouble - the Allies issued the Moscow Declaration, which described Austria as "the first free country to fall victim to Hitlerite aggression", pledged to establish an independent Austria after the war and called on Austrians to contribute to their own liberation.

It fell on deaf ears. There was no revolt, and no great increase in an internal resistance that had always been modest in scale. But the Moscow Declaration proved of extraordinary significance once peace came. It was the birth certificate of post-war Austria, enshrining a fiction which both the Allies and the Austrians knew to be untrue, but which everybody found so useful that it was maintained for decades.

Its consequences are still with us today. In her timely book, Hella Pick skilfully traces the line that, through the twists and turns of nearly 60 years of Austrian and international politics, connects the Declaration to Jorg Haider today. A child refugee from Austria who was brought up in England, Pick later frequently returned as a Guardian correspondent to the country of her birth. She has been on close terms with some of its great men, including Bruno Kreisky and Simon Wiesenthal. One virtue of her account is that it demonstrates how the concept of Austria as victim of the Nazis was, stage by stage, a product of collusion between the new state and its western friends. Another is that it shows how Austria's denial of its Nazi past, and continuing appeasement of those Austrians who clung to that past, perplexingly coexisted with a genuinely humane tradition. That tradition made it a country of refuge for hundreds of thousands fleeing the eastern bloc, a neutral state which took courageous diplomatic initiatives and an admired social and economic model.

The Declaration was wrong on every count. Austria was not a free country in 1938, but its citizens freely welcomed the Nazis - and with an enthusiasm that went beyond anything seen in Germany. The Austrian Nazis enrolled proportionally more members during the war years than the party did in Germany. According to one analysis, Austrians, who constituted 8 per cent of the population of Greater Germany, provided 14 per cent of the SS and an amazing 40 per cent of the men in killing units such as those at concentration camps. When the post-war Austrian leadership looked at the problem of de-Nazification it recoiled in horror, for registered Nazis and their families constituted a third of the population. Many of them, of course, were ordinary men and women who could be defined as victims of their times. But the public reconciliation between Austrian conservatives and social demo crats, whose hostility to one another had contributed so much to the country's inter-war troubles, was matched by a hidden compromise with this ex-Nazi constituency.

Austrians, the author writes, "mentally mislaid the Hitler years", a trick which allowed politicians to work with the parties that drew on that constituency. As she shows, political arrangements with the Freedom Party and its predecessors are nothing new. They were in and out of bed with the the Social Democratic Party for nearly 40 years, until Chancellor Franz Vranitzky brought the alliance to an end when Haider became the Freedom Party leader. Perhaps it is understandable that the Freedom Party complains about being pilloried today for doing what the Social Democratic Party did in the past with only intermittent controversy, both inside and outside Austria.

But Haider is a different kind of leader from his predecessors, and the party is no longer on the margins of Austrian politics. What is more, the reasons why the world turned a blind eye have all but disappeared. The cold war is over, Austria is in the European Union, the understanding of the second world war and of the fate of the Jews has shifted and the dangers of xenophobic nationalism have been freshly demonstrated in the Balkans. Furthermore, right-wing extremism is a significant problem in several western democracies. From the mid-80s on, with the scandal over Kurt Waldheim's election as president, the Austrian political establishment has increasingly been ready to face the truth about the past and, belatedly, to offer some restitution. The unhappy fact is that these are precisely the years in which Haider and the Freedom Party have prospered. The problem this represents is not Austria's alone. As in the past, the theatre of Austrian politics is both that of a small and rather provincial country and that of the world - a difficult combination for both sides, as this book makes amply clear.

As in the past, the theatre of Austrian politics is both that of a small and rather provincial country and that of the world - a difficult combination for both sides, as this book makes amply clear.

webTitle: Guardian review: Old Age in English History by Pat Thane

fields.headline: Old gold
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  discovers wisdom in Pat Thane's study of ageing, Old Age in English History: Past Experiences, Present Issues
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom discovers wisdom in Pat Thane's study of ageing, Old Age in English History: Past Experiences, Present Issues
fields.body:
Old Age in English History: Past Experiences, Present Issues by Pat Thane 548pp, Oxford, £25
Buy it at BOL

'When you are old and grey and full of sleep,/ And nodding by the fire, take down this book", advised a young ambitious WB Yeats (1865-1939) to his imagined older self in his poem "When You Are Old", published in The Countess Kathleen and Various Legends and Lyrics (1892). No. Better take down this book, Old Age in English History: Past Experiences, Present Issues by Pat Thane, professor of contemporary history at the University of Sussex, which is a challenge to all the usual tired, blasted, ragged, shrivelled, chicken-skinned, catnapping, Tiresias-dugged, slack-throated, liver-spotted, incontinent and Celtic Twilight twaddling assumptions about ageing and old age.

But of course, "Age is not a particularly interesting subject", or so claimed Groucho Marx (1895-1977). No again. Age is endlessly and horribly fascinating, from Plato's famous age rules in The Laws (judges of poetry, he wisely suggests, should be at least 50, and choirmasters 40 plus) to the tragedy of King Lear to the magnificent spectacle of Harrison Ford's gradual on-screen wrinkling and thickening (how can all those young women possibly kiss that?).

Some people, of course, are wretched and washed up at 30, but even 60, the traditional annus climactarius, is no bar to achievement. Just off the top of my head, and with the assistance of a set of encyclopaedias, since my memory is not quite what it was: Verdi composed Otello at 73; Henry James wrote The Golden Bowl at 61; Pasternak didn't see Dr Zhivago published until he was 67; Marx finally finished Capital aged 61. David Ben-Gurion became prime minister of Israel at 62; Menachem Begin, like Disraeli, didn't make it until he was 63; Reagan did it at 69; Gladstone bounced back for the third time at 76. John Wayne starred in True Grit at 62; Alec Guinness became George Smiley at 65; and Colonel Harlan Sanders franchised Kentucky Fried Chicken at 66, the same age at which Michaelangelo completed the Last Judgment.

Pat Thane makes the obvious but nonetheless compelling point that there is no such thing as an undifferentiated group, "old people", any more than there are, say, "young people", "fat people" or "rude people"."The age group which is most generalised about," writes Thane in timeless academic prose, "in fact incorporates a greater variety of ages, of social, economic and physical conditions than any other age group." Or to put it another way: old age is like a plate of mixed biscuits.

"With the ancient is wisdom; and in length of days under- standing", reasoned Job (dates unknown). No, no and thrice no. (Just reading about old age seems to make you curmudgeonly.) "In no time or place," counters Thane, "is it evident that old age, especially very old age, is especially valued in itself, independently of the attributes of specific old people. Nor that in 'the past' or in 'other cultures', old, as distinct from middle-aged, people in general were repositories of knowledge and skill in contrast to their obsolescence in fast-moving modern cultures."

As Thane further points out, in medieval and early modern England the witness of a few old men may have been relied upon as legal evidence of ancient custom in property disputes, but if you were an old woman in possession of traditional knowledge - midwifery, say - you were just as likely to have been burned as a witch.

In 24 careful chapters Thane surveys the evidence of the vigorous and varied lives of the elderly from pre-modern England to the present; her conclusions are never less than shocking. It was never the custom, for instance, for generations to share a home; the idea of "structured dependency" relies on a myth of well-paid and dignified work; the experience of ageing has always depended upon whether you are rich or poor, male or female; and extreme old age does not necessarily mean ill health.

There is a clear and signal purpose to these numerous claims and challenges. The world may be facing an ageing population, but is this necessarily a problem? No. "The generations do not have to compete for resources in the future, but can share them equitably... We need to work with a more complex and realistic picture of who older people are and of their roles in society and the economy than the simple, depressing, inaccurate image of burdensome dependency." After all, old age ceases to be a problem when you consider the alternative.

fields.headline: Press gang
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  enjoys the rat-like cunning of Fleet Street's finest in The Penguin Book of Journalism
fields.trailText: The Penguin Book of Journalism, ed Stephen Glover (£8.99)
fields.body:
The Penguin Book of Journalism, ed Stephen Glover (£8.99)

Journalists tend, it has to be admitted, to be an awfully self-regarding lot; so why should we be interested in a book where 27 of them write about their careers, when that, in a sense, is what we see them doing anyway?

Well, because they can tell a good yarn, that's why. (A talent for that is what has sustained them, after all.) And in this collection there is very much the sense of naughtiness you get at a convention: the delegates here are running down the corridors in the middle of the night, letting off figurative fire-extinguishers, and generally letting their hair down.

Instructive, too, if not bracing, for Guardian readers to be exposed to the kind of names that may only exist on the periphery of their nightmares: Petronella Wyatt, say (who disingenuously does not declare why she feels so moved to make an inaccurate complaint about Julie Burchill), Niall Ferguson, Peter McKay, and indeed Stephen Glover himself, regular Guardian diary joke-butt, who provides the illuminating confession that "at the comparatively tender age of twenty-six... I had found myself writing editorials for the Daily Telegraph on all manner of things about which I often knew absolutely nothing".

But let's concentrate on the good stuff - and salute Glover for having got so much of it in. It begins with Francis Wheen's sprightly essay on nostalgia for the old days of Fleet Street, with which this book is saturated (the thing about nostalgia, of course, is that by definition it never goes away); it is an unconscious companion piece for Michael Frayn's introductory essay to Towards the End of the Morning , recently republished by Faber and almost as essential a Fleet Street novel as Scoop.

Henry Porter writes well about editors (a wish to save my professional bacon saving me from saying any more); Carol Sarler makes a good case for the tabloids; Fiammetta Rocco, an in-depth profiler, explains why you shouldn't be the subject of an in-depth profile; Paul Foot has a good old go at Maxwell and other demons ("the editor of this collection foolishly urges me to indulge myself in my own experiences, so here goes").

Richard Ingrams reminds would-be litigants about the dangers of litigation; when Nora Beloff chose, perhaps reasonably, to take at face value an assertion in Private Eye that she had slept with every member of the Wilson cabinet, although "no impropriety occurred", she sued, and won. Auberon Waugh had his revenge when writing about her marriage, at the age of 56. "Even as I write, Clifford Makins is exploring the unimaginable delights of her body, never sweeter than when first sampled." (Oddly, he doesn't mention her PE nickname, "Nora Balsoff".)

Nostalgia, I think, is fine when you have something to be nostalgic about. Anyone with a sense of linguistic humour is going to enjoy the occasional reminiscences of cable-ese, those terse correspondences that would close with telegrams reading "my balls unmade crystal", "why you unswim shark-infested sea query" - or, the best ever, and unimprovable for as long as humanity endures, "Upstuff job arsewards".

The prognosis for the industry is not too bleak. Of course, the underlying message from each contributor is that any industry that employs him or her is not in such bad shape; but I am glad that Ann Leslie, the brave and cunning foreign correspondent, is still working. She reminds us of the only advice would-be journalists need on what it takes: a plausible manner, rat-like cunning, and a little literary ability. Enjoy.

fields.headline: The word is out
fields.trailText: The Loafer discusses the guest list for the coming second outing of London-wide literary festival The Word, and draws attention to the nautical themes running through the life and works of quirky novelist Tibor Fischer
fields.body:
 Last year's first London-wide literary festival, The Word, didn't have the smoothest of rides: scattered locations, nightmarish admin cock-ups and resources vastly drained by importing star turns from around the world. For its second outing in September, the whole shebang has been somewhat scaled down, confining itself mainly to one site, the Globe on Bankside. An investment banker and Random House's finance director have been drafted in to grasp the purse strings, and a mere 33 writers will appear. Of them, a considerable number will be London-based, banishing the need for costly travel arrangements: the ubiquitous Zadie Smith, for example, need only pop on the Jubilee line from Kilburn, although the reclusive JG Ballard will have to trek all the way from Shepperton, a journey that surely requires countless zone extensions. In any case, we wish them all the best of luck.

 Waterstone's is to be The Word's official bookshop, but let's hope that the staff are more on the ball than one former employee. John Boyne's novel, The Thief of Time, was researched in the history section of the Dublin branch, while in the evenings he moved on to the peaceful gardening or poetry departments in order to write behind the till. Impatient customers should be careful not to disturb nascent geniuses attempting to eke out their meagre salaries.

 Quirky novelist and expert on weird titles Tibor Fischer has jumped ship from Secker & Warburg to Scribner for his new book, Voyage to the End of the Room, described optimistically as Robinson Crusoe crossed with Treasure Island for the 21st century. To milk the tenuous navigation theme, we note that Fischer's agent is Stephanie Cabot.

fields.headline: Non-fiction: 12 Aug
fields.standfirst: Mexico City | World Food: Mexico | Mexican Tiles
fields.trailText: Mexico City | World Food: Mexico | Mexican Tiles
fields.body:
Mexico City, by Nick Caistor (Signal, £12)
Buy it at BOL

From "Cities of the Imagination", a modest series of companions that shame the shelves of greedy guidebooks promising you can possess places through 48 hours of consumption. Caistor is obsessed by every besmogged metre of his chosen metropolis, sinking in its lake clay foundations: by Posada, engraver of skeletons at the fiesta, whose grandson who lives still in the family house (his umbilical cord is buried in the garden); by Astrid Hadad's cabaret act mocking rancheras , the country music of the nostalgic urban poor; by the Nahua-speakers of the brickworks of Mixcoac, who bewitched the childhood of Octavio Paz among mud and ochreous dust. Wow.

World Food: Mexico, by Bruce Geddes (Lonely Planet, £6.99)

We loathe LP guidebooks (see above) but for all the "sit here, eat that, be an instant expert" approach, the powerful sensuality of Mexican food still bursts through the been-there, stained-the-T-shirt tone. The exuberant snaps of markets connect with the happiness the promise of a full belly still confers; the basic salsa recipe is great, as is the culinary dictionary at the back. Geddes does a graceful mini-interview with Laura Esquivel (author of Like Water For Chocolate ), while he and she grind the maize in an ancient stone metate to make corn tortillas in her kitchen in Coyoacan. He's way too pompous, but we enjoyed the pleased shock of him really connecting with her.

Mexican Tiles, by Masako Takahashi (Chronicle Books, £12.99)

Technically one of the San Francisco Chronicle 's design picturebooks, with an acute concern for detail: the cutout cover, the shots of a wedding party leaving a rustic, baroque church or of unglam washing-up liquid by less-than-perfect sinks. Then, as we read the captions, we began to notice how norteamericanos regarded Mexico - all those New York artists with holiday homes in San Miguel de Allende, those bed-and-breakfasts in Cuernavaca with tiled bathrooms for gentlefolk from Maine going south for the artfully simple life. Seldom has the love-hate between the US and Mexico been better caught, nor the sense that Mexican poverty has preserved its daily vivacity.

fields.headline: What's selling in... gardening
fields.trailText: This list of gardening books from WHSmith is dominated by two unstoppable forces utterly different in social character: the first is a variety of weighty reference tomes from the Royal Horticultural Society, the second is that hypnotic but cringe-making soap-opera of the herbaceous border, BBC1's Ground Force. Fronted by Alan Titchmarsh, backed up by Charlie Dimmock - or should that be the other way round? - it has afforded both opportunities to produce spin-off books of one kind or another (beefy deck-builder Tommy Walsh adds another to the roster). The RHS volumes are heavy on detail - nomina latina , etc - and if they don't have the vertiginous cheerfulness of Charlie and Alan, they can always provide chapter and verse on elusive vegetation. Together with the Hessayon "Expert" books, these two streams of material make up large chunks of a massively profitable sector of publishing.

fields.standfirst:
Endurance, by Alfred Lansing (Orion, £13, 365mn)
Buy it at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText:
Alfred Lansing's narrative of Sir Ernest Shackleton Antarctic voyage: the ultimate survival story
Hear a real audio clip
fields.body: It is, of course, the name of the ship in which Sir Ernest Shackleton voyaged to the Antarctic at the start of the first world war, intending to cross it overland. But the ship was first trapped, then crushed by ice. The title really describes what happens next to the crew, cast away on a drifting ice pack. Scott's doomed venture may be more famous, but Shackleton's 650-mile bid to cross the appalling Weddell Sea in a lifeboat to raise help in South Georgia will never be topped for sheer courage and will to survive. Lansing's 1956 narrative weaves first-hand survivors' accounts into a gripping day-by-day account of peril. Tim Pigott-Smith gives it a superb white-knuckle reading, finding the perfect voice and delivery for the long-haul adventure. You'll feel your car icing up, but you won't want to stop. If you listen to anything on holiday, it has got to be this ultimate survival story.

fields.headline: Fiction: 12 Aug
fields.standfirst: Life's Lottery | Teeth & Spies | The Sword Cabinet |  Ladies' Night At Finbar's Hotel | Overheads
fields.trailText: Life's Lottery | Teeth & Spies | The Sword Cabinet | Ladies' Night At Finbar's Hotel | Overheads
fields.body:
Life's Lottery, by Kim Newman (Pocket Books, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Does Keith Marion like Napoleon Solo or Ilya Kuryakin? Will he save his little brother from the playground bully or run off and get a teacher? The USP of Newman's novel is that you, dear reader, decide. If A turn to chapter 4, if B take chapter 3 and so on. The hero's life is in your hands, and choices - as Newman bangs home - have unforeseen consequences, which might make Life's Lottery an epic read or reduce its 600 pages to a slim novella. It is a gimmick that works better in the reading than in the telling. Choice, however, is not infinite, and whatever decisions you make, the writing is less exciting than the format.

Teeth & Spies, by Giorgio Pressburger (Granta, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Teeth & Spies is just that - the dental biography of SG, from the moment his father swallows his first milk tooth in a concentration camp to the fitting of his dentures 50 years later. A chapter per tooth takes SG around the world in government service, suffering toothache in his first upper right premolar whenever a world leader is assassinated and being forced by a Barcelona dentist to ransom his Jewish faith to his oral hygiene. In between the drills, extractions and abscesses SG struggles with philosophy, politics and love. Pressburger's conceit is an Eastern European metaphysical black comedy to its roots, with the fluidity of the best intellectual thrillers.

The Sword Cabinet, by Robert Edric (Anchor, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Mitchell is the last of the Kings, a theatrical family whose trade - variety acts, stunts and circuses - has been dying for 50 years. The seaside nightclub that Mitchell owns has reached the end of the pier too, so he turns to the family's past hoping to find out why his mother left the Kings. Edric juggles his images - illusion and deception, front-of-house glamour and back-stage reality - adeptly within an obliquely revealed plot that centres on escapologist Morgan King's involvement in a series of unsolved murders. The Sword Cabinet ought to thrill, but Edric clutches his metaphors too tightly for it to be more than an exercise in literary showmanship.

Ladies' Night At Finbar's Hotel, ed Dermot Bolger (Picador, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Bolger's welcoming Dublin hotel has gone up in the world since a handful of male Irish writers checked in a year or so back, invited to fill up the place with fictional guests. Restyled, it has embraced the Celtic tigers who settle back in its white leather sofas and toast the strength of the Irish economy with champagne and gin, though nothing can quite wipe out its past and the histories of its guests. Seven chapters, seven writers - Maeve Binchey and Clare Boylan included - and seven rooms. Anonymity is the watchword at Finbar's, though who wrote what is beside the point: each story is as restfully luxurious and tastefully appointed as the rooms.

Overheads, by Ann Oakley (Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Universities are the sitting ducks of satire: academics preying on each other for sex and advancement while bureaucrats snap at their heels. Oakley's portrait of East Midlands University (EMU) is, as the blurb says, "worryingly recognisable". Head of department Wormleighton is in cahoots with the vice-chancellor to bring in the management consultants; acronyms and initiatives abound; student numbers increase; resources are cut. Meanwhile Lydia Mallinder, Professor of Gender Studies, has her feminism in a twist over an affair with a married man, until a panther comes into her life. All diverting stuff from an insider, but recognisably old-hat.

webTitle: Small press corner: The Collected Strange Stories

fields.headline: Small press corner: The Collected Strange Stories
fields.trailText: The Collected Strange Stories, by Robert Aickman
fields.body:
The Collected Strange Stories, by Robert Aickman (two vols, Tartarus Press, £70)

Aickman (1914-1981) is sui generis; he built on Freud, whom he greatly admired, and the prose of Walter de la Mare, M R James and others, but there is nothing much like these disturbing tales. In "The Hospice", a traveller notices another guest is chained to a rail; in "Never Visit Venice", a character drifts away in a gondola with the skeleton of a young woman for company... straightforward genre horror, you would think, but it's all crossed with acute social observatiion and the kind of resistance to closure associated with more literary work. Pricey, but well worth it.

 Tartarus, 5 Birch Terrace, Hangingbirch Lane, East Sussex TN21 OPA .Tel: 01435 813224.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.trailText: The Tattooed Soldier | A Killing on Wall Street: An Investment Mystery | Enticement | Strange Police
fields.body:
The Tattooed Soldier, by Hector Tobar (Serpent's Tail, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

In the bleak setting of down-and-out Los Angeles, third-world refugees with degrees find themselves cleaning toilets - if they're lucky. Tobar doesn't put a foot wrong with this rich material; he goes for the gut-wrench, replaying a Guatemalan nightmare as sickening flashback. He works his plot as though it were a chess game with human figures, or one of those bad dreams that becomes another that's even worse: a man hitting rock bottom in LA after fleeing the Guatemala army death squads who murdered his wife and child ends up in the same neighbourhood as one of the killers.

A Killing on Wall Street: An Investment Mystery, by Derrick Niederman (John Wiley, £14.50)
Buy it at BOL

Notable for its curiosity value, this is both a murder mystery and an analysis of the US stock market. Fun for the initiated perhaps, but likely to bamboozle the financially dim, with the whodunnit element insufficient compensation.

Enticement, by Gill Paul (Hodder & Stoughton, £17.99)

A dirty weekend in Brittany ends with his sudden disappearance and her wondering who exactly he was - and, later, why he's not the man he said he was. Her mind is definitely not on the job (publishing), although even she gradually suspects that her grandmother's wartime memoirs of occupied France might have something to do with it. Robust openings often lead to flabby middles and flat endings, but apart from some Bridget Jones musings Paul keeps her narrative up, making a virtue of pace.

Strange Police, by Reg Gadney (Faber, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Gadney's usual man, the spiky Alan Rosslyn (ex-HM Customs and Excise and now insecurely in private security), finds himself, via an affair on a supposedly routine job in Greece, framed for the murder of his lover. He must also try to prevent a heist that has the air of a Greek Mission: Impossible - the stealing of the Elgin Marbles from the British Museum and their return to Athens. But it's the bureaucrats who are shown to have the sharpest claws and the deadliest desk moves, with Gadney as always a master of grown-up games.

 Chris Petit is the author of two thrillers, The Psalm Killer (1996) and Back from the Dead (1999), both published by Pan.

webTitle: Guardian review: Going Gently by David Nobbs

fields.headline: Last laugh
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Royle  enjoys David Nobbs' deathbed tragicomedy,  Going Gently
fields.trailText: Nicholas Royle enjoys David Nobbs' deathbed tragicomedy, Going Gently
fields.body:
Going Gently by David Nobbs 412pp, Heinemann, £15.99
Buy it at BOL

Kate Copson, born in 1899, is the oldest patient on Ward 3C, Whetstone General Hospital. With her hundredth birthday approaching at the speed of an express train, Kate is engaged in a race against time with a difference: she wants her life to crash into the buffers before she has to listen to the Queen's telemessage and a rousing chorus of "For She's a Jolly Good Fellow", but not before she's worked out which of her three sons is responsible for the murder of her fourth - or is it fifth? - husband, Graham Eldridge. Confined to bed after suffering a massive stroke, Kate is alert and rational. Although she retains limited power of movement, she feigns paralysis in order that she may, free of distractions, replay the mental video of her life and, she hopes, eliminate two of her sons from suspicion of murder.

Her life story is a spellbinding narrative that spans the 20th century from the battle of the Somme to Kosovan refugees, taking in the General Strike, the Great Depression, the war against Hitler and much else besides. The focus, however, is always personal. Born into a strictly puritanical Welsh family and brought up in Swansea, Kate is one of five children. She herself has four children - her three sons, Maurice, Nigel and Timothy, and a daughter, Elizabeth - with various husbands. Her life is initially shaped, like those of so many other young women at that time, by the death in the Great War of her childhood sweetheart, Gwyn, with whom she had enjoyed one glorious, illicit night of passion.

Leaving home to become a schoolteacher in Penzance, she finds herself joining an artists' colony instead and marrying Arturo, who dresses all in purple and hits upon the idea of hanging his canvases upside down. The art world is just one of the targets for Nobbs's unerringly accurate satirical darts. He pricks the bubble of pompous artists' pretensions and, later in the novel, highlights the cynical ruthlessness of a gallery owner who waits to mount a major exhibition of a talented painter's work until after the artist is dead, because he is aware that the work will only become fashionable with the artist's passing.

Kate is a superbly realised character: a strong, passionate woman with an unquenchable thirst for life and a keen social conscience. She carries a certain amount of guilt, but wears it lightly. She can be naive as well as wise, foolishly sacrificing her marriage to a wealthy industrialist by becoming ensnared in a trap involving industrial rather than conjugal relations. She is enormously loving towards her family, without allowing sentimentality to blind her to their faults. Like Nobbs's most famous creation, Reginald Perrin, she is an iconoclast and a rebel, and always heroic in her championing of the underdog. And, just like the Reginald Perrin novels, Going Gently is enormously entertaining and extremely funny.

David Nobbs didn't get where he is today without understanding the value of a good catchphrase. Kate's family members have one each. Brother Bernard tags "I beg your pardon?" on the end of any comment he judges to be at all challenging or radical - that is, every time he opens his mouth. Sister Enid has an endless supply of cautionary tales about local people dying tragicomic deaths, while Kate's other brother, Oliver, constantly reminds everybody that his socially repellent wife Bunny is a great mixer. But there's more to Nobbs's humour than catchphrases: longer, more intricate jokes lace the narrative, and no matter how far back you trace any of them, they never appear forced or contrived.

The tone is not light throughout. Kate's life, inevitably since she is as old as the century, is frequently touched by tragedy. But by letting us know in advance - to a certain extent - what a rough time she has in store, Nobbs manages to avoid the danger of her story appearing an implausible catalogue of disasters. He performs a perfect balancing act between seriousness and fun, comedy and tragedy. This is a consistently entertaining and very moving book that somehow manages both to affirm life and to welcome death with open arms - or, as in one of Nobbs's gags involving Kate and the flies of sculptor Stanley Wainwright's pyjama trousers, to open it with welcoming arms.

 Nicholas Royle's new novel, The Director's Cut, has just been published by Abacus. To order a copy of Going Gently at the discount price of £12.99 plus 99p p&p, call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Parrot's Theorem by Denis Guedj

fields.headline: Imaginary numbers
fields.standfirst: The fictional maths in Denis Guedj's The Parrot's Theorem just doesn't add up, finds  Simon Singh
fields.trailText: The fictional maths in Denis Guedj's The Parrot's Theorem just doesn't add up, finds Simon Singh
fields.body:
The Parrot's Theorem by Denis Guedj 350pp, Weidenfeld, £12.99
Buy it at BOL

The last year has seen an unprecedented boom in the publishing of novels about mathematics. Number Nine by Cecil Balmond, The French Mathematician by Tom Petsinis and Leaning Towards Infinity by Sue Woolfe all caused minor stirs; earlier this year Apostolos Doxiadis's Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture hit the headlines by offering a $1m prize for whomever could solve the eponymous problem. Now we have The Parrot's Theorem by Denis Guedj and, coming next year, The Wild Numbers by Philibert Schogt.

These books are neither as gripping as a Stephen King novel nor as literary as a Booker Prize winner, but they have a different objective from most other fiction - to smuggle mathematical concepts into the mind of the unsuspecting reader by wrapping the maths inside an engaging plot. The question is, does this new genre of fictional maths succeed?

The boom in maths books began when non-fiction authors started to write about mathematicians as well as mathematics, placing the intellectual concepts within a framework of history and human stories. The intention was to capture the reader's imagination for long enough to persuade him or her that understanding mathematical ideas and proofs can be a rewarding and enthralling experience.

Some of the finer exponents of this style of mathematical writing include Paul Hoffman (author of The Man who Loved Only Number ) and Sylvia Nasar (A Beautiful Mind). In the wider area of general science, Dava Sobel has succeeded in introducing the work of John Harrison (inventor of the marine chronometer) and the ideas of Galileo to hundreds of thousands of readers. This style of writing has been dubbed narrative non-fiction.

The majority of popularisers are attempting to convey the wonder of an esoteric subject to readers who would normally run a mile at the mere mention of trigonometry. The good news is that narrative non-fiction has been relatively successful in taking mathematics to a new readership, but perhaps the new pure-fiction approach can reach out to an even wider audience.

There is inevitably a level of compromise. The novelist seems doomed either to have the flow of the plot interrupted by equations or to omit the meaning of mathematics; without the nitty-gritty of maths it is impossible to convey any of the beauty of the subject. In Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture , Doxiadis is fortunate in having at the heart of his story a problem that is simple to explain. In 1742, the Prussian-born Christian Goldbach suggested that every even number bigger than 2 is the sum of two prime numbers: 6=3+3, 8=5+3, 10=7+3... (A prime number is one that cannot be divided by any number except 1 and itself, such as 5 or 7.)

For 200 years every even number that has been tested has obeyed Goldbach's conjecture, but nobody has ever been able to prove that the conjecture holds true for every even number up to infinity. Having established the problem without traumatising the reader, Doxiadis spends the rest of the novel concentrating on his characters and plot, in particular Petros Papachristos and his quest to prove the conjecture. The result is a highly readable novel about what drives mathematicians to spend decades searching for solutions to apparently insoluble problems.

By comparison, The Parrot's Theorem contains considerably more mathematics. Denis Guedj, Professor of the History of Science at Paris VIII University, has constructed a Sophie's World -type schema that enables him to use a child as a channel for explaining numerous mathematical ideas to his readers. The bizarre plot concerns a mathematical hermit in the Amazon jungle, an evil criminal genius, a murder mystery, a Parisian bookseller and a deaf child called Max who encounters an exceptionally eloquent parrot.

Along the way Max learns about 2,000 years of mathematics, which means that there are large sections discussing topics such as geometry, arithmetic, zero, imaginary numbers and calculus. Non-mathematicians will find some of these pages heavy going, but if they can persevere and comprehend the lines of logic, the consequence will be a genuine insight into the wonder of numbers. Unfortunately, no easy alternative exists when it comes to learning about mathematics, as Ptolemy II learned when he asked Euclid if there was a shortcut to understanding geometry. Euclid replied: "There is no royal road to geometry."

The plot is just about engaging enough to maintain the reader's momentum through the didactic sections. If further sustenance is required, one can look forward to Guedj's charming historical detours. For example, he describes the ethos of the Pythagorean Brotherhood. When a disciple entered the Brotherhood, he had to give all his worldly goods to the community. For five years students could only listen to Pythagoras's teaching from behind a curtain . . . Those who failed the tests of the Brotherhood were expelled, but were given twice the value of the goods that they had originally contributed. If they could not gain intellectually, then they should be compensated materially. A grave was dug within the grounds of the school, symbolising the tragedy of having lost a potential mathematician.

So Guedj's novel contains a pleasant plot, some excellent mathematical lectures and great historical tales, but how does it compare to books about real mathematics? I may be biased, but none of the fictional mathematics that I have so far read quite matches the standard of the narrative non-fiction currently being published. Hoffman's The Man Who Loved Only Numbers is a brilliant biography of Paul Erdös, one the great mathematicians of the 20th century, who dedicated his entire life to proving mathematical theorems. Erdös also had a penchant for one-liners that are as witty as any that a novelist could fabricate.

Sylvia Nasar's A Beautiful Mind is the story of John Nash, who did his greatest mathematics in his twenties before succumbing to paranoid schizophrenia. The book is an elementary introduction to game theory, but it is also a romance, a tragedy and an examination of madness and its treatments in the 1950s and 1960s. In both these cases, the truth is stranger than any mathematical fiction.

If they could not gain intellectually, then they should be compensated materially. A grave was dug within the grounds of the school, symbolising the tragedy of having lost a potential mathematician. So Guedj's novel contains a pleasant plot, some excellent mathematical lectures and great historical tales, but how does it compare to books about real mathematics? I may be biased, but none of the fictional mathematics that I have so far read quite matches the standard of the narrative non-fiction currently being published. Hoffman's The Man Who Loved Only Numbers is a brilliant biography of Paul Erdös, one the great mathematicians of the 20th century, who dedicated his entire life to proving mathematical theorems. Erdös also had a penchant for one-liners that are as witty as any that a novelist could fabricate. Sylvia Nasar's A Beautiful Mind is the story of John Nash, who did his greatest mathematics in his twenties before succumbing to paranoid schizophrenia. The book is an elementary introduction to game theory, but it is also a romance, a tragedy and an examination of madness and its treatments in the 1950s and 1960s. In both these cases, the truth is stranger than any mathematical fiction.

webTitle: Guardian review: Augusta Leigh: Byron's Half-Sister by Michael and Melissa Bakewell

fields.headline: Invisible woman
fields.standfirst: Why did Byron fall for his half-sister? Michael and Melissa Bakewell speculate in their biography, Augusta Leigh: Byron's Half-Sister
fields.trailText: Why did Byron fall for his half-sister? Michael and Melissa Bakewell speculate in their biography, Augusta Leigh: Byron's Half-Sister
fields.body:
Augusta Leigh: Byron's Half-Sister by Michael and Melissa Bakewell 438pp, Chatto & Windus, £25
Buy it at BOL

This is the latest in a line of biographies of people who are not as interesting as those with whom they are famously associated. Like the others, it is fraught with a tension between wanting to devote as much space to the famous as possible while maintaining the integrity of its project. Augusta Leigh (1783-1851) was the half-sister of the poet Lord Byron. She was also his lover. Aside from that, she does not appear to have been a very remarkable person. One might say she did no more than provide the means for her histrionic relative to prove himself right about what he had always suspected: that he was doomed to be a villain and an outcast.

The truth is less simple than that. Byron fled the country in 1816 because his wife, Annabella, was levelling three accusations at him as part of divorce proceedings: as well as incest (not then technically a crime), he was charged with homosexuality and heterosexual sodomy (both then crimes). His conviction that he had married the wrong woman drove him to treat his wife with unforgivable cruelty. In the final stages of her pregnancy he would station himself in the room below her bedroom and throw soda-water bottles at the ceiling to keep her awake.

Subtract Augusta from Byron's life, and he would still have found a way to get himself ostracised. Subtract Byron from Augusta's life, and what is left? The answer is an existence caught curiously between the distinctive and the obscure. Augusta was brought up at the likes of Holdernesse House and Castle Howard, before moving into the uncomfortably small Six Mile Bottom near Newmarket. Her penchant for dashing rakes - her husband and cousin, George, was one, though not in Byron's league - was the only eccentricity in a shy and practical nature.

The Bakewells save their subject matter from this dangerous equivocality by the sureness of their descriptive touch. We read of the gambling, the gossip, the parties and the daily domestic arrangements. The sketch of George Leigh is particularly memorable. A sporting bore, he seems to have named one daughter, Medora, after a horse; when Byron became engaged, he took bets for and against the marriage taking place.

As to Augusta, then, why did Byron love her so? Throughout their adult relationship she was either pregnant or looking after very young children. She was not interested in his poetry. When he suggested to her at the beginning of their affair (before his marriage, but not before hers) that she run away with him to the continent, she seemed eager, hesitated, then declined. This lack of passion may have played its part in the fascination she held for him; he felt that if there were scenes to be made, then it should be he who made them.

The Bakewells stress her ability to make him laugh (she was an accomplished mimic); and laugh, above all, at himself. She made him reasonable by not taking his unreasonableness seriously, a trick his wife never discovered. When, during his honeymoon (which he gallantly termed his "treaclemoon"), Augusta heard that he had "taken to stalking the long gallery in the middle of the night with his pistol and his dagger, threatening to kill himself", she advised Annabella to ignore these "grumps".

This seems to have been the key. Unable to pose, when alone with his half-sister Byron was forced to relax, to be natural and even pleasant. One of the great unanswerable questions of their histories is what would have happened if the two had gone away together in 1813. As it was, after the crisis of Byron's marriage and subsequent exile, Augusta was left at the mercy of a spendthrift husband she did not love and an embittered sister-in-law bent on revenge. Unsurprisingly, the rest of her life - as described here so fully by the Bakewells, who make it readable against the odds - was wretched.

webTitle: Guardian review:  Idioglossia by Eleanor Bailey

fields.headline: Intimate escapes
fields.standfirst: Justine Jordan  on family feuds in Eleanor Bailey's Idioglossia
fields.trailText: Justine Jordan on family feuds in Eleanor Bailey's Idioglossia
fields.body:
Idioglossia by Eleanor Bailey 381pp, Doubleday, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Is madness more than "feeling not how others felt"? Can you be held responsible for giving your child a loveless upbringing if you were unloved as a child? And when dysfunctional patterns have been laid down over the generations, can a family find the capacity to change? Idioglossia , Eleanor Bailey's first novel and a domestic saga for the Prozac generation, worries at these enormous, intimate questions through the relationships of four generations of unhappy women. It's an ambitious project, attempted through a series of flashbacks covering 90 years, and a multiplicity of voices from the mundane to the maddened.

The primary matriarch is sour, ancient Edie, expert emotional manipulator; her loathed daughter Grace, lost to schizophrenia, is the significant absence at the heart of the book. Then there's Grace's middle-aged daughter, Maggie, who was raised in isolation on a cruise ship after her mother's incarceration; finally, Maggie's unwanted daughter Sarah, drifting miserably through careerless confusion and detached casual sex.

It is thirtysomething Sarah, born into an age of stability and affluence, who has suffered least, expects most and rages hardest: "Nobody used to have time to have this depression," spits Edie of her great-granddaughter. But Sarah cannot identify her constant low-level upset: "I have nothing to complain about and that is pre cisely my complaint... I have choices: real coffee, 24-hour supermarkets, freedom and daytime television. And none of them does it for me. The joke is that I'm still totally fucked off."

It's too late for Edie, and a lifetime too late for Grace. Maggie has a chance of happiness, though, with Sarah's father, back after 30 years to challenge the self-protective order of her life. And so does Sarah with the reclusive Alex, also hugging a childhood trauma, who is as uncomfortable with intimacy as she is. Both couples find a haven in each other, a chance to be childlike that was strangled in childhood. They play games fiercely, banter, speak in riddles, sharing the private language or "idioglossia" of the title.

But the most accomplished sections of this almost overstuffed book deal with the relationships between the women themselves. Bailey has a sophisticated ear for familial torture -Edie's vicious assurances that they'll all end up in the loony bin/never get a man/be sorry when she dies - and doesn't flinch to unpack the venom between Maggie and Sarah, the petulant "I hate you" of the daughter receiving a fervent "I hate you too".

Idioglossia is oddly sweet-and-sour in tone, strong on misery but also on sentiment. And despite the deftly woven architecture of mirrors, mazes, riddles and games, the subject matter stretches the breezy writing style to breaking point, throwing up such awful sentences as "There came, as always, a sense of renewal with the dawn". The undeveloped, sub-Kate Atkinson supernatural elements are a distraction from the exploration of inner terrors.

The novel is crammed with escapes from the world - Grace's asylum, Maggie's cruise-ship childhood, Alex's book-lined retreat, the board and card games all the characters love - but finally Idioglossia puts with conviction a happier alternative: what Vonnegut called the nation of two, escape into intimacy with another.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Silence of Sodom by Mark D Jordan

fields.headline: Catholic tastes
fields.standfirst: The Church is broader than bigotry, says Eric Griffiths after reading Mark D Jordan's The Silence of Sodom: Homosexuality in Modern Catholicism
fields.trailText: The Church is broader than bigotry, says Eric Griffiths after reading Mark D Jordan's The Silence of Sodom: Homosexuality in Modern Catholicism
fields.body:
The Silence of Sodom: Homosexuality in Modern Catholicism by Mark D Jordan 248pp, University of Chicago Press, £16
Buy it at BOL

Italy, where the Bishop of Rome hangs his mitre, has the lowest birth rate in western Europe. Several explanations of this fact are possible, but it seems likely that practical disregard of the Pope's teaching on "artificial" methods of contraception has played a part. The limp arguments adduced in support of that doctrine may even have hardened Italian hearts against it. The voice of the Roman Catholic church in its homeland is, on this matter of sexual conduct, a shrill, small voice.

Gays in the US by contrast, if The Silence of Sodom is to be believed, need to pay keener heed to the Pope because "religious condemnation remains the most potent homophobic rhetoric" and "compelling cases can be made that identifying as a Catholic (or Christian) at this moment in American life can only be a form of collaboration with homosexuality's most dangerous enemies". However many such cases "can be made", Mark D Jordan makes none of them, just as when he alleges that the Catholic church "in a number of countries... represents the most powerful voice in favor of the repression and persecution of lesbians and gays", he names no such country. Like many Catholics, Professor Jordan has a blessed naivety about political realities; he probably imagines the Swiss Guard possesses a terrifying strike power.

A pervasive weakness of his book stems from his failure to distinguish what is specific to Catholicism, as distinct from Christianity or other religions and religion substitutes. The Pope holds no patent on fear and loathing. I once knew a Catalan Maoist who assured all who would listen that, as a result of the cultural revolution, only one homosexual remained in the People's Republic. Nor was it the Catholic church that subjected US homosexuals to electroconvulsive therapy; that was a bitter fruit of the Freudianism to which Jordan makes intermittent, unreflective appeals.

It might rather be charged against current Catholic doctrine and practice that they lack any distinctively Catholic wisdom or compassion, as for instance in those dioceses and religious orders, running scared from scandal, that have handed over the assessment of vocations to psychiatrists and "require extensive personality and psychological testing for their recruits... some have even resorted to penile response tests" (Charles R Morris, American Catholic). This sits oddly with other official teaching - liberation theology is condemned for relying on Marxist tenets thought incompatible with Christianity, while at the same time the church capitulates to a science of the soul that aims to cure homosexuality along with other lamentable aberrations of the human creature, such as religious belief.

Affliction, unlike fish, is not good for the brain, and abrasive years of conflicting loyalties as a gay Catholic have told on Jordan. He badly misstates some factual claims, as when he informs us that in the US "everyone seems to agree that there are now more homosexuals in the Catholic priesthood and religious life than in the population at large". Like many things everyone agrees on, this would be astounding if true, but he means only "a higher proportion" not "more". He doesn't bother to give statistics to back the allegation that "sexually active gay clerics and ex-clerics seem so often to prefer the leather or S&M 'subcultures' ". Some of the book is mere anecdotage: he met a gay bartender with a Sacred Heart of Jesus tattoo, from which he infers a kinship between homosexual and Catholic cultures.

Much that he says is as little specific to homosexuality as it is to Catholicism. He condescends to young men by telling them they cannot "truly appreciate what has already been done to [them] by the ambient homophobia", though he might as well have written "the ambient heterophilia" or any other force of acculturation. "Growing up Catholic" may well be "remembered as growing up in a kind of bondage", but the same is true for many of growing up in Aylesbury. He stipulates that "you have not felt the force of religious hate speech until you can condemn it angrily and in public precisely as hate speech", which amounts to saying that your view doesn't count unless it coincides with his. He sounds in this respect quite like some Catholic bishops.

Professor Jordan has my sympathy; it is hard to keep your temper and your wits when contemplating some pronouncements of the Catholic hierarchy, for instance the repulsive slur in the 1975 Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith's declaration on sexual ethics, that remarked on homosexuals' "inability to fit into society". It is not as a homosexual but as a Catholic that I find this objectionable; it betrays not only ignorance about the reality of homosexuals' lives but, worse, a sell-out of the gospel to the kingdom of this world, a rendering unto Caesar of things which are not his. It is not the church's business to assist in the manufacture of individuals who "fit into" society; her mission is to strive towards a society fit for the flourishing of the individuals whom God created. The church hierarchy has many times connived with coarse ethical majoritarianism; homosexuals have not been the only, or even the principal, victims of such connivance.

Many gays hate Christianity, perhaps especially Catholicism. This is unsurprising; as Auden said, "Those to whom evil is done/ Do evil in return". Yet history does not support what John Boswell in his pioneering book, Christianity, Social Tolerance, and Homosexuality , called "the common idea that religious belief - Christian or other - has been the cause of intolerance in regard to gay people". Gays who wish to do more than shore up their own preferred bigotry would do better to read Boswell than Jordan. And Catholics who are not wholly sated with the spurious certainties palmed off on them in place of the Gospel challenge will learn more from Gareth Moore's splendidly considered The Body in Context: Sex and Catholicism , which has the advantage of not isolating homosexuality from other questions in Christian sexual ethics.

Each group, and particularly anyone who belongs to them both, needs constant reminding that Christian teaching can be taught only by Christ-like means. He said "in my Father's house are many mansions", from which it probably follows that the house has many approach roads too. One thing at least homosexuals and Catholics must have in common - the hope that practising makes perfect.

webTitle: Guardian review: Liberace by Darden Asbury Pyron

fields.headline: Sex, lies and candyfloss
fields.standfirst: Larry Adler  is appalled by the spectre of Darden Asbury Pyron's Liberace
fields.trailText: Larry Adler is appalled by the spectre of Darden Asbury Pyron's Liberace
fields.body:
Liberace by Darden Asbury Pyron
502pp, University of Chicago Press, £19.50
Buy it at BOL

Before I read this book I knew, from having seen his shows in Cleveland and in Chicago, that Liberace put on the act of a camping queen. And I knew about his libel case against the Daily Mirror , when he was asked: "Are you a homosexual?" "No," Liberace replied. "Have you ever indulged in homosexual practices?" "No, sir, never in my life."

Both of these answers were lies, yet the jury believed him and he won the case. The author of this biography, Darden Asbury Pyron, admits they were lies. He then describes several ways in which they could be construed as not really being lies, citing Proust, Foucault and Rousseau for the defence. It all rings hollow, like much about his subject: Liberace never admitted his homosexuality. He consistently denied, though he knew better, that he had Aids. He died on February 4, 1987.

There is no need for revisionism because of that. I have spoken to sad but kindly men on the Mirror and other newspapers who have met every celebrity arriving from the United States in the past 30 years. They all say that this deadly, winking, sniggering, snuggling, chromium-plated, scent-impregnated, luminous, quivering, giggling, fruit-flavoured, mincing, ice-covered heap of mother love had the biggest reception and impact on London since Chaplin arrived in 1921.

This appalling man - and I use the word appalling in none other than its true sense of terrifying - hit the country as violently as Churchill receiving the cheers on VE Day. He reeked with the kind of emetic language that can only make grown men long for a quiet corner, an aspidistra, a handkerchief and the old heave-ho.

Slobbering over his mother, winking at his brother and counting the cash every second, this superb piece of candyfloss had an answer for every situation. Nobody has purveyed a bigger slagheap of lilac-covered hokum. And nobody has ever made so much money out of high-speed piano playing, with the ghost of Chopin gibbering at every note. There must have been something wrong with us, that our teenagers longing for sex and our middle-aged matrons fed up with sex should have fallen for such a sugary mountain of jingling claptrap.

The biography reports the so-called "affair" with Joanne Rio that appeared to be not an affair at all - rather an attempt to overcome the reports of homosexuality. Liberace also dated Sonja Henie and Mae West, both gay men's icons. Scott Thorson, Liberace's live-in lover for six years, later sued for palimony, the first suit of its kind. His own lawyers advised against taking the case to court, and eventually he dropped the suit.

Then of course there are the trimmings, all of which are listed here: the outrageous costumes, the piano-shaped swimming pool, the grin that seemed riveted to his face. In the 20-odd photos, the perpetual grin is in 18 of them.

It could have been different. Pyron states that the young Liberace was influenced by the Polish pianist Ignace Jan Paderewski. At one point the young boy played for Paderewski, who was quoted as saying "some day this young man will take my place". There were some similarities in our careers - I, too, was influenced by Paderewski, and was expelled from music college for playing his early hit Yes, We Have No Bananas at a graduation ceremony. But as a musician, I just could not respect Liberace's music. It was speed for speed's sake, flashy technical acrobatics, and to me no more than that. This book doesn't change my mind.

They all say that this deadly, winking, sniggering, snuggling, chromium-plated, scent-impregnated, luminous, quivering, giggling, fruit-flavoured, mincing, ice-covered heap of mother love had the biggest reception and impact on London since Chaplin arrived in 1921. This appalling man - and I use the word appalling in none other than its true sense of terrifying - hit the country as violently as Churchill receiving the cheers on VE Day. He reeked with the kind of emetic language that can only make grown men long for a quiet corner, an aspidistra, a handkerchief and the old heave-ho. Slobbering over his mother, winking at his brother and counting the cash every second, this superb piece of candyfloss had an answer for every situation. Nobody has purveyed a bigger slagheap of lilac-covered hokum. And nobody has ever made so much money out of high-speed piano playing, with the ghost of Chopin gibbering at every note. There must have been something wrong with us, that our teenagers longing for sex and our middle-aged matrons fed up with sex should have fallen for such a sugary mountain of jingling claptrap. The biography reports the so-called "affair" with Joanne Rio that appeared to be not an affair at all - rather an attempt to overcome the reports of homosexuality. Liberace also dated Sonja Henie and Mae West, both gay men's icons. Scott Thorson, Liberace's live-in lover for six years, later sued for palimony, the first suit of its kind. His own lawyers advised against taking the case to court, and eventually he dropped the suit. Then of course there are the trimmings, all of which are listed here: the outrageous costumes, the piano-shaped swimming pool, the grin that seemed riveted to his face. In the 20-odd photos, the perpetual grin is in 18 of them. It could have been different. Pyron states that the young Liberace was influenced by the Polish pianist Ignace Jan Paderewski. At one point the young boy played for Paderewski, who was quoted as saying "some day this young man will take my place". There were some similarities in our careers - I, too, was influenced by Paderewski, and was expelled from music college for playing his early hit Yes, We Have No Bananas at a graduation ceremony. But as a musician, I just could not respect Liberace's music. It was speed for speed's sake, flashy technical acrobatics, and to me no more than that. This book doesn't change my mind.

webTitle: James Hopkin  looks at Czech fiction

fields.headline: Prague spring
fields.standfirst: Continuing our series,  James Hopkin  looks at Czech fiction
fields.trailText: Continuing our series, James Hopkin looks at Czech fiction
fields.body:
Since the Soviet invasion of August 1968 and the Velvet Revolution of 1989, the older generation of Czech writers has been well served by translations. Jaroslav Hasek's picaresque novel, The Good Soldier Svejk (1923), is a national favourite: its garrulous prose and carnivalesque laughter are characteristic of a Bohemian literature that could seldom dare to be overtly political. Following the ludicrous yet effective antics of its anti-hero Svejk, an idiot savant in the Austro-Hungarian army, the novel takes on the church, the state and the army with a bumbling fury. The result is a Czech Don Quixote, blissfully excessive and strangely pertinent.

Bohumil Hrabal carried on this mischievous spirit of defiance as Czech literature remained underground and forged its own democracy. Closely Observed Trains (1965) is set at the end of the war and Too Loud a Solitude (1980) during Communist oppression. Both are slim classics that read as if written while running down a hill; they recover humour and humanity from difficult times.

Perhaps the best introduction to Hrabal's work is I Served the King of England (1980), which depicts the bizarre life of a bellboy at the Golden Prague Hotel on the eve of the second world war. There is sadness here and an implicit feeling of loss, yet such is the felicity of Hrabal's prose that his reflectiveness merely preludes more astonishing touches of wisdom and beauty. And the city of Prague is magically invoked throughout.

Josef Skvorecky's fervent anti-communism led him to emigrate to Canada following the 1968 invasion. The Engineer of Human Souls (1977) is his magnum opus, but a more accessible read is Talkin' Moscow Blues , which brings together his lively and deeply ironic essays on politics, literature, jazz and his wartime childhood.

Kafka aside, Milan Kundera is the Czech Republic's best-known writer (although he now lives in Paris and writes in French), and it's hard to beat The Unbearable Lightness of Being for a dramatisation of the spring of 1968. Sardonic and philosophical, Kundera is an astute observer of human behaviour and, like the best Czech writers, effortlessly combines sexual and national politics.

The same can be said for Ivan Klíma. A survivor of the Terezin camp, Klíma's work explores love and freedom with insight, compassion and wit. The narrator of Love and Garbage (1968) gives up his thesis on Kafka to become a road-sweeper, using his free thinking time to muse on the nature of love and liberty and the demands of being a writer. Both poignant and funny, this is an extraordinary novel. The Spirit of Prague, a collection of Klima's essays and articles, is also worth investigating, while Jan Neruda's Prague Tales (1877) remains a classic for its vignettes of life in the Malá Strana at the end of the 19th century.

Among the younger generation of writers, Michael Viewegh is very popular. As their titles suggest, The Wonderful Years of Lousy Living (1992) and Bringing up Girls in Bohemia (1994) are irreverent social satires that playfully deconstruct the freedoms enjoyed since 1989. They're also very funny. Viewegh is included in a valuable anthology of new Czech fiction, Daylight in Nightclub Inferno (1997), which also offers pieces from Ewald Murrer, Daniela Hodrová, Alexandra Berková and - perhaps the most promising - Jíri Kratochvil.

Once described by Ted Hughes as "one of the half dozen most important poets living anywhere", Miroslav Holub is a poet-scientist whose pieces read as if each word has been persuaded into place by a delicate fingertip. Poems Before and After (1990) gathers work written either side of the Soviet invasion, while The Rampage (1997) is his most recent collection.

 To order any of these titles, call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166 102.
