fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: The Durham captain Nick Speak made his top score of the season to give his side an unlikely first-innings lead in the First Division relegation battle against Kent at Chester-le-Street.
fields.body:
The Durham captain Nick Speak made his top score of the season to give his side an unlikely first-innings lead in the First Division relegation battle against Kent at Chester-le-Street.

Fifteen wickets fell before tea as Durham slipped to 130 for eight in reply to the visitors' 170, but Speak and Neil Killeen stayed together throughout the evening session with the captain on 79 as Durham managed to reach 209 for eight at the close.

Martin Saggers took full advantage of the conditions to complete his first five-wicket haul for Kent against his former county. But the lack of support in the Kent attack was badly exposed with no other bowler taking more than one wicket.

Angus Fraser and Phil Tufnell put Middlesex firmly in charge on day two of the Second Division match at Trent Bridge. They took three wickets each as Nottinghamshire were bowled out for 245 in reply to Middlesex's impressive first innings of 412. Chris Tolley was Nottinghamshire's top scorer with 60 and, forced to follow on, the home side had gone a little way to avoiding an innings defeat by reaching 29 at the close without loss.

The Derbyshire batsman Rob Bailey again highlighted the lack of depth in West Indies' attack ahead of next week's fourth Test. Without Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh, the tourists' bowling looked ordinary as Bailey led a recovery with an unbeaten century. West Indies cruised to 110 for three from 18 overs by the close after Derbyshire declared 148 runs behind on 242 for five.

Sri Lanka's former captain Arjuna Ranatunga left the field in tears to a standing ovation on his retirement from international cricket yesterday as the third and final Test against South Africa in Colombo ended in a draw with the series tied 1-1. Needing 263 for victory, the Sri Lankans reached 195 for four, including an unbeaten 101 by Mahela Jayawardene.

Yorkshire officials have given the green light to a £10m redevelopment of Headingley to upgrade seating and spectator facilities.

India have pulled out of next month's Sahara Cup series against Pakistan because of the recent violence in the disputed territory of Kashmir. The five-match series was scheduled to be held in Toronto, Canada, on September 9-17.

fields.headline: Sussex subdued by core values
fields.standfirst:
Sussex 232
Northampton 327-4
fields.trailText:
Sussex 232

Northampton 327-4
fields.body:
John Prescott would be most impressed. Those who seek profit from spin were found out at Wantage Road yesterday. The Northamptonshire pair, Russell Warren and Tony Penberthy, pursued the core values of solid defence and judicious attack to leave the Second Division leaders well placed for victory.

Both made their highest scores of the season and they will be back for more today. Warren, who was on 98 for nine overs, took 277 balls over his century. To rub it in, he is only playing because David Sales is struggling with tendinitis.

Their partnership of 188 broke one of Northamptonshire's more courageous records. Eighty years ago, Don Denton batted with an artificial leg - a memento of France in 1917 - and a runner in helping put on 131 for the fifth wicket against Sussex. These are clearly softer days.

At the outset Sussex had reason for optimism. On a pitch offering help to spinners, the onus was on Umer Rashid and Justin Bates to follow the example set by Jason Brown and Graeme Swann on the first day; it proved too much for them. At times they kept the batsmen quiet, occasionally forcing an indiscretion, but they rarely carried the same threat, 53 overs bringing combined figures of two for 144.

Sussex's only encouragement came before lunch. Northamptonshire scored at four-an-over for the first hour but were careless along the way. Matthew Hayden clipped a catch to square leg and Mal Loye played across a straight ball from James Kirtley after hitting his previous two deliveries through the leg side for four.

Adrian Rollins then edged to the wicketkeeper Nick Wilton to leave Northamptonshire struggling at 76 for three. From there, they confirmed new-found resilience.

Jeff Cook knows much of patience. Born in Australia, he waited seven years to qualify for county cricket and here he took 72 deliveries to make his first 13 runs. Then, seemingly fed up, he lofted Bates for six and drove his next ball through extra-cover. By now he could not help himself.

Another attacking stroke in Bates' next over was sliced into the hands of Adams at cover, bringing Warren and Penberthy together and Sussex only saw the back of them as they walked off at the close.

fields.headline: Larsson helps spur Celtic
fields.trailText:
Uefa Cup, first leg, first round
Jeunesse Esch 0 - 4 Celtic
Celtic's promising early-season form continued in Luxembourg last night when they breezed past part-timers Jeunesse Esch.
fields.body:
Celtic's promising early-season form continued in Luxembourg last night when they breezed through the first leg of their first-round Uefa Cup qualifying encounter against the outclassed part-timers Jeunesse Esch. Lubo Moravcik scored a goal in each half in a 4-0 win.

Martin O'Neill had made four changes from the side which beat Motherwell last weekend, Moravcik coming in for Eyal Berkovic and Johan Mjallby making his first appearance of the season as Olivier Tebily joined the substitutes. Tom Boyd and Stilian Petrov were injured and replaced by Vidar Riseth and Bobby Petta.

The only surprise was that it took Celtic 37 minutes to open their account. Henrik Larsson, making his first appearance in a European club competition since breaking a leg in Lyon last October, slid the ball into the path of Moravcik inside the area and he calmly slotted it into the bottom corner.

The tie was killed off when Chris Sutton and Larsson combined on the edge of the area and the Swede controlled the ball with his right foot before scoring with his left. Petta scored the final goal when he cut through a group of players before unleashing an unstoppable drive nine minutes from time.

Scotland's other clubs in European action did not impose themselves as impressively as Celtic. Scott Severin and Darren Jackson gave Hearts a win in Iceland against IBV Vestmannyjar but Aberdeen were beaten 2-1 at home by Bohemians after taking the lead. Trevor Molloy scored a last-minute penalty for the Dubliners. Truly a Bohemian rhapsody.

fields.headline: Portsmouth pay out £3m for Mills and Taylor
fields.trailText: Portsmouth broke their transfer record on two strikers yesterday, signing Lee Mills from Bradford for £1.2m and Bob Taylor from Manchester City for £1.8m.
fields.body:
Portsmouth broke their transfer record on two strikers yesterday, signing Lee Mills from Bradford for £1.2m and Bob Taylor from Manchester City for £1.8m.

Mills' departure from Valley Parade follows the arrival of Benito Carbone, and Bradford hope to sign another forward, Ashley Ward, from Blackburn Rovers next week.

A £1.5m fee has been agreed, although Everton have also expressed interest in the 29-year-old and could scupper the deal. Heading for the exit at Bradford are the forward Lee Mills, who will join Portsmouth today for £1m subject to personal terms, and the centre-half Ashley Westwood, who has gone to Sheffield Wednesday on a month's loan.

Coventry's manager Gordon Strachan has strongly criticised Rangers, claiming the Scottish champions turned down his offers for Neil McMann and Jorg Albertz after agreeing fees for the players.

Neil Lennon has signed a new four-year contract with Leicester City worth £5.75m.

Germany's midfielder Jens Jeremies could miss the World Cup qualifier against England on October 7 after tearing left knee ligaments.

webTitle: Should McManaman stay at Real Madrid?

fields.headline: Should he stay or should he go?
fields.standfirst: Steve McManaman is being paid £56,000 a week by Real Madrid but since Luis Figo arrived there is little prospect of a game for the midfielder. The England man's decision is a hard one, so we asked various interested parties to enter the debate
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman is being paid £56,000 a week by Real Madrid but since Luis Figo arrived there is little prospect of a game for the midfielder. The England man's decision is a hard one, so we asked various interested parties to enter the debate
fields.body:
STAY

Ian Rush

Former Liverpool and Wales striker. Spent one season with Juventus in the mid-80s before returning to Anfield

"For the time being he should just sit tight, relax and let other people deal with a problem which is very much of their making. This is something which must be addressed and then sorted by the club's board and the team coach.

"Steve is entitled to dig in his heels. Although he is not the sort of player to put up his feet and count the money, he should not be pushed out. They signed him, they gave him the big money, the long contract, so the onus is on them.

"I did face a similar problem. It became clear to me that the Juventus coach, or maybe it was the club, was not entirely comfortable with me. I realised that the writing was on the wall - albeit in a language I couldn't fully understand.

"Steve is a lad who likes to work for his money, so I can't envisage a situation where he would play reserve football just to see his bank balance build up. He'll want paying well wherever he goes to next - but what he'll really want is to play football. Money is great but you can only spend so much."

Ian Clarkson

Captain of the Nationwide League newcomers, Kidderminster Harriers

"What a nice problem to have - £56,000 a week is a very tidy sum. He could afford to go somewhere for less. I'm sure he'd earn at least £30,000 a week elsewhere, and that's what I'd take if it meant first-team football.

"But it might be worth him biding his time. Football can change quickly; just because he's not in the team at the start of the season does not mean he will not get back into it. Coaches have a notoriously short shelf-life in Spain, and it's generally accepted in football that the 11 who start the season do not usually finish it."

Michael Thomas

Former Arsenal, Liverpool and Benfica midfielder, now training with Wimbledon

"If he leaves I can't see him coming back here. He'll go to another club in Spain or somewhere else on the continent. But you never know what might happen at Real Madrid. Things might change. The supporters still love him, so you never know.

"It was hard for me at Benfica knowing I would never get a chance [after Graeme Souness was sacked as the coach]. It's hard going to get motivated but it's a mental thing more than anything. If you give in, they'll break you. But I think Steve is strong enough. When I was at Liverpool with him he was strong, so I think he can handle it.

"I wouldn't say it's the Real coach who has made the decision. The coach never gets a say abroad; it's always upstairs - the money men."

Ben Hamilton

Football finance analyst

"I would move to another club either within Spain or somewhere in Italy. I would want to carry on improving my game and my mind. What is the point of coming back now? When he finishes he will be more than the typical retired footballer and the foreign experience has helped him.

"I would take a pay-cut for first-team football. There's a lot to admire about McManaman. People have been crying out for English players to go to Italy or Spain - it improves the enjoyment of the world game."

GO

Luther Blissett Milan 1983-84, now reserve-team coach at Watford

"The decision is simple: do they have a decent standard of reserve-team football?

"As long as they have, and there is a reasonable expectancy for him to get back in the first team in the forseeable future, it is fair enough for him to stay.

"I was at AC Milan and it was plain that I was surplus to requirements. There was no reserve-team football and I didn't want to be sitting on the bench. I just wanted to be playing football.

"I knew I could either come back to Watford or take the option of a couple of other Italian clubs who were interested in me. I decided to come back.

"If a club doesn't want you in this country it's not very pleasant, but they make it even harder on the continent.

"If that's the case at Real Madrid he should either find another Spanish club or come back to England. I was 22 and I wanted to play. Playing football is, in the end, what it's all about."

Rachel Anderson

Agent

"Joining Real Madrid was a great move, both as a player and personally. But I would come home now. Sometimes you only need to be away for a little while to appreciate what you have left behind. He was underrated here, people never fully appreciated what a great player he is. If I was him and a good club came in for me, I would definitely return. The Premier League is the place to be. It's very difficult to be away from home, players are not trained to handle abroad. But McManaman has handled it very well.

"He probably does not want to come home; he has a wonderful life, he is the envy of all the footballers he grew up with. He has become a better player and we would all appreciate him more if he came home. Perhaps he should come to West Ham. We need players like him. Seriously though, there are probably only two or three clubs in the Premier League who could afford him."

John Barnwell

Head of the League Managers Association

"I would give it three months, perhaps until Christmas, because the last thing I would want to do is throw a fit, say that I have done well but am being treated badly and immediately walk away. I would at least try and prove to the club that I could do it.

"When I was a manager I would tell my players that if you have been left out of the team that's because the manager thinks he has someone better, but your outlook has to be 'I will ram it back down his bloody throat'.

"He's not living in a city that is unpleasant. I would give it a few months and try and get back into the first team. McManaman is at the important part of his career - it's not the beginning, it's not the end, it's the crucial bit in the middle when he needs to be playing top-class football regularly.

"They have not dropped him because he's been playing badly, but circumstances have overtaken him. McManaman's problem is that after playing for Liverpool and Real Madrid, that limits the number of clubs he would be interested in going to. [But] if I didn't make it by Christmas I would be off."

WELL, IT DEPENDS ON HOW YOU LOOK AT IT...

Jack Lamport Mitchell Consultant sports psychologist who works with several footballers and other sportsmen

"What Steve McManaman has to do is draw up a list of pros and cons. He has to look at the financial, social and cultural aspects, friends and family, and then prioritise them so that he can make an objective decision.

"The crucial question is how much does he want to leave? If I was him I would look at the aspects that I am satisfied with and not satisfied with.

"The money has reached such a level with him that he probably does not worry about it. He can afford to look at other things like being with friends, family, the weather and the quality of life. I would look for another club in Spain or somewhere else on the continent. He seems quite happy there.

"He can always come back to England [some other time]. McManaman is learning the [Spanish] language, he likes the food, he's obviously got some friends so what's the point in coming back at this stage?"

fields.headline: City to snap up £3m Howey
fields.trailText: A frantic afternoon of transfer activity saw Manchester City close in on a £3m deal for the Newcastle United centre-back Steve Howey yesterday and Chelsea sign Christian Panucci on loan from Internazionale for a year with a view to a permanent deal.
fields.body:
A frantic afternoon of transfer activity saw Manchester City close in on a £3m deal for the Newcastle United centre-back Steve Howey yesterday and Chelsea sign Christian Panucci on loan from Internazionale for a year with a view to a permanent deal.

City had a bid accepted last night for Howey, who is due at Maine Road to finalise the terms of a three-year contract, subject to a medical. The 28-year-old was capped four times by England under Terry Venables in the mid-90s.

The defender is Newcastle's longest-serving player after 14 years at St James' Park and would end City's search for a centre-half. Recent attempts to sign Ugo Ehiogu from Aston Villa failed after the clubs were unable to agree a fee.

City's midfielder Jamie Pollock was last night thinking over a £600,000 transfer to Crystal Palace, but more excitement was generated in London by Panucci's arrival at Chelsea, who have an option to make the move permanent from next season.

The 27-year-old right-back, who is also comfortable at centre-half, was out of favour with Inter's coach Marcello Lippi after a public fall-out and failed to make Italy's Euro 2000 squad. He is not expected to start against Manchester United on Sunday in the Charity Shield.

"I want to stay here for two, three, four years," said the player, who won the European Cup alongside Marcel Desailly with Milan in 1994. Panucci, who has 21 Italy caps, also won a European Cup with Real Madrid in 1998 and returned to Italy last season.

"It's an excellent stage for him to not only prove a few points back in Italy but to possibly resurrect his international career," said Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson.

fields.headline: Hussain on the edge
fields.standfirst:
The England captain's frailty is exposed as Test looms
Worcestershire 302
Essex 461-9
fields.trailText:
The England captain's frailty is exposed as Test looms
Worcestershire 302

Essex 461-9
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain, the England captain, must earn a fortune from the manufacturers of cricket balls. Every one, it seems, has his name on it.

His wretched form continued yesterday in the County Championship Second Division when, resuming his innings for Essex on nine, he added only a single before being caught behind.

In 12 completed first-class innings this season - half for Essex and half for England - he has scored 144 runs, which is gross in more ways than one. One does not need Bill Frindall to work out his average of 12, the sort of figure that would be sniffily disowned by bowlers, let alone batsmen, although injury and international commitments have restricted his opportunities.

On a flat pitch, and on a ground with a reputation for fast scoring, Hussain was desperately looking for some form and confidence before next week's fourth Test against West Indies at Headingley, which is normally user-friendly for bowlers. But at the moment he looks incapable of batting an eyelid.

In the second over of the morning, facing his third ball, Hussain pushed forward to the medium pace of Kabir Ali. The good-length delivery seamed away off the pitch, caught the outside of the bat and was held by the wicketkeeper Steven Rhodes.

Hussain remained in position for some time, as if to show the watching world that there was nothing wrong with the stroke. The nick was so obvious that the umpire, John Steele, did not even bother to give Hussain out. He merely nodded. But when Hussain stood his ground Steele raised his finger by way of confirmation. Forlorn, Hussain dragged himself to the dressing room and refused to discuss his malaise.

His failure yesterday looked even more poignant when he was replaced at the wicket by Stuart Law who, with Paul Prichard, added 166 for the third wicket and then another 185 for the fifth with Stephen Peters.

Hussain is not the first England captain to run out of runs. If Mike Brearley was a famous egg-head he had a few egg-shaped scores to match. And Mike Denness had such an awful time against Dennis Lillee and Jeff Thomson in Australia in 1974-75 that he dropped himself for the fourth Test. There is no chance of Hussain doing that. Besides, his captaincy and fielding qualities are still intact. But a brittle England batting line-up is in urgent need of runs from him.

The issue is important enough to attract the attention of the chairman of selectors David Graveney, though by the time he turned up yesterday Hussain was out. If Graveney is to take Hussain-watching seriously he must buy a faster car. Today the England coach Duncan Fletcher is expected at the Chester Road ground.

Graveney said yesterday: "Nasser is not in the best form and I hope he gets a second opportunity here. But it's not a huge issue for me. These players now play virtually 12 months a year, so it will not always go well for them."

Essex's bowling coach Geoff Arnold, who has been working with Hussain in the nets, said: "There was nothing wrong with his shot today. He played forward, and straight, and the ball left him. He is working on the line of the ball and which deliveries to leave alone.

"Technically he is much better now than when he first played for England and would lean back on the drive and get caught at cover-point. At the moment it's a confidence thing more than anything else."

No one could accuse Law of being short of confidence. This was his fourth century of the season, which is a quiet one for him compared with 1999. It was also his 25th for Essex. He went on to score 189 from 243 balls, including 30 fours. Hussain will not be best pleased if the Australian's effort denies him a second innings.

v Nottinghamshire 4, 24

v Zimbabweans 33

v Gloucestershire 3, 0

v Worcestershire 10

For England

Zimbabwe (1st Test) 10, 21

Zimbabwe (2nd Test) 0

fields.headline: Gran goes off the rails
fields.standfirst: An OAP who's all steamed up over railway modernisation; the Yorkshire town with a new lease of nightlife; a councillor gets in a flap over holiday flats and a tale of sewing woe
fields.trailText: An OAP who's all steamed up over railway modernisation; a Yorkshire town gets a new lease of nightlife; a councillor gets in a flap over holiday flats and a tale of sewing woe
fields.body:
Pensioner signals disapproval over station name change
A radical pensioner has vowed to chain herself to posts outside her local train station to stop a regional railway operator obliterating its historic name.

Grandmother Lily Atkin, 77, says that any plans to rename Thornaby Station would be another nail in the coffin for the Teesside town's identity. The plucky OAP says she will fight for the station "to the bitter end".

Train operator Northern Spirit is bidding for a funding programme that would make Thornaby Station a more important rail link than nearby Stockton. It has been suggested that renaming the station "Stockton South" may attracting the travelling public to the Trans Pennine line.

Mrs Atkin, an ardent campaigner for Thornaby, has long ties with the railway station. Her late father, Albert Crooks, was signalman there for 38 years and she has fond childhood memories of visiting him while he worked.

Her brother was a train driver, her great grandfather was an engine shed foreman and her great-great-grandfather and an uncle also worked on the railways.

"It was much busier than it is now and I remember it was lovely, full of flower boxes," she said.

Mrs Atkin's fellow OAPs are overwhelmingly against Northern Spirit's proposals to drop the town's name.

Sybil Gregory, 74, chairman of Old Thornaby residents association, said: "They are trying to wipe Thornaby off the map."

The rail operator said no decisions have been taken and the public would be consulted.
Middlesborough Evening Gazette

By gum, it's buzzin' in Skipton
Skipton got a taste of the high life this week when the Yorkshire town added a "contemporary bar" to its roster of night spots.

And thirsty locals need not wait too long to partake of a cocktail. Part-owner Dave Rogers says the watering hole has a specially designed long bar so people will not have to queue for drinks.

The bar, built in a converted gas depot, has everything traditional pubs do not. Loud, bright colours, chrome fittings, waitress service and jazz and dance nights are all part of the package, the Craven Herald enthusiastically reports.

The first punters were welcomed on Friday to an invitation-only event with the doors being thrown open to the general public on Saturday.

Mr Rogers said the opening nights were busy and everyone seemed to enjoy themselves. "They were all saying that this is just what Skipton needed," he added.
Craven Herald

Flat refusal
Gwynedd councillor Richard Parry Hughes came under attack from his colleagues after he set up a website to campaign against holiday flats.

The website (www.natyha.co.uk), whose name means "No to holiday homes", sets out an application for 16 flats that were approved by a planning committee meeting with a majority of 9-3.

Cllr Hughes's fellow councillors say the site is "biased" and "slightly over the top". The site's creator, however, remains unrepentant.

"I make no secret of the fact that I strongly oppose this development and I sincerely hope that not a brick of this building will be built," he said. Cllr Hughes says he set up the website because he felt that the general public did not have adequate access to information regarding planning matters:

Councillor Brian Evans said: "I do think it is slightly over the top and goes against our usual way of working.

"I am in favour of the application as this is one area that is in desperate need of development - I don't believe these holiday flats are a big threat - the greatest threat to the area comes from people who buy houses in our town as second homes."

Cllr Hughes strongly opposed Cllr Evans' comments and threw down a gauntlet to his rival in the chamber: "I do not inflict my own personal views on peopleI welcome people, including Cllr Evans to write in with their comments [that] could be included on the site."

The website is currently published only in Welsh but there are plans to have it translated.
North Wales Chronicle

Sign stitch-up
Not only are its banks and sub-post offices closing but rural England woke up to the news this week that the world's largest tapestry is missed by thousands of visitors because it is not adequately sign-posted.

The 267ft tapestry - considerably longer than its rival in Bayeux, France - has become a victim of its rural location, says Jill Taylor, director of Coldharbour Mill in Uffculme, Devon.

"We have been campaigning on and off for the past 10 years but we can't get signage from the North Devon link road or the M5," she says.

Local MP Angela Browning agrees and is backing the call for more signs. She says she is amazed that the "excellent" tapestry is not receiving the full support of Devon county council.

The New World tapestry was begun in the 1970s but only completed in March this year when Prince Charles added the final stitch at his Gloucestershire home. The Queen, Princess Anne and the Queen Mother have all visited the tapestry and added a stitch.

"Many people have given so generously of their time and expertise that it beggars belief that, at the last hurdle, they should be having to fight this crass bureaucracy," said Miss Taylor.

She challenged the council's highways chiefs to visit the tapestry and see for themselves how many visitors it attracts. County council spokesman Peter Doyle said that no formal application for a motorway sign had been made.
Mid Devon Gazette

Letter of the week
I thought Burnley MP Peter Pike had the right attitude when he wished the Queen Mother a happy birthday - something which, correct me if I'm wrong, Pendle MP Gordon Prentice did not do.

I thought that was rather mean of him. No wonder our town, Nelson, never loses its 'Little Moscow' tag. I felt proud to be British watching the Queen Mother celebrate her 100th birthday on TV.

Olive Slater, Sussex Street, Nelson.
Lancashire Evening Telegraph
fields.bodyText: Pensioner signals disapproval over station name change A radical pensioner has vowed to chain herself to posts outside her local train station to stop a regional railway operator obliterating its historic name. Grandmother Lily Atkin, 77, says that any plans to rename Thornaby Station would be another nail in the coffin for the Teesside town's identity. The plucky OAP says she will fight for the station "to the bitter end". Train operator Northern Spirit is bidding for a funding programme that would make Thornaby Station a more important rail link than nearby Stockton. It has been suggested that renaming the station "Stockton South" may attracting the travelling public to the Trans Pennine line. Mrs Atkin, an ardent campaigner for Thornaby, has long ties with the railway station. Her late father, Albert Crooks, was signalman there for 38 years and she has fond childhood memories of visiting him while he worked. Her brother was a train driver, her great grandfather was an engine shed foreman and her great-great-grandfather and an uncle also worked on the railways. "It was much busier than it is now and I remember it was lovely, full of flower boxes," she said. Mrs Atkin's fellow OAPs are overwhelmingly against Northern Spirit's proposals to drop the town's name. Sybil Gregory, 74, chairman of Old Thornaby residents association, said: "They are trying to wipe Thornaby off the map." The rail operator said no decisions have been taken and the public would be consulted. Middlesborough Evening Gazette By gum, it's buzzin' in Skipton Skipton got a taste of the high life this week when the Yorkshire town added a "contemporary bar" to its roster of night spots. And thirsty locals need not wait too long to partake of a cocktail. Part-owner Dave Rogers says the watering hole has a specially designed long bar so people will not have to queue for drinks. The bar, built in a converted gas depot, has everything traditional pubs do not. Loud, bright colours, chrome fittings, waitress service and jazz and dance nights are all part of the package, the Craven Herald enthusiastically reports. The first punters were welcomed on Friday to an invitation-only event with the doors being thrown open to the general public on Saturday. Mr Rogers said the opening nights were busy and everyone seemed to enjoy themselves. "They were all saying that this is just what Skipton needed," he added. webTitle: Style: John, a womenswear collection by John Richmond

fields.headline: Most wanted: John by John Richmond
fields.body:
There's a department store near you where you can buy dresses by Ben de Lisi, men's suits by Ozwald Boateng, knickers by Janet Reger, hats by Philip Treacy, bags by Orla Kiely, children's clothes by Elspeth Gibson and bedlinen by Cath Kidston. The thing is, you probably wouldn't think of going to Debenhams unless you needed an iron or some tights.

Yup, Debenhams. A pioneer of the high-street designer diffusion range, this store has a stellar roster of designers hiding behind the waist slips and tea trays, creating gorgeous pieces with sensible high-street price tags. The latest arrival is John, a womenswear collection by John Richmond, highlights of which include this suit in plum leather (from Debenhams and Debenhams Direct by Mail, 0800 0288266). A designer outfit for the price of a keyring and a Bellini on Bond Street. Not to be sniffed at, label snobs.

fields.headline: Chaos hits Scottish exam results
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Problems with a new computer system have been blamed for chaos in the distribution of exam results in Scotland.
fields.body:
Problems with a new computer system have been blamed for chaos in the distribution of exam results in Scotland.

Almost 1,500 pupils received incomplete certificates yesterday morning. Schools were told they would not receive the results until today at the earliest, and universities were not sent the results in time to advise applicants immediately if they had secured admission to their chosen institution.

The Scottish education minister, Sam Galbraith, has called for an independent inquiry into the debacle and the chief executive of the Scottish qualifications authority, Ron Tuck, has promised the problems will not be repeated next year.

The SQA said the implementation of a new IT system as complicated as those used for air traffic control and new administration procedures had led to the problems.

"We accept full responsibility for everything that has happened in the course of this year," said Mr Tuck. "We had to introduce a whole range of new qualifications, which means the documents and all the systems concerned with it.

"We need to make sure that things get absolutely right for the next examination cycle, which in effect begins today," he added.

"I can guarantee it will not happen next year. We will cooperate fully with Mr Galbraith's review."

More than 140,000 pupils sat exams for the highers, the standard grade and the new intermediate qualification, but 10% of them received incomplete certificates. The SQA also failed to get the results to the universities and colleges admissions service in time. Ucas warned applicants going into higher education of possible delays receiving confirmation of places after the results were sent to them two days late.

The SQA has opened a telephone helpline for pupils, schools and universities affected, and has written to English universities to explain the problem. Scottish institutions had already been contacted.

Teachers described the situation as a disgrace. The head of a school near Perth said there had been scenes of "complete confusion" at her school yesterday morning.

Juliet Austin, of Kilgraston school, Bridge of Earn, said the school would not now receive the results until Monday. "We have had calls this morning from some of our pupils living abroad asking for their results, but we cannot get them," she said. "One pupil even called to say that she had received someone else's."

Mrs Austin said the new system for processing results was "the worst I have ever seen". The Scottish National party said the delays were unacceptable and that Scottish pupils were being treated as guinea pigs for new education policies. Pass rates for the new exams were said to be broadly in line with last year's results.

fields.headline: Chopin: Four Ballades
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Chopin's Four Ballades
fields.body:
The Four Ballades, composed between 1831 and 1842, are perhaps the most perfect examples of Chopin's instinctive sense of musical shape and tonal organisation.

The sheer technical finesse of his piano writing may be displayed more extrovertly in his studies, his lyrical gifts distilled down to a more concentrated essence in the preludes, and mazurkas and nocturnes, his revolutionary approach to large-scale form demonstrated more potently in the second andthird sonatas. But it's in the ballades, and the F minor Fantasy composed in the same period, that allthese facets of his music are welded into a single all-embracing form.

The title implies some kind of narrative programme behind the music, and Robert Schumann, to whom the second in F major is dedicated, claimed that Chopin had told him that a quartet of ballads by the poet Adam Mickiewicz was the starting point for these extraordinary pieces, even revealing their titles - Konrad Wallenrod, Switez, The Water Sprite and The Three Budrys. There is no clinching evidence either way, but it scarcely matters the musical argument in each of the four pieces is so clear, the drama so self- contained and convincing that no literary explanation is required.

It's surprising that by no means all the great Chopin interpreters of the 20th century have tackled the ballades in the studio. There are recordings of any of them by Dinu Lipatti, Sviatoslav Richter or Martha Argerich, for instance, while Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli favoured just No 1 in G minor, and Vladimir Horowitz the F minor fourth.

For those who admire Artur Rubinstein's Chopin, his set of all four on RCA - warm, and ever so slightly sentimental - remains in the catalogue in remastered form, and Vladimir Ashkenazy's accounts (Decca) are fine-grained and well polished, if not quite as searching and all-embracing as some of his other performances in his complete Chopin survey.

The choice for a library version, though, comes down to one of four.

There is Emanuel Ax on RCA, recorded near the beginning of his career and dashing and impulsive in his approach, even if the rubato sometimes seems a bit self-consciously applied, and Andrei Gavrilov on Deutsche Grammophon, whose performance has marvellous facility and sense of colour. But the recordings by Murray Perahia and Krystian Zimerman really stand head and shoulders above the rest, and it is hard to decide between them.

Perahia's reading is one his finest achievements on disc, deeply felt, sumptuously coloured, and always perfectly balanced Zimerman's is equally aristocratic, full of subtleties of touch and timbre and a constant awareness of Chopin's architecture. Both contain superlative piano playing, and if Zimerman just gets my vote, others may well favour Perahia.

Key Recording: Zimerman (Deutsche Grammophon 423 090-2)

webTitle: French judge orders experts to study Yahoo! case

fields.headline: French judge orders experts to study Yahoo! case
fields.standfirst: The issue explained
fields.trailText: A French judge today ordered a team of experts to examine ways of blocking the US search engine and web directory Yahoo! from French users after the company was found selling Nazi memorabilia on its popular auction site.
fields.body:
A French judge today ordered a team of experts to examine ways of blocking the US search engine and web directory Yahoo! from French users after the company was found selling Nazi memorabilia on its popular auction site.

Under French law it is illegal to sell or exhibit material that incites racial hatred. In a previous judgement the company had been told find a way to stop French users from accessing the site but had claimed it was technically impossible.

Judge Jean-Jacques Gomez has given the team of three experts - one French, one American, and one European - until 6 November to find a solution and will then rule on whether Yahoo! has done enough to comply with French law.

The case highlights the extent to which individual countries will accept freedom of speech on the net. Yahoo!, based in Santa Clara, California, is protected by the US constitution if its pages express racist or extremist ideas. However, in May, Judge Gomez ruled that the service provider had offended France's "collective memory".

The battle has sparked fears that one nation's legal system, such as the US, could stretch its tentacles across national borders, subverting laws in other countries. Countries have previously been largely powerless to combat extremist web pages stored on servers in other countries, but the Yahoo! case has given some legal observers a start.

"It could be a worldwide prior restraint against free expression," said San Francisco-based lawyer Michael Traynor , who filed an affidavit on behalf of Yahoo!. "For [France], a country that prides itself on human rights, it would be an extraordinary imposition on fundamental freedom of expression."

Yahoo! has pulled Third Reich paraphernalia from its French site - fr.Yahoo.com. In a further step, the company recently added warnings, in French, to some pages of its US-based site, alerting French users they risk breaking French laws by viewing them.

Yahoo!'s lawyers say it would be impossible to go further, arguing that it is not technically feasible to keep French users off disputed websites.

On the other side, the International League Against Racism and Anti-Semitism (LICRA) and the Union of Jewish Students of France say the country should not be subject to ideologies it has made illegal.

"It's linked to our history, which has known the occupation, [and] the collaboration of our government with, the Nazis," said Marc Knobel of LICRA, whose letter-writing campaign sparked the lawsuit.

The prosecution has asked that Yahoo! be fined for each day it violates French law.

fields.headline: Smith confident of signing £3.7m Ferguson
fields.trailText: Everton have reportedly made a £3.7m bid for Newcastle striker Duncan Ferguson - and manager Walter Smith is confident the deal will be completed in the next few days.
fields.body:
Everton have reportedly made a £3.7m bid for Newcastle striker Duncan Ferguson - and manager Walter Smith is confident the deal will be completed in the next few days.

He said: "The Newcastle bid is more or less completed. We are now discussing the situation with the player's representatives and we have to await the outcome.

"Am I optimistic? I am always optimistic. I know all about Duncan and I need to add to our strike force."

No fee has been given but it is believed Ferguson could move for £3.7m. That figure is about half of what Newcastle paid for him in November 1998 when Ruud Gullit was manager.

Ferguson has had a frustrating time on Tyneside with injuries cutting back his appearances - but he is still revered at Goodison and Smith is anxious to strengthen his strike force.

fields.headline: Bates brands Sutton a "disaster"
fields.trailText: Chelsea chairman Ken Bates has warmed up nicely for the new season with a stinging attacking on £10m misfit Chris Sutton.
fields.body:
Chelsea chairman Ken Bates has warmed up nicely for the new season with a stinging attacking on £10m misfit Chris Sutton.

Bates pulled no punches in his condemnation of Sutton, who scored just one Premiership goal last season following his move from Blackburn.

"There is no escaping the fact Sutton was a disaster. His attitude wasn't right towards the end. He wasn't good for Chelsea," he said. "He became anxious after missing two open goals against Sunderland on his debut. But he's done well to go to Celtic. It's an easier league and he showed that by getting a goal early on."

Bates has replaced Sutton with Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, as well as bringing in Eidur Gudjohnsen and Mario Stanic to Stamford Bridge, and he reckons the trio will ensure Chelsea are a force to be reckoned with this season.

"For the last two seasons we have lacked a goalscorer. But with the three summer signings, we have addressed that situation," he said. "Our defence was good last season - no team kept more clean sheets than us and only Liverpool conceded fewer goals."

Ahead of Sunday's Charity Shield at Wembley, Bates admitted he was determined to end Ferguson's domination of English football.

"We have a healthy respect for Manchester United and a healthy rivalry," said Bates. "They have won six out of the last eight championships which says something. It's up to clubs like us to stop them making the league a one-horse race like it is in Scotland."

In a final twist, Bates has a surprise up his sleeve for Ferguson when the two meet on Sunday, particularly with the Scot having compared the colourful Chelsea chief to Chairman Mao because of his forthright views.

"I think he was trying desperately to scrape up even more sales for his autobiography, which is now out in paperback," quipped Bates. "But we are good verbal sparring partners. I think one of his comments was that he hasn't known anyone since Chairman Mao who had faith in their opinions like me. I took it as a compliment. Are you not supposed to have faith in your opinions?

"I think I've got a little surprise planned for him on Sunday which will add to the amusement. I can't tell you what it is because it won't be a surprise."

fields.headline: Predict next year's Premiership
fields.trailText: "Intelligent and amusing"... "a fair and largely accurate summing up of our chances"... "the rantings of an idle, ill-informed hack". That's what you've been saying in response to the first batch of our Premiership previews.
fields.body:
"Intelligent and amusing"... "a fair and largely accurate summing up of our chances"... "the rantings of an idle, ill-informed hack". That's what you've been saying in response to the first batch of our Premiership previews.

Of course, we've tried our best to predict what's going to happen next season. But plenty of you are bound to disagree. So we want to hear your take on what will happen next year.

Tell us who you think will finish where in the Premiership next season, from 1-20. And, if you can be bothered, bung a few thoughts down as well.

Just before the season kicks off, we'll publish the best of the rants you send us - as well as the Football Unlimited readers' table, an average of all your place predictions.

Email the.boss@theguardian.com and keep an eye out for the results.

fields.headline: Returning, Redistributing and Really exciting
fields.trailText: THE BIG MAN'S BACK AGAIN (DEDICATED TO THE NEO-EVERTON REGIME)
fields.body:
THE BIG MAN'S BACK AGAIN (DEDICATED TO THE NEO-EVERTON REGIME)

Now that Everton have given football funster Paul Gazza a drink in the last chance saloon, every fan in the country will be wishing him well and hoping he can get his act together for one last hurrah. There's no better place for Gazza to regroup than the school of science, after all, and avuncular manager Walter Smith will be a calming influence. It's the big game at Wembley on Sunday afternoon, as Manchester United and Chelsea's of Chelsea compete for everyone's favourite pre-season platter, the Charity Shield. United haven't done too well in this fixture over the past couple of years - not that they'll care too much, because after losing dismally, they go on to win all the games people actually remember. Even so, they won't mind having a ready-made excuse should they get tonked this year: David Beckham is suffering from an injured back.

According to the official Manchester United website (go to http://www.crewealex.co.uk instead, United fans, and share around the hits), Beckham "started hobbling" an hour into an open training session at Old Trafford and ended up "face down on the grass". Poor Becks then got a nice massage by the club physio and spent the rest of the session sitting on his arse with his hands on his back. Alex Ferguson thinks everything will be alright, however: "David took a slight knock to the small of his back but he'll be fine for Sunday. These things happen."

You might not hear the clarion call from the Premiership-fixated Sky. And we're pretty certain that some Johnny-come-lately called Giles won't be banging on about it in the pub tonight either. But to the rest of us, the new English season kicks off tomorrow, and the Fiver is positively giddy. However, Juventus president Gianni Agnelli has said there is no way the deal will go through.

Manchester United are sensationally planning to offer Real Madrid £9m for Steve McManaman. Spanish newspaper AS claims that McManaman "would find it very difficult to say no to an offer from United", despite the winger's claims that he does not want to return to England.

Middlesbrough are lining up an £8m bid for Aston Villa's unsettled defender Ugo Ehiogu, according to Teamtalk.

Charlton will observe a minute's silence before the game against Vicenza at The Valley tomorrow in memory of Pierre Bolangi, who drowned while on a training exercise with the Army earlier this week.

Steve Howey has completed his £2m move to Manchester City from Newcastle. Howey came through a medical today and has agreed a four-year contract.

Crystal Palace have signed Jamie Pollock from Manchester City for £750,000. The 26-year-old midfielder has been included in Palace's squad for tomorrow's game against Blackburn.

Hassan Kachloul has rejected a £2m move to Ipswich. The Moroccan midfielder said: "I have respect for Ipswich, and I like the fans and club. However, I want to see out the last year of my contract at Southampton."

The chief executive of the Wembley Stadium project has angrily denied suggestions that the cost of construction is set to soar beyond the £1bn mark. "Stories that the cost has gone up are absolutely not true," said WNSL chief executive Bob Stubbs. "In fact, we are taking steps to ensure that the price does not rise by negotiating a guaranteed maximum price with the building contractors."

Uefa have confirmed that referee Costas Kapitanis made a mistake in giving Leeds midfielder Eirik Bakke a straight red card during the Big Cup game against 1860 Munich on Wednesday. Bakke should have been sent off for two bookable offences and, as a result, will only be suspended for one match.

Germany will almost certainly be without key midfielder Jens Jeremies when they face England in a World Cup qualifier on October 7. The Bayern Munich star has suffered knee ligament damage in training and has been ruled out of action for two to three months.

Wolves have signed former Swindon goalkeeper Frank Talia on a month's contract after second-choice keeper Mike Stowell picked up an ankle injury.

Sheffield Wednesday have signed Simon Grayson on a month's loan from Blackburn.

Sky Sports 3: Football (8pm)

fields.headline: Shoes made to last
fields.standfirst: Who would pay £1,500 for a pair of shoes? William Hague, apparently, who buys bespoke footwear from the tiny shop of GJ Cleverley. But are they worth it? William Leith goes for a fitting
fields.trailText: Who would pay £1,500 for a pair of shoes? William Hague, apparently, who buys bespoke footwear from the tiny shop of GJ Cleverley. But are they worth it? William Leith goes for a fitting.
fields.body:
When, like William Hague, you wear bespoke shoes - shoes which are made for your feet and nobody else's - you are a special kind of person. For one thing, you are a person who can afford to spend £1,500 on a pair of shoes. As a pedestrian, you are privileged - you have your own customised craft. You have more in common with the motorist than with the man who takes public transport. You have, as it were, "two Jags" on your feet. You are a fierce individualist. You are making a statement about yourself. You are a person who can, in all honesty, say the words "my shoemaker".

William Hague's shoemaker is GJ Cleverley, one of five companies in London that make traditional bespoke men's shoes. The others are Lobb's, Maxwell's, Foster's, and Taylor's. Bespoke shoes for women are an altogether different matter, attended to in Paris, or at the very least Sloane St. But to get to Cleverley's you turn into the dinky, shadowy Royal Arcade which joins Old Bond Street to Albermarle Street. The shop is, of course, tiny and shady. The workshop above, where the shoes are wrought, is a cramped smithy, full of antique-looking tools and rolls of leather. It looks like a place of solid craftsmanship, a place into which gimmickry has never entered. You enter by climbing a steep spiral staircase; the first thing you notice is a piece of leather soaking in a bucket of water.

John Carnera, one of the two proprietors of GJ Cleverley, says that bespoke shoes are made in the same way as they were made a century ago. Technology has not altered the process one whit. It still takes three months to make the first pair for a client; he - it is almost without exception a he - must come in for three fittings. It is a process of customising, of gradual building. Along with the shoe, one thing that is being built, clearly, is the ego of the client. You put your foot on a book, and Carnera draws a line around it. He takes four measurements - heel to toe, width at the widest point, around the instep, and instep to heel. This is the first fitting. "We have to get inside the minds of clients," he says. Some people like their shoes loose; some like them tight. Bony feet are the hardest to accommodate. But Carnera does not talk about his clients' feet. That's another thing you get with a bespoke shoemaker - like an accountant, a lawyer, or a spin doctor, he will keep your secrets.

How does it make you feel, having your feet so closely studied? It feels good. It is not without symbolic, even biblical, connotations. This is ministration. It tickles slightly, but not in an unpleasant way.

"I've taken a photographic picture in my mind of your foot," says Carnera, who was born in Udine, Italy, and came to England at the age of seven. Having worked for Cleverley's since the 70s, he and a colleague, George Glasgow, took over when George Cleverley died in 1993 at the age of 92. Along with the traditional virtues of bespoke shoemaking, Cleverley's is known for elegance. "Now, is that a chiselled toe!" says Carnera, handling a dressy half-brogue.

Having measured your foot, Carnera fashions a last - a wooden, shoe-shaped snapshot of your foot. Then the leather work begins. "Calf" - the tanned hides of calves, which are 10 or 12 feet long, and softer at the rump than the shoulder - is the staple. "We do scour the world for materials," says Carnera - words which must have a pleasant ring to an ambitious opposition leader. The front of a good shoe is rump; the heel portion is cut from further forward. The lining, the part which cushions the toe, is soft horsehide.

If the craftsmanship at Cleverley's has not changed for a century, neither have the fashions. It's not that they could not cater for new lines; it's that the clients do not want them. The men who come here want some things to be like they were 100 years ago, when Britain was great, when the map was pink, the pound strong, the Navy invincible, the Channel a wide, insurmountable gulf.

Hague wears Oxfords - one pair with a plain toecap, one a half-brogue. Some people want the Derby, a more rustic version of the Oxford. Some want the Cambridge, which is a slip-on version of the Oxford. Carnera shows me a pair of Oxfords which have come in for their first mending; the date is 1989. They might need to be mended again in another decade.

These, then, are not the shoes of a careful, image-conscious politician. They would not go down well in a focus group. They are the shoes of an empire-builder, an egotist, a show-off. They might be a cad's shoes. James Hewitt might wear shoes like this, as might Chris Eubank. They are not Conservative in the sense of John Major. They are Napoleonic. "When you take them off," says Carnera, "you have to put the trees in while they're still warm." You can almost hear the words, in that clipped Rotherham accent: "Hang on, Ffion. I won't be a minute."

webTitle: Phyllis Cohen reports on Botox, a poison that eradicates wrinkles

fields.headline: Toxic shock
fields.standfirst: Dose of botulism, darling? Phyllis Cohen reports on the rise of the soft drug of cosmetic surgery: a poison that eradicates wrinkles
fields.trailText: Dose of botulism, darling? Phyllis Cohen reports on the rise of the soft drug of cosmetic surgery: a poison that eradicates wrinkles.
fields.body:
Botox has become the acceptable face of cosmetic surgery. Women who scoff at the cartoonish effects of silicone breasts and collagen lips, and would not contemplate the risk, pain and inconvenience of going "under the knife" for a face lift, are succumbing to the appeal of swift, easy Botox injections to rub out their wrinkles. Annie Boyd, previously insecure about her crow's feet due to a sun-worshipping adolescence, says: "It's about the price of three good facials [£150-200] and far more effective." She went out for dinner after her first treatment and by the time dessert appeared, her crow's feet had begun to disappear. So impressive were the results that her dining companion booked in for Botox the next day.

Boyd is 27. While face lifts are rarely sought by the young, Botox, the soft drug of the cosmetic procedure world, is introducing an ever-younger audience to preserving their unlined looks. According to fashion and beauty photographer Iain Philpott: "Rarely a day goes by when someone in the studio isn't discussing the pros and cons of Botox." Philpott knows at least one 23-year-old supermodel whose forehead is frozen. She is thrilled with it.

Botox is derived from botulin, the toxic bacteria less glamorously associated with poisoned grannies and ancient tins of food. Injections of minuscule amounts of botulinum toxin type A affect nerve-endings, preventing the brain from transmitting the chemical messages that make facial muscles contract. It has been used for over a decade to help people who suffer from facial spasms and is now known as the "poor man's face lift".

Slight bruising and an insect bite-like sting can be expected during the 15-minute treatment but after five or six days, hey presto: no facial movement in targeted areas for up to four months, allowing existing lines to smooth out and preventing new lines appearing. After the first year, the paralysed muscles slowly begin to atrophy and less Botox is needed for the same effect.

Dr Alastair Carruthers, one half of the husband and wife dermatologist-ophthalmologist team who pioneered the cosmetic use of Botox, proclaims that his wife Jean "hasn't frowned for 10 years". Charles Darwin would be horrified: in The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals, he wrote that frowning was "one of the most important of all expressions". His mentor, Sir Charles Bell, believed the corrugator muscle that causes brows to knit "the most remarkable muscle of the human face" and praised its ability to "convey the idea of mind".

In Beverly Hills, Botox is the fastest growing cosmetic surgery procedure. One of its greatest fans is Dr Larry Koplin, who Botoxes himself and most of his patients. He feels it is a great addition to his techniques "to create a sculpting of the face. I don't believe we're creating a generation of Dorian Grays but rather creating the ability for people to look the way they feel." But if you can't raise your eyebrows, you will just look stunned when surprised because only your eyes will widen.

The evolutionary purpose behind the surprised expression is to widen the eyes as quickly as possible. Try opening your eyes as wide as possible without raising the eyebrows; it takes twice as long. If you are very angry or concerned, and a generous dose of Botox has rendered your "remarkable" corrugators kaput, your eyes will merely narrow slightly. If you can't move your eyebrows inwards or upwards, the one expression that will be impossible is that of horror. Drastic loss of expression happens only with extensive use, however. The impact on facial movement of Boyd's treatment for crow's feet is barely perceptible: there is none of the tautness of traditional face lifts.

But a cavalier attitude among women desperate to avoid wrinkles is common: Dr Patrick Bowler of Harley Street, one of London's leading Botox specialists, reports that "younger clients are less attached than older ones to their facial expressions" and says many come in explaining they "don't want to frown any more".

Bowler is an advocate of the less is more policy, preferring to inject less and have people come back a few weeks later for a top-up injection if desired. He is careful to prevent Botox tolerance developing and makes over-enthusiastic patients sign agreements not to seek further treatment until a specific date. He is also meticulous about concentration levels.

Botox comes as a powder and has to be reconstituted with a saline solution; some practitioners dilute it too much, causing it to spread into the wrong muscles: in these rare cases, a droopy eyelid or eyebrow can occur because some of the material injected finds its way into those muscles unknowingly.

However, while some people who "suffer" from wrinkles are thinking about Botox injections to limit expressive movement in the face, others are born without the ability to use their face to make an emotional connection with those around them. fields.headline: Regulating the net
fields.standfirst: The US search engine, Yahoo!, is up before a French judge after it allowed Nazi memorabilia to be sold on its website. Simon Jeffery explains the impact the decision could have on the worldwide web
fields.trailText: The US search engine, Yahoo!, is up before a French judge after it allowed Nazi memorabilia to be sold on its website. Simon Jeffery explains the impact the decision could have on the worldwide web
fields.body:
Why is Yahoo! being brought before a French court?
Yahoo!, the world's most popular search engine and web directory, was allowing Nazi memorabilia to be sold on its auction site. Under French law it is illegal to sell or exhibit objects that incite racial hatred, so two human rights organisations took the giant US company to court. Material on the internet is currently distributed freely across the world so it has turned into something of a test case to see who has the power, and confidence in their legal system, to regulate the net.

Is that practical in this day and age?
Perhaps more so than ever. The law stems from France's occupation under the Nazis between 1940 and 1944, but neo-Nazi style violence is on the rise across Europe and many government's blame the internet for propagating hate. The case will go part of the way to determining whether the internet can be regulated by nation states or simply be subject to the rules of the lowest common denominator, which in practice means freedom of speech as it exists in the United States.

But if Rupert Murdoch can bar the BBC from broadcasting in China why can't Yahoo! stop sending Nazi websites to France?
Broadcasters, like Mr Murdoch's Asia-wide Star TV, beam their material to selected geographical locations and find it relatively easy to pull controversial material. However, no one broadcasts the internet. If you type "Find me swastikas" into the Yahoo! search engine your computer effectively goes to the company's server and asks for them.

Can't search engines refuse to find certain requests?
Yahoo! is the world's most-visited website. According to the audit bureau of circulation, the UK portal alone (http://uk.yahoo.com) delivered 234 million pages in April and it simply does not know where it is sending them to. The company testified in court that no system exists to block a user's access to selected websites by geography. However, Cyril Houri, founder of geographical locating dot.com Infosplit disagrees. Speaking to internet magazine TheStandard.com, Mr Houri said that Yahoo!'s expert technology witness contacted him during the trial and together they ran tests which, using the Infosplit technology, saw that page requests were coming from France and blocked them. Strangely Yahoo! did not mention these tests in court.

Why not?
If Mr Houri is correct - and Yahoo! could selectively block access - the company would almost certainly face a barrage of demands from countries world wide to remove material of varying degrees of offence from its sites. Of course, Mr Houri may simply be talking up his technology's talents to boost Infosplit's public profile.

So what did Yahoo! do?
It pulled the offending material off the French portal (http://fr.yahoo.com) and put warning messages on the US yahoo.com site telling French users that they could be breaking the law in their country if they looked at certain material. Yahoo! co-founder Jerry Yang says his company will not alter the content of its site to comply with a non-American law. The US constitution's first amendment protects Yahoo!'s right to free speech so it is extremely unlikely the company would be extradited to face further charges.

Could America become the guardian of "free speech" the worldwide web over?"
Yes. Individual countries try to regulate their citizen's access to the net but, as the French are finding out, they can only stop a site from serving pages within its national boundaries. America's right to freedom of speech suits many "offensive" sites who can simply switch their pages to a US server. Marc Knobel, the French human rights activist whose letter-writing campaign sparked the lawsuit, says the American net is becoming a "dumping ground" for racists the world over.

Are the French courts acting alone?
No other country is prosecuting Yahoo! but Germany moved to bar Nazi slogans as web addresses when they found that someone had registered www.heil-hitler.de. Concerned authorities in Germany have reported that far-right extremists are increasingly organising themselves on the internet at a time of escalating neo-Nazi activity. Justice minister Herta Daeubler-Gmelin called websites bearing racist and Nazi propaganda "a new threat to our society" and said the nation should do all it could to fight such sites, even beyond its borders.

How many hate sites are there on the net?
The Simon Wiesenthal Center, which monitors racist groups, says there are now more than 1,400 hate sites on the net compared with one in 1995. Many are hosted on US servers.

webTitle: British man arrested over Thai death

fields.headline: British man arrested over Thai death
fields.trailText: Thai police arrested a British man late last night in connection with the killing of a British backpacker found raped and strangled in a hostel.
fields.body:
Thai police arrested a British man late last night in connection with the killing of a British backpacker found raped and strangled in a hostel.

The man, named by Thai officials as Nathan Soley, contacted police voluntarily, British diplomats said. He has since been released and has asked for police protection.

The body of Kirsty Jones, 23, from south Wales, was found in her room at the Aree guesthouse in the northern resort of Chiang Mai yesterday. She had checked in alone on Monday.

The guesthouse owner and other backpackers broke into her room at 5pm local time after worrying that she had not come out all day. They found her semi naked with a piece of cloth wrapped round her neck.

Thai police said they believed the man had been a fellow guest at the Aree hotel. He is being held at the main city police station in Chiang Mai.

Earlier Thai police said they were looking for a white European backpacker in his late 20s. He was seen drinking with Ms Jones the night before she died.

Lt Col Suvit Khunprasert, investigating the murder, said guests heard screams and the sounds of a struggle coming from Ms Jones's room the night before. He said no one interfered, thinking it was a lovers' quarrel.

Sarah Wiggett, 25, a British backpacker from Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, spent the evening drinking in local bars with Ms Jones before she died. She said yesterday: "I'm staying at a different guesthouse to Kirsty so we parted ways at the end of the night.

Ms Wiggett, a student at Canterbury University, who had been in Thailand two weeks, said: "Kirsty was a really nice fun girl. I think she had a round the world ticket and her friend was flying out in a couple of weeks to join her in Bangkok."

Ms Jones graduated from Liverpool University last year. She had worked locally to save money for her trip.

Chiang Mai city, 422 miles north of Bangkok, is a jungle resort built around moats and known as the "rose of the north". It is the cheapest city in Thailand and thousands of backpackers and gap year students travel there every year to go trekking in nearby hills. Most stay at guesthouses which charge around £2 a night.

Jemima Broadbridge, of the travel publishing firm Rough Guide, described Chiang Mai as an "easy going" city and could only recall one other recent case when a young British woman, also travelling on her own, was raped and killed by a Buddhist monk in the grounds of a Thai monastery. Julie Thomas, of the backpacking specialists STA Travel, said the number of single women backpackers travelling to Thailand has grown sharply in the last year following the film The Beach. She said the murder of one woman would not put travellers off.

Around 35% of foreign visitors to Thailand are women, according to the World Tourism Organisation. This is ahead of most Asian countries and incidents of sexual harassment in Thailand are fewer than in India, Indonesia or Malaysia.

But the Lonely Planet guide to Thailand warns that several women have recently been attacked while travelling alone in remote areas. It says most urban areas of Thailand are safe but Chiang Mai is an exception.

The Foreign Office warns travellers to Thailand to be wary of accepting food and drink from strangers as it may be drugged.

Lisa Ellis, 22, a backpacker from Slough, Berkshire, who recently stayed at the Jungle Mai guesthouse near Ms Jones's hostel, said: "I was in a group of six women in Chiang Mai. We were scared by the local guesthouses. The owner at our hostel took all our spare clothes and locked them in a safe, because she said we could not risk carrying anything ... I would not have stayed one night alone in Chiang Mai."

Sian Rees of the Suzy Lamplugh trust which offers advice to lone female travellers to Thailand, said lone women travellers were not naive and should not be scared about travelling alone. "Women must understand this was an isolated incident. But they must learn from it to trust their instincts and take safety guidelines seriously."

fields.headline: US election costs
fields.standfirst: The battle for the job of American president doesn't come cheap. Julian Glover explains how candidates are financed and how much is forked out on their campaigns
fields.trailText: The battle for the job of American president doesn't come cheap. Julian Glover explains how candidates are financed and how much is forked out on their campaigns
fields.body:
How much does an American presidential election cost?
Democracy US-style has never come cheap - and the cost is rising. By this stage of the 1996 election, the candidates had spent some $237.2 million between them, up from about $123 million in 1992. So far this year the campaign has cost well over $350 million.

Who has most money to spend?
George Bush is well ahead: to date he's raised $93,260,829 and spent $81,038,713. Al Gore, in contrast, has raised $52,568,089 and spent $41,841,378.

Are there any rules?
Yes - and they are complex. The first legislation regulating federal campaign finance was introduced between 1905 and 1908 in an attempt to limit the disproportionate influence over elections held by wealthy individuals. In 1974, after dubious practises were reported in the 1972 election, legislation led to the creation of the federal election commission: the biggest innovation was the introduction of partial public funding of candidates. Since then, the rules have remained more or less the same - although many Americans are now unhappy with them and want reform. Campaign finance reform was a major part of John McCain's campaign for the Republican nomination, although it has now fallen off his party's agenda.

And what are these rules?
In short, contributions by individuals and groups to federal campaigns are limited to a direct contribution of $1,000 a year and $25,000 a year in total. Contributions by certain groups - such as foreign nationals and corporations - are prohibited. In return for accepting limits on overall campaign spending, candidates are given federal grants. In 1996, the major parties each received $12.36 million.

That sounds fair
Yes - but candidates have hardly been constrained by the rules. This year, for instance, George Bush has refused to take federal funds and so been released from official limits on how much he can spend. Candidates can also be supported by independent donations, which back their cause but don't go directly to their campaign. Much TV advertising is paid for this way. Such so-called soft-money contributions are arguably illegal, since most candidates establish committees to back their causes, which are barely separate from the campaign. However candidates prefer not to raise the issue since almost all of them risk trouble if the letter of the law is applied.

Where do the contributions come from?
Much of the money of does come from small gifts. George Bush claims to have received 600,000 such donations at an average of $99.63. But much more comes from special interest groups. Bush is well ahead of Al Gore here, raising more money than his rival from almost every part of the economy. For instance the energy and natural resources sector has given governor Bush some $2,420,372 - but just $253,710 to Al Gore. Gore leads only in donations from labour unions, lawyers and lobbyists.

But why do people give such vast amounts of money?
Sometimes they do it for ideological reasons. Both Bush and Gore's web sites allow the public to make credit card donations and list hundreds of people who have given small sums. But the real money is raised through the aggressive fundraising campaigns which take up much of an American politician's time. In return for contributions, big donors can expect access to the candidate and the chance of favours if he should win. Many US ambassadors receive their jobs in this way

What sort of events are used to raise money?
Ahead of the Democratic convention Barbra Streisand is holding a fundraising brunch for Bill Clinton's presidential library at her Malibu home, which should raise around $1m. Another fundraising event should bring in $4m for Hilary Clinton's senate campaign. Al Gore expects to make $2.5m from his star-studded convention bash. More dubiously, Al Gore was heavily involved in raising cash for Bill Clinton's campaign in 1996, telephoning key donors from the White House.

Where does all the money go?
Television advertising swallows the bulk of the cash - in contrast with Britain, candidates are allowed to buy airtime. Bill Clinton's saturation advertising for 18 months before the 1996 election allowed him to pull ahead of Bob Dole. Other big costs include running a company-sized campaigning operation for almost two years.

What is the future for campaign finance?
It's possible that the law will remain unchanged and the election after next will simply see bigger sums spent. American voters want reform, however, and this is likely to lead to some sort of change. George Bush has called for a ban on soft money donations and an increase to the $1,000 limit on individual gifts. Al Gore wants TV stations to offer politicians free air time and wants an endowment fund to pay for political campaigning, among other things. But whoever wins, action in the short term is unlikely.

The Electronic Policy Network: campaign finance

webTitle: Clinton: A hard act to follow

fields.headline: Clinton: A hard act to follow
fields.standfirst: President Bill Clinton asked Americans to not punish Al Gore for the Monica Lewinsky affair yesterday, but former US correspondent Mark Tran wonders whether the vice-president is politician enough to capitalise
fields.trailText: Friday, 3.45pm President Bill Clinton asked Americans to not punish Al Gore for the Monica Lewinsky affair yesterday, but former US correspondent Mark Tran wonders whether the vice-president is politician enough to capitalise.
fields.body:
The US president, Bill Clinton, staged the latest in a series of dramatic performances yesterday that has made his presidency such compelling theatre.

Mr Clinton revisited the Monica Lewinsky scandal in front of 4,500 ministers at South Barrington, Illinois, during an oratory tour de force that subtly blended a plea for understanding with a helpful fillip for his protégé, Vice-President Al Gore.

Microphone in hand like a host from one of America's numerous talk shows (perhaps he'll have his own one day), Mr Clinton talked about rebuilding his life after "the terrible mistake" he committed with the former White House intern.

Then came that helping hand for Mr Gore, who is trying to distance himself from the president, while simultaneously capitalising on his economic legacy.

"Surely no fair-minded person would blame [Mr Gore] for the mistakes I've made," said Mr Clinton. It was an eminently reasonable plea that would have gone down well within the Gore camp.

Mr Gore will accept the Democratic presidential nomination at the party's convention in Los Angeles on Thursday. He has already won plaudits by choosing Senator Joseph Lieberman, who famously denounced Mr Clinton as immoral on the Senate floor during the Lewinsky scandal, as his running mate.

Mr Gore unveiled his battle plan to beat the Republican presidential nominee, George W Bush, in an interview with USA Today. He said a Gore-Lieberman presidency would mark a "fresh start", a euphemism for no more hanky panky in the White House, while continuing the successful economic policies of Mr Clinton's reign.

"The question is whether we are going to continue the policies that have produced the strongest economy in American history or instead go back to the policies that created the worst recession since the Dust Bowl of the 1930s," Mr Gore said, referring to the recession of 1982 under President George Bush.

Logically, Mr Gore should win in November. Unemployment and inflation have been low during an era of economic expansion that has outlasted any other during peacetime. When the economic conditions are bright, the odds should favour the incumbent, and Mr Gore is not going to be shy in claiming the credit.

"Those are my policies. I've helped to shape them," he rather immodestly told the USA Today.

So while Mr Gore has his strategy, the question is whether he is a good enough politician to make it work. He lacks Mr Clinton's all-too seductive charm to temper the wonkiness that the vice-president also has in abundance.

In a contest between the two middle-of-the-road presidential candidates, Mr Gore's lack of charm is his weak spot.

Often maligned for a lack of emotion, he can actually get quite worked up on the stump, as he has shown on the campaign trail. But his passion is often perceived as orchestrated, unlike Mr Clinton, who is a natural before a crowd.

Mr Clinton showed how superbly he can work a crowd in yesterday's appearance in Illinois, confirming his standing as one of America's most talented politicians in the post-war era; whether he made the most of that talent is debatable.

Mr Gore, if he wins in November, may well bring a fresh start to the White House.

But it will almost certainly be a much duller place in an era when the American public likes to see a bit of show biz in its capital.

USA Today

US elections 2000: Special report
