webTitle: Bill and Ted's excellent middle age

fields.headline: Bill and Ted's excellent middle age
fields.trailText: Rumour has it that Reeves and co-star Alex Winter are set to re-visit their blockbusting success with Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure by shooting a middle-aged spoof of the flick
fields.body:
It's a long while since Bill and Ted had an excellent adventure. Some might feel bemusement that Keanu Reeves, who - with the Matrix - has only just managed to shake off his floppy-haired bumbling idiot image, is considering coming back for more. But maybe this is the role he feels most at home in, and who are we to argue?

Rumour has it that Reeves and co-star Alex Winter are set to re-visit their blockbusting success with Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure by shooting a middle-aged spoof of the flick.

Reeves and Winter shot to stardom in the film - the tale of two American teenagers as bumbling mid-west heroes - in the early 1980s. And now the pair, who are both approaching 40, are considering remaking the movie - with two ageing heroes replacing the original teenagers.

Reeves revealed: "We always pictured them in some sort of hotel bar with guitars. They would be sitting there very drunk and kinda fat."

fields.headline: Most everywhere: long leather coats
fields.trailText: In this crazy ol' celebrity-obsessed age of ours, from the oddest moments can fashion trends spring forth. Think Madonna singing American Pie in a lacy vest, serenading Rupert Everett. Think Meg Mathews and her stetson, forcing the cowgirl look on to the national consciousness. Then there's Victoria Beckham, who is in a class of her own when it comes to kick-starting unlikely fashion must-haves, from ripped bleached denim to cropped bleached hair. So when she sported a long leather coat in the video to her True Steppers collaboration, it was only a matter of time before Pimp Chic became the look du jour.

Think Meg Mathews and her stetson, forcing the cowgirl look on to the national consciousness. Then there's Victoria Beckham, who is in a class of her own when it comes to kick-starting unlikely fashion must-haves, from ripped bleached denim to cropped bleached hair. So when she sported a long leather coat in the video to her True Steppers collaboration, it was only a matter of time before Pimp Chic became the look du jour.

Posh's coat, designed by Wale Adeyemi, may have cost a little under £5,000 and been a one-off design, but the high street has thoughtfully provided us with more accessible versions. Marks & Spencer, H&M, Episode and George at Asda are among the plethora of retailers taking their undoubtedly lucrative cue from Mrs Beckham.

But this is not all about Posh adulation. Sleek, fitted, yet ever-so-practical, the long leather coat fulfils that ever-so-now requirement of being both smart and casual. Moreover, it shows the ongoing influence of those unlikely fashion icons, Missy Elliott and Puff Daddy - this is feminine ghetto fabulous without the smelly fur and heavy jewellery.

fields.standfirst: An original formula of fruit juices, rumours, spring water, rumours and natural herbal extracts
fields.trailText: Manchester United are sensationally planning to offer Real Madrid £9m for Steve McManaman. Spanish newspaper AS claims that Steve McManaman "would find it very difficult to say no to an offer from United", despite the winger claiming he does not want to return to England.
fields.body:
Manchester United are sensationally planning to offer Real Madrid £9m for Steve McManaman. Spanish newspaper AS claims that Steve McManaman "would find it very difficult to say no to an offer from United", despite the winger claiming he does not want to return to England.

Real have already accepted an £8m bid for McManaman from Middlesbrough, according to the Daily Mail. The Spanish giants, who may not even give the ex-Liverpool winger a squad number, gave Bryan Robson the go-ahead "several days ago".

Meanwhile, Arsenal, who are also interested in Macca, have made Bordeaux a final £12m offer for Sylvain Wiltord.

Duncan Ferguson will return to Everton in a £5m transfer. The Newcastle striker left Goodison for St James' Park 20 months ago in an £8m deal but has been plagued by injury, scoring only 12 goals. But the move depends on Ferguson taking a pay cut: Everton are not prepared to match his current £40,000-a-week contract.

If Everton fail in their bid for Ferguson, Walter Smith will turn to former Arsenal striker Kaba Diawara, now at Paris St Germain, according to the Daily Mail. Not so, says the Star. They'll try to snatch £1.5m Ashley Ward from under the noses of Bradford instead.

Middlesbrough are close to signing Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu for £8m, two days after Manchester City had a £7.25m bid for the player turned down.

Coventry have made bids for Rangers duo Jorg Albertz and Neil McCann. Gordon Strachan claims the Ibrox club agreed to sell the players for £3.5m and £4m respectively but have reneged on the deal.

Sunderland are preparing a bid for Rennes striker Cedric Bardon. The 23-year-old has impressed Peter Reid while on trial with the Black Cats in Holland.

Barnsley will take Uruguayan left-back Corbo Mateo on trial. The 24-year-old currently plays for Real Oviedo.

Birmingham defender Jonathan Bass is a £250,000 target for Grimsby.

webTitle: Toy Story team to tackle monsters

fields.headline: Toy Story team to tackle monsters
fields.trailText: Disney and Pixar, the team behind the phenomenally successful Toy Story films, have announced their next project
fields.body:
Disney and Pixar, the team behind the phenomenally successful Toy Story films, have announced their next project.

Billy Crystal (pictured) and John Goodman take top billing in a team of actors who will be voicing the animated comedy-adventure, Monsters, Inc.

The film, which is scheduled for a November 2001 release in the US, will also feature the voices of James Coburn, Jennifer Tilly and Bonnie Hunt, and will be directed by Peter Docter, who was Oscar nominated for his role in creating the original story for Toy Story.

The movie, so the press release goes, is a comedy, "set in the realm of things that go bump in the night, where chaos breaks loose after a hapless monster accidentally lets a human child into the monster world."

John Goodman will play "a huge, intimidating monster with blue fur, large purple spots, and horns," and Billy Crystal his best friend, "a green, opinionated, feisty little one-eyed monster." Best of all, Steve Buscemi will voice "a sarcastic chameleon monster named Randall Boggs." With such a cast, Pixar's success already looks assured.

webTitle: Trescothick's new niece has perfect timing

fields.headline: Trescothick's new niece has perfect timing
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's gossip column this week, Charles de Lisle reveals why Marcus Trescothick's mind wasn't fully on the cricket at Old Trafford and explains how the Lord's Taverners are raising extra funds in their 50th year
fields.trailText: More good news for the Trescothicks
fields.body:
More good news for the Trescothicks

Becoming an England Test player was not the only new role Marcus Trescothick assumed last week. He also became an uncle for the first time: his 27-year-old sister, Anna, gave birth to a daughter, Erin, who entered the world four days before Marcus entered the Test arena.

Trescothick, 24, barely had time to absorb the impact of his stirring debut - 66 and 38 not out in the third Test against West Indies at Old Trafford - before going off to meet his niece. On Tuesday, Trescothick and his girlfriend Hayley Rowse rushed to Swansea to see the new addition. "Marcus couldn't wait to see Erin, Anna and her fiance Darren," says his father, Martyn. "In recent weeks Anna's pregnancy has been in the back of Marcus's mind all the time. But as long as Anna was OK, he was OK."

The impending birth - the baby was due on July 17 - had kept the family on tenterhooks for weeks. Several false alarms meant that Martyn and his wife Lin had to abandon plans to watch their son opening the batting in several one-dayers, and they missed his highest England score so far, 87 not out in the 10-wicket victory over West Indies at Chester-le-Street. Mrs Trescothick also opted out of the triangular series final at Lord's, on July 22, because she was convinced their grandchild would arrive that day.

However the baby, with a sense of timing which evidently runs in the family, arrived at the ideal time (July 30), midway through a ten-day break in the international schedule. The Trescothick parents duly took their places in the crowd at Old Trafford for Marcus's big moment. "My wife takes everything in her stride," says Martyn. "I get extremely nervous when Marcus is batting, but his performance was absolutely superb."

What price 27 England captains?

Fifty cricket bats signed by every surviving England captain of the past half century are being auctioned by the Lord's Taverners. The bats, believed to be unique, carry the signatures of the 32 men who have led England at least once since the Taverners were founded in 1950. One has already fetched £6,000.

All the regular captains are there, from Sir Leonard Hutton, Peter May, Ted Dexter, Mike Smith, Brian Close, Colin Cowdrey and Ray Illingworth, through Mike Denness, Tony Greig, Mike Brearley, Ian Botham, Bob Willis, David Gower and Graham Gooch right up to Messrs Atherton, Stewart and Hussain.

So are all those whose brief spells in charge are easily forgotten, among them Tony Lewis, John Edrich, Geoffrey Boycott, Keith Fletcher, John Emburey, Chris Cowdrey, Allan Lamb - and Mark Butcher, who became England's 73rd and most recent captain when he led the side once against New Zealand last summer (next Test, he was out of the team altogether).

The signing sessions were organised by someone with a keen appreciation of such accidents of history: Tim Graveney, son of Tom, another one-Test captain. It was Tim, a member of the charity's commercial committee, who had the arduous task of getting the 27 surviving captains to sign each of the 50 full-size bats.

"It took three years to get all the signatures," says Graveney. "MCC let us station the bats at Lord's during the season so that former captains could sign them as they passed through. But we still had to have someone drive round the country collecting signatures. And some players were difficult to pin down, David Gower for example." Graveney adds: "We thought we'd finished the job and suddenly there was a new England captain - Mark Butcher."

What about the five 1950s captains - Hutton, May, Norman Yardley, Freddie Brown, and Nigel Howard - who are no longer with us? Graveney, who is Colin Cowdrey's godson, explains: "We had somebody stencil exact copies of their signatures on to the bats."

So far eight have been auctioned at Taverners' events, at an average price of £4,000, and another 41 will go under the hammer in due course. That leaves one bat currently available through the organisation's website. If you'd like to make a bid, e-mail Jennie Green (jgreen@lordstaverners.org). There's only one catch: bidding starts at £2,000.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

For the mid-week Grapevine, with stories on Jonathan Agnew having surgery this winter, the unlikely player who profited most from Zimbabwe's tour of England, and the one-cap wonder who will make history for his county next season, click here.

fields.headline: Obituary: Alan Boon
fields.standfirst: The man who made a million bosoms heave with passion
fields.trailText: Few who wield a pen for a living have not thought that they could see a way through lean times by writing a Mills & Boon romantic novel. But it was harder than it looked to get sloppy phrases past the acute eyes of Alan Boon, who has died aged 86, and who, with his elder brother, John, brought postwar prosperity to the company which their father had co-founded in a very different era.   Not only had it published EF Benson and PG Wodehouse, but its biggest seller was Jack London.
fields.body:
Few who wield a pen for a living have not thought that they could see a way through lean times by writing a Mills & Boon romantic novel. But it was harder than it looked to get sloppy phrases past the acute eyes of Alan Boon, who has died aged 86, and who, with his elder brother, John, brought postwar prosperity to the company which their father had co-founded in a very different era. Not only had it published EF Benson and PG Wodehouse, but its biggest seller was Jack London.

A man of charm and wit, Alan was educated at Felstead and joined the family firm as a clerk in 1930, two years after the death of Gerald Mills, with whom his father, Charles Boon, had started the company in 1909. Alan had a great business sense; never solemn, he bore with good humour the banter about all those short, pink novels of holiday romance beneath sweltering suns or of eyes meeting across a hospital ward. He was always serious about editing and marketing.

As his brother once said: "Any new reader of Edgar Wallace does not mean one less of Proust." The firm's earliest titles were certainly diverse, and - as all canny publishers do - it realised the importance of a bedrock in the educational and medical market. When John Habgood, the Archbishop of York, alleged that the firm's books were responsible for a rise in the ddivorce rate, he ungratefully forgot that its non-fiction side had published his Religion and Science.

The aftermath of the second world war almost brought Mills & Boon to bankruptcy. All the while, the firm had not realised that, in the midst of its list, were romantic titles, whose potential only became apparent when Alan arrived. Unlike John, he did not go to Cambridge, such was the financial crisis. As he recalled, his father said: "Since you can't get jobs elsewhere, you might as well join the firm. I worked in editorial. There I picked up any knowledge I have of romances."

Alan Boon was always modest, but many an author appreciated personal touches, like his willingness to reply personally to every letter. During the 1930s, when other publishers suffered, Mills & Boon prospered with its then brown-covered hardbacks, designed for the rigours and sensitivities of the circulating- library market. In another unlikely twist, Alan set great store by Percy Lubbock's book, The Craft Of Fiction, which stresses the virtue of telling a story from the heroine's point of view. All of the firm's 150 authors were women.

During the war, Alan joined the navy, while John was in the Royal Norfolk Regiment. The bombing of warehouses in London's Paternoster Row in 1940 destroyed 6m books across the publishing industry, with the result that anything that survived sold out immediately to a book-hungry public. The situation changed with peace, by which time the Boons' father had died. For a while, their firm was caught between the conflicts of an era which was opening up to racier prose, but had to contend with the demands of the lucrative, hidebound Irish market - while trying to reconcile the safe, moderate sale of hardbacks to libraries with the limitless market for cheap paperbacks, and to take advantage of the serial market.

Mills & Boon found that such apparent promiscuity worked well in those 3s 6d tales of sweaty rectitude, whose now familiar length and format were drilled upon a benignly-ordered parade ground. Authors were as diverse as Edwin Lutyens's daughter and Violet Winspear, who caused controversy with her 1970 description of her work to the Radio Times: her heroes, she said, needed love but, when roused, are capable of breathtaking passion and potency. They frighten but fascinate. They must be the sort of men who are capable of rape: men it's dangerous to be alone in a room with.

Twas ever thus. In the 1920s, Denise Robins's Sweet Love had covered all the vices - rape, bigamy, suicide, illegitimacy, divorce, stabbings, poisoning, and more violence, as Joseph McAleer wrote last year in his admirable study of Mills & Boon. Despite the sensibilities of the transatlantic firm, Harlequin, which, in effect, took over the firm in 1971, later romances still found room for such acts as the lonesome heroine Suzy Walker's resorting to that "solitary, inadequate substitute for the ecstasies of a shared bed".

Boon was always sharp on grammar, detail, and an eye for the future; a reference to a Rolls and the Ritz could stay, as these were likely to be around for some while, but likening a heroine to Vivien Leigh was pencilled out, for she would soon date a book whose potential went far beyond its domestic market to being used as a textbook in former British colonies. Even today, a Chinese interest is taking annual sales beyond the 200m, which they have long enjoyed worldwide.

Alan Boon bred racehorses with all the prowess that he brought to novels. He was married for 50 years to Olivia, and had three daughters and a son. They all survive him.

Alan Wheatley Boon, publisher, born September 28 1913; died July 29 2000

fields.headline: British Library junks 80,000 books
fields.trailText: The British Library has thrown out up to 80,000 books in a change of policy which has brought to an end its 338-year- old role of collecting every volume published in Britain.
fields.body:
The British Library has thrown out up to 80,000 books in a change of policy which has brought to an end its 338-year- old role of collecting every volume published in Britain.

The library, which under copyright law receives every new book, cleared well over a mile of shelves. The books were chosen and weeded by "comparatively junior grade professional staff" to make room for new stock.

The new policy, though approved by the library board, has not been publicly announced.

Yesterday a library spokesman at first denied that it had been introduced. Later he confirmed it after hearing that a senior staff member had acknowledged its existence in a letter to a scholar. The letter indicated that it had been suspended because of lack of staff to do more weeding. But no assurances could be given that it would not be resumed.

The move, which breaks a practice that began in 1662 and made the British Library a near complete historical collection, came to light during inquiries by Keith Armstrong, an author researching a book on the history of disability.

Mr Armstrong, who has written or edited four other books, discovered that five books he wanted to read were marked "discarded" in the library catalogue.

He also found a copy of an important work in his field, by the psychologist Deborah Marks, in a London secondhand bookshop. Though published only last year, it was marked "British Library - withdrawn".

His protest to the library led to a reply which horrified him, he said yesterday. Richard Cheffins, head of the BL's social policy information service, told him discarding began after the board accepted a 1989 report, headed Selection for Survival, by Brian Enright, librarian of Newcastle University.

Dr Enright's report said the steeply rising number of books published meant that the time-honoured policy of storing each one would put an ever-increasing cash burden on the BL and imperil the quality of its collections.

Mr Cheffins explained that discarding of low use books began soon after the report was accepted.

"Decisions on a case-by-case basis were made by comparatively junior grade professional staff.

"I am given to understand that, over a couple of years, some 2km of stock in all - about 70,000-80,000 volumes - were withdrawn", he told Mr Armstrong.

"The space thus freed was filled within a few months with the growth of new stock... You are obviously disturbed that any material, once part of our collections, should have been discarded.

"There is not much that can be done about that".

Mr Cheffins added that "a significant number of about 25 library users a year asked for discarded titles. None of the titles would have been available elsewhere in the country". Last night a BL spokesman said: "The discarding of books is an ongoing process."

webTitle: Jail chief resigns over 'Dickensian' conditions for youths

fields.headline: Jail chief resigns over 'Dickensian' conditions for youths
fields.trailText: A deputy governor of Britain's biggest young offenders institution has resigned in protest over the "Dickensian" conditions faced by some of its inmates.
fields.body:
A deputy governor of Britain's biggest young offenders institution has resigned in protest over the "Dickensian" conditions faced by some of its inmates.

Ian Thomas said he could no longer stand working at Feltham Young Offenders Institute after watching children being "warehoused".

The institute in west London holds more than 800 15- to 21-year-olds.

Mr Thomas said he was no longer prepared to tolerate the situation after arriving at work last week to find a 17-year-old had attempted suicide.

The youth should have been housed on a special juvenile unit which has capacity for 180 under-18s. But last week, there were 280 at the institution.

He said the "overflow" was being held with older offenders in lamentable conditions, where they were becoming "dangerous" and "anti-social". Inmates spent hours in their cells with little to occupy them.

"I found myself in a position where I could no longer work ... in a system that meant I was responsible for ultimately conditions that meant young people would want to do this," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"They spend a lot of time in cells where the conditions are Dickensian and the regime that is offered is very, very paltry.

"If the prison service in Feltham is not given a fighting chance and making a difference with these lads rather than simply warehousing them, we will send out bitter, more dangerous and more anti-social young people on to the streets," he added.

Mr Thomas said the institution took in a huge catchment area and had not received "significant investment" for the non-juvenile centre.

"As such it is set up to fail."

The prison service has pointed out Feltham is "going through a transition", but accepts there are more inmates in the institution than it expected.

Chief Inspector of Prisons Sir David Ramsbotham told Today he was "very concerned".

"Provision is still not satisfactory for this vulnerable group, particularly in London," he said.

The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, told the programme the institute was benefiting from extra investment with a £6m unit opening next week.

"I think things are looking immensely better. I don't think his resignation makes much sense. We will at last start to get the numbers down at Feltham."

He said conditions for some inmates had been poor, but they would be improved next week.

"I recognise that working in places like Feltham is immensely difficult.

"There are more young people being sentenced than we expected and we will start to relieve the immense pressure," he added.

Mr Thomas said: "For someone who had a promising ... well-paid career to reach the point where he could no longer stand working in an institution that had these problems, I would hope Mr Narey will listen to the criticisms I have made and do all that he can within his power to give it a chance to work."

fields.headline: Security in wolves' clothing
fields.standfirst: Killing time at airports in the Gulf often means drifting into a game of Spot The Hijacker, writes Middle East editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: Friday, 11.30am Killing time at airports in the Gulf often means drifting into a game of Spot The Hijacker, writes Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
I'm in Kuwait airport. My plane to Jordan should have taken off by now, but it won't be leaving for another two hours and already I'm bored with the book I brought for the flight. There's nothing else to do but play Spot The Hijacker: It's silly, I know, but I can't help it.

At any airport in the Middle East you'll find at least a smattering of bearded men with odd-shaped hand baggage who resemble Osama bin Laden, the Saudi Muslim fugitive that is probably the west's most wanted man. I usually discount them, on the grounds that no hijacker would be stupid enough to board a plane looking like that.

But perhaps that's unwise. A very smart hijacker might realise that the security people have come to the same conclusion and wave bin-Laden lookalikes through without a second glance. In general, though, I reckon that professional hijackers can be identified because they look abnormally ordinary.

The more ordinary, the more reason to be suspicious. Take the Arab man sitting opposite me: medium build, medium height, medium length hair, medium everything. He has absolutely no distinguishing features. He's in his 30s and his clothes are neat but nondescript: dark grey trousers and a blue shirt. Hang on a minute, what's that? There's kind of angular bulge inside his shirt, on the left side, just above the waistline. It might be a Walkman or something but there's no sign of earphones, and anyway, why INSIDE the shirt?

I suppose it could be some kind of medical appliance, but he looks healthy. No, there's definitely something strange. He's one for the suspect list - codename: Osama bin Blueshirt. Game over. It's time to board the plane. The airline is Royal Jordanian that, as it happens, had a hijacking only last month. A man on a flight to Damascus demanded to go to Germany but nearly crashed the plane by setting off a grenade and ended up dead.

They have given me a window seat at the back and when I get there I find Osama bin Blueshirt already occupying the aisle seat next to it. "Would you like the window seat?" I ask. "No," he says firmly and lets me squeeze past.

As we settle in for takeoff another passenger is struggling with the overhead locker. Osama stands up to help, and the bulge in the side of his shirt comes almost level with my eyes. What's more, there's a straight, tubular bit about six inches long pointing downwards under his trousers. He's carrying a gun - no doubt about it.

Osama sits down again and fastens his seat belt. What can I do, hemmed in by the window? Press the call button? Say: "Excuse me, do you mind letting me out to have a word with the pilot?" Osama buries his head in a newspaper. Cunning! And he is so cool. By now, I reckon, most hijackers would be sweating rather a lot and just pretending to read the paper.

I watch him, trying not to make it too obvious. He really is reading the paper. He folds it over and spends some time on an article about the Jordanian army. Anyway, it's too late now - we're airborne and in a few minutes Osama bin Blueshirt will be heading for the flight deck, unlessÉ

Reports of the hijacking last month mentioned there were security guards on board who overpowered the man with the grenade. Could Osama be one of them? From his aisle seat at the back, he has a clear view to the front of the plane, and he's sitting on the left, so his right hand is free to pull out the gun and use it, without even leaving his seat.

The food arrives and he strikes up a conversation: Where are you from? What do you do? Is it your first visit to Jordan?

I ask him if he's ever been to Britain. "Yes, London, six times," he says proudly.

"Holiday or work?"

"Work."

"Do you like London?" "I don't know. I stay only one night."

"Do you work in security?" He looks surprised.

"I saw the gun when you stood up," I say, pointing to his shirt. Perhaps I shouldn't have mentioned it. Perhaps he doesn't like to be recognised. But he grins and slaps the palm of my hand, the way that Arab men do when they want to be matey.

"Yes, I work in the army," he says.

"Do you fly every day?" I ask. "Do you always have this seat?"

He pulls out the newspaper again, signalling that he doesn't want to answer questions. Anyway Osama, thanks for a safe flight. Next time I'm sitting bored in an airport I'll be playing Spot the Security Man.

fields.headline: Car firm reignites euro row
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The political row over Britain's membership of the single currency burst into fresh life yesterday when the Japanese car manufacturer Toyota insisted that British suppliers seeking new business would have to trade in euros.
fields.byline: Michael White, Mark Milner and Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
The political row over Britain's membership of the single currency burst into fresh life yesterday when the Japanese car manufacturer Toyota insisted that British suppliers seeking new business would have to trade in euros.

The leading Tory eurosceptic John Redwood seized on the Toyota move, accusing the government of getting the motor company to "do its dirty work for it" by stepping up the pressure for the UK to enter monetary union.

After a summer of cabinet warfare over the single currency, the government yesterday sought to play down the significance of Toyota's decision, taken as a result of the impact of weakness of the euro on cars manufactured in Britain and sold in mainland Europe.

The Blairite cabinet office minister, Lord Falconer, stood by Gordon Brown's "five economic tests", though he added: "We in principle think it is a good thing to join the euro if it is in the economic interests of this country."

The Department of Trade and Industry also played down the symbolic importance of Toyota's move by reminding industry that it had long been encouraging business, especially small and medium sized firms, to start trading in euros if there were sales to be had that way. "If being able to transact and quote in euros allows you to win more business why let a point of principle stand in your way?" said one official.

In a statement, Toyota said: "We can confirm we have requested a small number of suppliers to quote for new business in euros rather than sterling." It added that it was looking to find ways of cutting costs, although that might include stepping up production at its Derbyshire manufacturing base from last year's 180,000 cars to its full capacity of 220,000 - a move likely to involve extra investment.

The Conservative view - that a major player in a troubled sector was simply trying to offload the exchange rate "risk" on to its smaller suppliers - was echoed by the lobbying group Business for Sterling, which opposes UK membership of the euro.

UK components makers had been bracing themselves for Toyota's initiative, the latest in a series of moves by Japanese companies worried about the high value of the pound at a time when selling cars globally has never been more competitive. After a mini-recovery earlier in the summer, the euro has been on the slide again recently, both against the pound and the US dollar.

"We were warned earlier this year by some big components suppliers that there would soon be a deadline for change from Toyota," said Edward Roberts, chairman of the Worcestershire-based firm, Peterson Springs.

"It comes down to a competitive issue, especially with the pound as strong as it is. Whatever the politicians and the public feel about the pound and the euro, the change is happening anyway within business."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering union, expressed sympathy for Toyota's problem, and warned: "This will have a huge impact on the motor components sector, who will have to bear the brunt of currency fluctuations. Our major European exporters do not want the uncertainty of exchange rate fluctuations."

The director general of the CBI, Digby Jones, said Toyota had made "a pragmatic business decision".

webTitle: Fledgling Mondus raises £100m with sale of 40% stake

fields.headline: Fledgling Mondus raises £100m with sale of 40% stake
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Mondus.com, the Oxford-based business-to-business specialist, yesterday proved that fledgling internet firms can still raise large sums of money despite investors' nervousness about companies in the hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
Mondus.com, the Oxford-based business-to-business specialist, yesterday proved that fledgling internet firms can still raise large sums of money despite investors' nervousness about companies in the hi-tech sector.

Italian business directories group Seat Pagine Gialle said it was paying $150m (£100m) in cash and shares for a 40% stake in Mondus - representing one of the largest private fundraisings by a European internet company. Mondus was founded by two Oxford university Rhodes scholars last year and operates business to business sites for large firms; it is valued at $375m after the fundraising.

Around $10m of the new money will come in cash, with the balance in Seat shares which Mondus expects to sell for cash later in the year. Seat issues telephone and business directories in several European markets and is in the process of merging with Italian internet service provider Tin.it.

Earlier this week Seat announced the acquisition of TDL Infomedia, publisher of the Thomson Local directories circulated to 22m homes in the UK. Mondus co-founder Rouzbeh Pirouz said the combination of Mondus' technology and e-commerce experience with Seat's directories and client base presented "a powerful proposition" for connecting buyers and sellers. Gary List, chief executive of TDL Infomedia, said: "Mondus will enable Thomson to take our leading business directory into a whole new dimension - that of an online dynamic marketplace, providing a more efficient way for listed businesses to communicate and trade."

Mr Pirouz, 28, co-founded Mondus with Alexander Straub. He was raised in Canada after his parents were exiled from his native Iran. He won a scholarship to Oxford after completing degrees at Stanford and Harvard.

fields.headline: Labour poll lead back to 15%
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's £43bn comprehensive spending review has pushed Labour's lead over the Conservatives back to 15% - 5% higher than a month ago, before the chancellor unveiled his plans, according to a new poll which may revive speculation about an early election.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's £43bn comprehensive spending review has pushed Labour's lead over the Conservatives back to 15% - 5% higher than a month ago, before the chancellor unveiled his plans, according to a new poll which may revive speculation about an early election.

Today's Gallup poll for the Daily Telegraph confirms the Guardian/ICM findings, and other polls, which suggest that Tory gains during William Hague's spring offensive have proved as ephemeral as jittery ministers hoped.

The Gallup poll suggests Labour is now on 47% - up 2% over mid-July - with the Tories down 3% on 32%, and the Liberal Democrats unchanged on 14%.

That is enough to allow Labour's election strategists to assume they are on course for a second term, with polling day probably next May or June.

But persistent speculation among a few MPs does not rule out that Tony Blair will try to wrongfoot opponents by a snap election in October.

Talk of a snap poll this year is offset by two calculations, one that any hint of cut-and-run may reawaken voter fears that Labour is all spin, the other that Mr Blair is going to the country because he shares those doubts.

fields.headline: Leader arrested at ETA rally
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: A Basque politician linked to ETA was arrested after scuffling with the police in Pamplona yesterday as protesters holding a vigil for the separatist movement's latest presumed victim screamed "murderers" and "scum" at a pro-ETA group across the square.
fields.body:
A Basque politician linked to ETA was arrested after scuffling with the police in Pamplona yesterday as protesters holding a vigil for the separatist movement's latest presumed victim screamed "murderers" and "scum" at a pro-ETA group across the square.

The hundreds gathered outside Pamplona town hall and throughout the Basque region were marking the fatal shooting on Wednesday of Sub-Lieutenant Francisco Casanova.

The man arrested in Pamplona was Juan Kruz Aldasoro, a leader of Euskal Herritarrok, which includes Herri Batasuna, regarded as ETA's political wing.

The party had been refused permission to hold a rally in memory of four suspected ETA members killed on Monday when the car in which they were driving exploded, but about a dozen of its local leaders gathered nevertheless.
AP, Pamplona

webTitle: Russia offers help to British detainees

fields.headline: Russia offers help to British detainees
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Russia signalled for the first time yesterday its willingness to use its influence with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to try to secure the release of two British policemen and two Canadians held in Belgrade on terrorism charges.
fields.body:
Russia signalled for the first time yesterday its willingness to use its influence with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to try to secure the release of two British policemen and two Canadians held in Belgrade on terrorism charges.

The offer came as a British and a Canadian diplomat gained access to the men for the first time, more than a week after their arrest near Montenegro's border with Kosovo.

Accompanied by local lawyers, the British envoy, Robert Gordon, and the Canadian charge d'affaires, Craig Bale, visited the men at the military court where they are under preliminary investigation.

Mr Gordon said that the two Britons, Detective Sergeant Adrian Prangnell, 41, from Hampshire, and PC John Yore, 31, from Cambridgeshire were "fine and in good health".

The two Canadians, Shaun Going and his nephew Liam Hall, were also reported to be in a satisfactory condition.

"They are healthy, they've been well treated and we were able to discuss their detention with them," said Mr Bale. "We are hopeful ... that they will be released as soon as possible."

The Yugoslav army detained the four last week after allegedly finding de-mining and explosives-related material in their car. They have not yet been formally charged. During a court hearing on Wednesday all four men denied any wrongdoing.

UN officials in Kosovo - where the four worked - maintain that they were returning from a brief holiday when captured. If tried and convicted, they face up to 15 years in prison.

Alexander Yakovenko, the Russian foreign ministry spokesman, told the Guardian last night that the Kremlin would react "positively" to British requests for it to use its influence in Belgrade to free the men.

Earlier the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, told his Canadian counterpart, Lloyd Axworthy, that Moscow wanted the legal status of international organisations in Yugoslavia defined swiftly, so that employees of international agencies there could enjoy immunity from arrest and prosecution.

The detained men were working in Kosovo for the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

Earlier this week, British MPs called on Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, to intervene with Mr Milosevic to have the men released.

An aide to Mr Putin said the Russian president took a dim view of all "international hostage-taking", but declined to say whether Mr Putin had contacted the Yugoslav leader.

Yesterday's moves by the Russian foreign ministry were the first signs of Moscow's intervention. Following a phone conversation with Mr Ivanov, Mr Axworthy said Moscow had agreed "to offer Russian assistance" in Belgrade.

He added that the Russian ambassador "is very well regarded''. President Milosevic's brother, Borislav, is the Yugoslav ambassador in Moscow.

fields.headline: Hospital equipment funds 'diverted'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: More than £160m earmarked for hospital equipment in Scotland over the last five years has been diverted to reduce NHS trust budget deficits, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
More than £160m earmarked for hospital equipment in Scotland over the last five years has been diverted to reduce NHS trust budget deficits, it emerged yesterday.

According to figures compiled by the Scottish National party, £165m of capital funds allocated for equipment was transferred to revenue budgets between 1995 and this year, a time when the medical profession had increasingly been warning of the problems caused by a lack of equipment, and outdated machines.

One doctor has revealed that his department resorted to getting parts from a scrap yard to keep old equipment in use.

The SNP said the practice of diverting funds was known about and sanctioned by the Scottish executive and the Scottish Office before it.

The Scottish executive said it has now been banned and money allocated for new equipment cannot be spent elsewhere.

Using parliamentary questions, the SNP said it had discovered that in Glasgow alone, a city with one of the poorest health records in the UK, £21m had been moved from capital to revenue budgets.

"We have had all this hype about new money here, there and everywhere," said the nationalist Glasgow MSP Kenneth Gibson. "But the NHS has been drained of resources, especially for equipment. The Scottish executive have been trying to make out that this was nothing to do with them.

"The reality is, they have always known about it and sanctioned it. They allowed the trusts to move the money about. The trusts had to seek permission to do so."

A spokeswoman for the executive said: "As Mr Gibson is aware, capital to revenue transfers were allowed within the NHS for a number of specific reasons.

"However, the Scottish executive changed that position in April of this year. We have tightened up the financial rules for trusts and they are now barred from moving resources around in this way. Trusts are no longer able to behave like separate financial bodies. And we hold their managers to account for the quality of care they provide and for the management of their finances."

Jamie Weir, chairman of the Royal College of Radiologists in Scotland, said he could not comment on the SNP's claims but he said equipment used by colleagues was often in a poor state and they had been forced to resort to often extreme measures to keep them working.

"In Aberdeen, we are actually getting some parts from a Glasgow scrap yard dealer to be able to keep parts of our equipment going and that is not an exaggeration," Professor Weir said.

"The manufacturers will, in fact, not replace parts because they do not hold spare parts for more than 10 to 12 years and a lot of equipment around the country is 17 to 20 years old."

Mr Gibson has said he will raise the matter when the Scottish parliament resumes in September and will challenge the executive to explain how the "lost" money will be replaced.

webTitle: No room for Blairism in new OED

fields.headline: No room for Blairism in new OED
fields.trailText: The latest words to join the English language include white van man, frankenfood and cybersquatting, according to a new edition of the Oxford Dictionary.
fields.body:
The latest words to join the English language include white van man, frankenfood and cybersquatting, according to a new edition of the Oxford Dictionary.

But there is no room for Blairism among the 67 new words to have been included in the Oxford Compact English Dictionary. Compilers of the dictionary say the word, relating to prime minister Tony Blair, must first pass the test of time.

The publishers monitor television, radio, newspapers and magazines to determine which words have been adopted into the English language and are now used in everyday conversations.

Carpenter trousers (multi-pocketed trousers with loops for tools) will be included, along with shrug (close fitting woman's cardigan) and buzz-cut (today's answer to the crew-cut).

The information technology sector has also provided a number of new words including meatspace (physical world, as opposed to virtual), screenager (internet-addicted teenager) and sticky (website attracting long or repeated visits from users).

More unusual words to have earned a place include gaydar (ability of one gay person to recognise another) and lookism (discrimination on the grounds of how a person looks).

And although the prime minister may have not been recognised, the government may be familiar with prebuttal (political response agreed in advance of criticism).

The Oxford University Press dictionary is to be published on August 14.

fields.headline: UK charity accused of spying
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russian intelligence yesterday accused the British mine clearance charity the Halo Trust, endorsed by Princess Diana, of spying against Russia and aiding and abetting rebel fighters in Chechnya. It also alleged that several Halo Trust employees were undercover British intelligence agents or army officers.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor and Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Russian intelligence yesterday accused the British mine clearance charity the Halo Trust, endorsed by Princess Diana, of spying against Russia and aiding and abetting rebel fighters in Chechnya. It also alleged that several Halo Trust employees were undercover British intelligence agents or army officers.

In a detailed statement, the FSB domestic intelligence service said that the Halo Trust had been working unauthorised in Chechnya since 1997 in league with the Chechen leader, President Aslan Maskhadov, and other Chechen warlords, training rebel combat engineers while pretending to be engaged in mine clearance operations.

The FSB named three British citizens working behind Chechen lines in the war zone and said the leader of a team of around 15 Halo Trust employees working in Chechnya last November was a career British military intelligence officer. He was named as Matthew Middlemis.

A senior aid official in Moscow confirmed that two other British citizens named were working for the Halo Trust.

The Foreign Office said last night that the Halo Trust was well aware of its advice to agencies not to go to Chechnya. Other Whitehall officials said the charity had done extremely valuable work in Kosovo, Cambodia and elsewhere and had worked closely with the FO.

They described the Russian allegations as "speculation" and said they were seeking further information from Moscow. Whitehall sources said they were fairly confident there was nothing behind the Russian allegations which they conceded were "specific" but whose timing they described as "bizarre".

The Halo Trust "came to the notice of Russian state security agencies in 1998 when British subjects Charlie Emms, Nicholas Nobbs, and Zimbabwe citizen Thomas Dibb... were reported to be engaged in spying and subversive activities against Russia in Chechnya", the FSB statement said.

The charity's director, Guy Willoughby, a former Coldstream Guards officer based in Dumfriesshire, Scotland, flatly dismissed the Russian charges.

"We just completely deny this sort of allegation, that we were in any way supporting mine laying or any form of terrorist activity. We were running a standard humanitarian mine-clearing organisation and the Russian authorities knew about it," he said.

He said the agency had left Chechnya late last year and that of the four men named by the FSB only one - Mr Dibb - still worked for the organisation. Mr Middlemis had left four years ago.

He said the charity employed 150 Chechens, as its website made clear. Some of them had been captured by the Russians. The charity worked in Chechnya between 1997 and 1999 when they surveyed the whole of Chechnya. It left of its own accord, said Mr Willoughby.

The Halo Trust teams were said to have entered Chechnya with the aid of rebel fighters via the high mountain passes of the Georgia border, which the Russians view as the rebel supply lines. "Halo Trust is supposed to be engaged in humanitarian work, clearing mines," said the FSB spokesman, Alexander Zdanovich. "But the road to hell is paved with good intentions. In fact this organisation's staff and its recruits - it trained more than 100 people - were trained not to clear mines, but mainly to lay minefields, to lay explosives on the roads used by federal [Russian] troops, as a result repeatedly exploding their charges on the roads, laying their bombs in the forests, killing people, servicemen and peaceful civilians."

But senior aid workers with long experience of the extremely dangerous conditions in Chechnya praised the Halo Trust's professionalism and courage in conducting mine clearance operations that no one else would take on.

The FSB said the Russian authorities had arrested seven Chechens trained and employed by the Halo Trust.

"Under cover of mine-clearing operations, [the Halo Trust] organised the training of combat engineers and carried out full-scale topographic surveillance of Chechnya, fixing Chechen villages to the Nato frame of reference," the FSB said.

The Russians appear to have been following the charity's activities for months, if not years, and aid workers in Moscow were at a loss to understand why the FSB unveiled its allegations now.

webTitle: Scientists get to the heart of the antimatter

fields.headline: Scientists get to the heart of the antimatter
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: European scientists have started making the ultimate hard-to-handle product - antimatter. Yesterday they turned on their new antiproton decelerator at Cern, the European particle laboratory in Geneva, and started the tricky business of manipulating a material that would destroy anything it touched.
fields.body:
European scientists have started making the ultimate hard-to-handle product - antimatter. Yesterday they turned on their new antiproton decelerator at Cern, the European particle laboratory in Geneva, and started the tricky business of manipulating a material that would destroy anything it touched.

Antimatter is matter in reverse. It is created in particle accelerators, but when it meets ordinary fabric, both matter and antimatter are annihilated in a colossal burst of energy.

Scientists at Cern see antimatter appear and disappear instantaneously during every second of their experiments. But they have seen only the equivalents of parts of atoms, rather than atoms themselves. Physicists have known about positrons (positively charged electrons) and antiprotons for decades. The proton is the heavy, positively charged bit at the heart of the atom; the electron is the light, negatively charged bit that balances it.

In 1996, scientists at Cern went further, making nine atoms of antihydrogen, which perished almost immediately. Antiparticles are born from experiments in an accelerator which takes matter almost to the speed of light. The new instrument, the 188m antiproton decelerator, gathers the antiprotons in bunches, slows them down, traps them in electromagnetic cages and slows them almost to a standstill. All this has to be done in a perfect vacuum.

At this point, two groups of scientists plan to add positrons - now routinely used in hospital brain scans- to the antiprotons to make antihydrogen. A third group are planning to use the helium atom as a kind of antiproton-catcher.

The antimatter will be made only in the tiniest trickles - all the antimatter made in Europe and the US in the last two decades would add up to less than a millionth of a gram. But once they have amassed their imprisoned anti-atoms, scientists can study their behaviour.

Space scientists have a direct interest: they calculate that even a small lump of antimatter - perhaps 20kg - could drive something the size of the Starship Enterprise around the galaxy. More directly, the experiment could begin to answer one of the big questions of creation: why is the universe made of matter, rather than antimatter?

All the evidence is that when matter condenses from energy, it does so in equal quantities of matter and antimatter. But unless there was slightly more matter than antimatter in the first moments of creation, the two should have destroyed each other.

"In this cosmic battleground, matter came out the winner and we are all here. But that defies the understanding of physics," said Neil Calder of Cern, yesterday. "Exactly the same amount of matter and antimatter is produced, so we shouldn't be here. But we are."

webTitle: Prescott bid to improve work safety

fields.headline: Prescott bid to improve work safety
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, yesterday agreed to stage a conference next year on safety and penalties for carelessness in the construction industry, as a building worker suffered leg injuries after falling eight storeys from scaffolding in central London.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, yesterday agreed to stage a conference next year on safety and penalties for carelessness in the construction industry, as a building worker suffered leg injuries after falling eight storeys from scaffolding in central London.

He met health and safety executive officials following a sharp rise in the number of construction workers killed as routine inspections drop.

Over the past 12 months there have been 79 deaths in construction, up from 65, against the national trend in workplace accidents. Construction accounts for a third of work deaths. In May three men were killed in a crane accident in east London.

Unions say the number of inspectors has fallen by 40% since 1992. They want increased fines and an offence of corporate negligence.

webTitle: Porn history for Lib Dem candidate

fields.headline: Porn history for Lib Dem candidate
fields.trailText: A woman who plans to stand as a county councillor admitted today she had a leading role in a hardcore porn film which was filmed in her Northampton council house.
fields.body:
A woman who plans to stand as a county councillor admitted today she had a leading role in a hardcore porn film which was filmed in her Northampton council house.

Tina Harvey, better known by her middle name Louise, stood for the Liberal Democrats in last year's borough council elections.

She took part in a group sex session for the video, British Housewives' Fantasies, but is adamant she has done nothing wrong. "My private life is my own business. I was just having a bit of fun with some friends," she said.

Richard Church, vice-chairman of Northampton Liberal Democrats, said the reputation of the party had not been damaged but Ms Harvey should have told members about her past before standing for the elections.

It was reported that Ms Harvey, 35, received no payment for the film.

The sex scenes, which take up around 20 minutes of the two hour, 22 minute video, were filmed around Ms Harvey's home in Northampton.

webTitle: Watchdog acts on payments for MPs' speeches

fields.headline: Watchdog acts on payments for MPs' speeches
fields.standfirst:
Filkin seeks to ensure money for services is not laundered as fees
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, is cracking down on outside speaking engagements by leading MPs such as Charles Kennedy and Michael Portillo because she is determined to prevent speech fees being used to circumvent the rules on members interests.
fields.body:
The parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, is cracking down on outside speaking engagements by leading MPs such as Charles Kennedy and Michael Portillo because she is determined to prevent speech fees being used to circumvent the rules on members interests.

She wants to stop money owed for less innocent services being "laundered'' as fees for speeches - as happened in Washington DC until the practice was banned.

In what looked to some MPs like a tit for tat exchange, Mr Portillo's availibility to speak for up to £5,000 was revealed by a Labour MP days after a Conservative colleague had shone a similar spotlight on Mr Kennedy - who vigorously denied any impropriety.

There is no suggestion that the Liberal Democrat leader or the shadow chancellor has done anything wrong in failing to make more explicit declarations of after-dinner speeches. It seems likely they failed to understand what is now expected of them.

Nor did the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, nor John Major, the former Tory prime minister, whose speech-making have also fallen foul of Mrs Filkin's investigations this year. In 18 months before he was elected mayor Mr Livinstone earned £220,992 from speech making, including £158,000 not included in the members' register.

Now any speech which earns an MP more than £500 should be itemised.

Some 208 MPs list "occasional'' fees for speeches, journalism or broadcasting. All may have to check their records, MPs were advised in June. Some have been slow to respond.

"When in doubt consult and register,'' the independent MP, Martin Bell, said last night. Mrs Filkin, who succeeded Sir Gordon Downey as Westminster's independent watchdog on parliamentary ethics - a byproduct of Lord Nolan's anti-sleaze inquiry - is determined that MPs who make such outside speeches more than three times a year using a professional agency should register their employment agreement and the fee.

The reasoning behind the move, which is subject to oversight by the Commons standards and privileges committee, stems from US experience which led to all "honoraria'' for speeches or guest appearances being banned a decade ago.

In a series of cases, including that of Jim Wright of Texas, speaker of the house of representatives, US congressmen were found to be taking fees for speeches which were, in reality, covert payments for consultancies and similar services.

In effect, payments were being "laundered'' despite 20 years of ever-tighter efforts to clean up US politics, which is money-driven because candidates are obliged to buy costly television advertisements.

A ban on speaker's fees was therefore imposed, though members of congress are allowed to nominate a charity to which up to $2,000 (around £1,300) can be given, provided the senate or house member does not benefit directly and that the money is not sent to the charity via the politician.

Unlike "cash for questions'' and other unsavoury conduct unearthed at Westminster, no evidence exists for similar tactics being deployed in Britain. But it has made MPs and officials sensitive to the danger.

Rules designed to oblige MPs to register outside consultancies also are written so as to require them to register employment agreements with the speakers' agencies who provide after dinner stars.

With most MPs away from Westminster, Mrs Filkin has not spoken either to Mr Kennedy or Mr Portillo. But colleagues argued that the speakers' agency was "acting for me'' in fixing up a speech -rather than the other way round, as when an MP acted in parliament on behalf of a consultancy client.

Though most complaints about MPs entries in the register were either incorrect or amicably resolved, the speech issue has caused some anger.

webTitle: Man dies as bike stunt goes wrong

fields.headline: Man dies as bike stunt goes wrong
fields.trailText: Witnesses yesterday described the moment when a daredevil motorcycle stunt went horribly wrong, leaving a 59-year-old compere dead.
fields.body:
Witnesses yesterday described the moment when a daredevil motorcycle stunt went horribly wrong, leaving a 59-year-old compere dead.

The 24-year-old motorcyclist from Cheshire, who police refused to name, attempted to leap over several people on Wednesday night in Clacton-on-Sea, Essex, but landed his machine on the head of Colin Burns.

The motorcyclist was taken to Colchester general hospital where he was treated for a broken shoulder and ribs.

A police spokesman said Mr Burns, from the Hollywood Stunt Show, was playing a reluctant volunteer who was persuaded to lie in front of the bike with others.

At the last minute everyone moved away to leave him as the only person to be cleared by the bike. But the machine hit him as it came down.

Police are treating the incident as an industrial accident and confirmed that the Tendring district council's health and safety department was also investigating it.

Paula Adekunle, from London, who is on holiday with her family in Clacton, said the rider first jumped over three or four men with crash helmets. "For the second stunt the commentator was talking about jumping a fifth man and said they had never done five men before.

"Then as the guy was talking the stuntmen came up behind him, lifted him and plonked him on the grass. Just before the bike jumped, all the others ran behind some cars and left the commentator alone. The bike landed right on his head."

Ian Batey, foreman of the Hollywood Stunt Show, said future show dates had been cancelled. "Everyone is just ready to give up."

He said the stunt had been performed for the last 20 years and "never before have we had any accidents".

fields.headline: Missile warning to US
fields.trailText: A decision by the United States to proceed with its controversial national missile defence system (NMD) could trigger a huge build-up of nuclear arms by China and Russia and increase nuclear proliferation on the Indian subcontinent, intelligence chiefs have warned President Clinton.
fields.body:
A decision by the United States to proceed with its controversial national missile defence system (NMD) could trigger a huge build-up of nuclear arms by China and Russia and increase nuclear proliferation on the Indian subcontinent, intelligence chiefs have warned President Clinton.

A still-classified report reiterates that North Korea could threaten the US with a ballistic missile attack within a few years - the ostensible original reason for the development of NMD. But it paints a dramatic picture of the worldwide consequences as other nuclear and would-be nuclear powers respond to fresh US missile deployments.

The National Intelligence Estimate was delivered to the White House this week and sent to Congress yesterday. The report is part of a process in which Mr Clinton is pledged to decide this autumn whether to go ahead with work to begin installing up to 100 interceptor missiles in Alaska by 2007 - a move opposed not only by Washington's enemies but almost all of its allies, including Britain.

It is looking increasingly likely that Mr Clinton will not be able to give the go-ahead to the project. The US defence secretary, William Cohen, admitted this week that "a number of difficult issues" remained unresolved with NMD which, from the outset, has been driven at least as much by US domestic politics as international defence issues.

The latest intelligence report focuses on two of the four questions the administration has said will be taken into account in making a decision on whether to deploy. These are an assessment of the threat to the US and an assessment of the international security consequences of a decision to go ahead.

The other issues Mr Clinton must take into account are the feasibility of missile defence systems and their cost. Washington already faces huge problems with feasibility and cost following the failure of the latest test interception over the Pacific ocean last month.

Normally, the intelligence assessments would only intensify the pressures on the White House to abandon - or indefinitely postpone - NMD. But Mr Clinton and the vice-president, Al Gore, are afraid to halt the project before the November 7 US election because it would enable the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, to label the Democrats soft on defence.

The report, which was leaked to two US newspapers yesterday, warns that even the "limited" version of NMD under consideration could prompt China to expand its current arsenal of some 20 long-range nuclear missiles. China would attempt to expand its missile stockpile to target the NMD interceptors in Alaska and their ground-based support systems, which the US is planning in the Aleutian Islands, Greenland and at Fylingdales on the North York moors.

One report yesterday said the intelligence briefing estimates that China would increase its arsenal to 200 ballistic missiles by 2015. Such a move would almost certainly trigger a response from China's nuclear neighbours, including India and Pakistan, as well as increasing the possibility of other nuclear proliferation.

Turning to Russia, the intelligence chiefs say that the US move could lead Moscow to again deploy shorter range missiles along its borders and resume adding multiple warheads to its ballistic missiles.

The Clinton administration's plan would involve 100 interceptor missiles, which Washington has said could handle only about 25 incoming warheads, and would be aimed at blocking attacks by countries such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq.

Chinese officials have complained that even this deployment could overwhelm Beijing's existing nuclear forces, thus necessitating a response.

webTitle: Computer bugs could delay new air traffic centre

fields.headline: Computer bugs could delay new air traffic centre
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A £623m air traffic control centre which has already been held back for six years is in danger of being further delayed because 200 computer bugs still plague its software, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A £623m air traffic control centre which has already been held back for six years is in danger of being further delayed because 200 computer bugs still plague its software, it emerged yesterday.

Three hundred IT experts are racing against the clock to iron out glitches before safety inspectors assess the centre's system at Swanwick, Hampshire, in December this year. Should they fail, the centre, which had an initial budget of £350m, may have to push back its scheduled opening date of January 2002, causing costs to soar.

The extent of the problem was unearthed by the magazine Computer Weekly, which has been a vociferous critic of the centre's system since problems first emerged in 1994. Thousands of bugs were initially uncovered, with 1,400 still existing in 1999, and 500 in May this year. Tony Collins, an executive editor at the magazine, said there was now a low to medium risk that the centre - due to control most of the airspace above England and Wales - would not open on schedule.

"Any one of these bugs that affects safety has the potential to delay the programme because Nats [the national air traffic services, which control Britain's airspace] won't compromise on safety," he said.

"On a positive note, they have cleared up many of the problems, but to some extent the bugs they have identified are less serious than the ones they haven't yet identified. This is a piece of software with 2m lines of code and there are still some upgrades of software they need to do. With a system of this size, there could still be huge problems."

Faults have included a problem with communication links between Swanwick and the ageing London air traffic control centre at West Drayton, most of whose work it will take over. There has also been a big problem involving back-up power supplies that would keep Swanwick's 200 controller work stations running in an emergency.

In tests, up to 60% of the work stations failed instead of the anticipated 25%.

"That was an unacceptably high failure rate," admitted Richard Wright, a spokesman for Nats. "But we have acquired an additional, fifth, power supply, to preserve the level of service."

Nats, which is expected to be partly privatised before the Swanwick centre is opened, last night said that it was confident that it would meet its technical handover date in December, when the system will be ready for air traffic controllers to spend a year training.

"There's still a lot to do but the fact that we're down to this number of so-called bugs now is extremely good news for us", said its chief executive, Bill Semple.

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, he insisted that no bugs would affect its operation.

"I can absolutely assure anybody... that there will be no compromises made that will impact on safety. If there are any doubts on that account I can assure you that I will not take this system into operation," he said.

webTitle: Extra police tied to meeting crime targets

fields.headline: Extra police tied to meeting crime targets
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText:
Police forces will receive new funds for more officers only if they meet Home Office targets to cut crime in their areas and to take on more black and Asian officers, it emerged last night.

As chief constables learned their shares of the extra 4,000 officers promised nationally over the next three years, the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, said the government would insist on seeing real results on current targets before it parted with funds for future expanded staffing. "Forces across England and Wales have now been given an unexpected boost to their existing and already enhanced recruitment plans, and will want to work hard to ensure they use the extra ring-fenced resources to improve their crime-fighting capabilities," said Mrs Roche. "In return the government and the public will want to see results - reduction in crime, with more offenders being brought to justice."

Their recruitment targets include boosting the number of black and Asian officers as well as cutting annual sickness levels from the current average of 11.7 working days per officer.

The money for the extra 4,000 recruits was announced by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in the July comprehensive spending review. It came on top of existing plans to recruit a further 5,000 officers over the next three years, in an attempt to reverse the decline in police numbers. A total of £667m has been earmarked to pay for the project. The expansion will stretch police training places to the limit. A newly-trained constable can expect to be paid better than £18,000 a year outside London and more in the capital.

The distribution of the 4,000 extra recruits among the 43 forces in England and Wales has been on the same basis as the annual allocation of budget funds. The total of 9,000 will be spread at the rate of 3,000 a year.

There has been no particular allowance made to boost police in rural areas despite the furore over the Tony Martin case, in which the East Anglian farmer shot two burglars. The largest numbers of extra officers are being put into the big city forces, with the Metropolitan police getting funds for 931 extra officers. The West Midlands is to get 213; Greater Manchester 210; West Yorkshire 161 and Merseyside 131.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, welcomed the plans but warned that the government was likely to break its manifesto commitment to increase police numbers. "Police numbers started to fall under the Conservatives but accelerated under Labour," he said. "The Government's decision to stick to Tory spending plans for the first two years means that most of this money will be used to replace officers lost since Labour came to power. Ministers admitted that they will only get back to 1997 levels of police strength in 2002."

webTitle: Problem Leylandii to be cut down by councils

fields.headline: Suburban monster cut down to size
fields.standfirst: Minister will give green light to chain saw enforcement teams after saga of legal battles, violence and ruined lives
fields.trailText: Leylandii, the fastest growing, most numerous and most hated tree in Britain, is finally to be called to account for the mayhem it has caused in suburbia. Council chain saw hit squads are to be given the power to enter gardens and cut problem hedges down to size, bringing relief to many an overshadowed home.
fields.body:
Leylandii, the fastest growing, most numerous and most hated tree in Britain, is finally to be called to account for the mayhem it has caused in suburbia. Council chain saw hit squads are to be given the power to enter gardens and cut problem hedges down to size, bringing relief to many an overshadowed home.

Yesterday the environment minister, Michael Meacher, announced new legislation to curb the cupressocyparis leylandii which, he says, has, more than any other issue, filled his postbag since the general election with "thousands of ruined lives, many legal battles and even violence".

Following a public consultation begun last year, an astonishing 97% of the public wanted the government to sort out leylandii - 94% supporting the idea of legislation to allow them to be compulsorily cut down.

Nearly eight out of 10 local authorities, exhausted by fruitless efforts to sort out disputes between neighbours, wanted the power to act unilaterally if hedge owners would not cooperate.

The ubiquitous plant, once praised for its robust constitution and ability to set roots down virtually anywhere, has been the culprit in numerous court cases pitting neighbour against neighbour.

It has even spurred a police manhunt for a bizarre arsonist who has been targeting gardens in Leeds suburbs where the offending trees have been set on fire in the dead of night. Never in the history of gardening has a single plant caused so much trouble - or a Latin name so readily entered the English language.

The tree, an accidental hybrid between two unrelated fir trees from North America which occurred on the estate of the collector C J Leyland in 1888, was once thought a boon for gardeners. They were marketed as graceful but "flourishing in any soil, standing up to fierce winds, free of pests and disease, and growing like rockets".

It was this last trait that has caused the trouble. Some varieties of leylandii grow readily 3ft a year. From a tiny start in the 1960s when nurseries learned to propagate the tree easily, there are now an estimated 55m in Britain and around 300,000 are sold every year.

Because the trees are still relatively young, no one knows how high they might grow but one in Kent is already 150ft and hedges of 60 to 70ft are frequent.

The most celebrated legal battle involving the tree lasted seven years, cost £100,000, and reached the court of appeal. It involved Michael Jones and his neighbour Bernard Standon of Bournville in Birmingham, who quarrelled over a 35ft leylandii hedge which Mr Jones had leaned over and trimmed by 9ft.

Mr Jones won his case because of local covenants on the estate in Birmingham which prevent nuisance to neighbours but dozens of other cases have been lost on the basis that an Englishman can do what he likes in his own garden. Many people have been fined for criminal damage for taking unilateral action like Mr Jones, because they were not protected by covenant. Mr Jones founded Hedgeline to help them. The organisation, which has 3,000 members whose lives have become dominated by disputes over out of control boundary hedges, has been campaigning for a change in the law.

Two years ago the group took its case to Downing Street. Like the avenging army of Malcolm approaching Macbeth it hid its numbers under branches of leylandii but left the government in no doubt about the strength of feeling.

Mr Meacher knows the weight of his postbag. "This has caused huge feeling. A vote of 97% in favour of action on any issue does not happen outside the Kremlin normally. "There are tens of thousands of cases of private disputes between neighbours. There is a depth of anger and misery which high hedges cause which cannot be overstated - this show of public opinion proves it."

He said that there would be no prescribed height limit for hedges. In some cases to shield houses from wind or traffic nuisance a high hedge could be justified but in small suburban gardens matters were different. "It will not be hard for local authorities used to dealing with planning matters to sort this out. Mediation is the best answer but in the last resort the councils must have the power to physically intervene, and that means sending in the chain saws." Mr Jones said: "We are delighted to have a firm pledge that this nuisance will be finally dealt with. There are a lot of hedge victims out there who need urgent help."

He urged the government to support the private member's bill currently before the House of Lords, which would give local authorities the power to intervene in hedge disputes, and Mr Meacher said yesterday that he would consider it.

Clare Hinchcliffe, a Hedgeline organiser, compiles case histories of violence and court cases. She said: "Many of our members are old ladies and timid people bullied by monster hedges which cut the light out of their homes and their gardens and dominate their lives. They suffer years of anxiety as the hedges grow bigger and bigger and they are powerless to do anything about it.

"If at last they can get relief by appealing to the local authority to mediate and if that does not work to apply compulsion that is wonderful news. Let us hope it comes soon."

A growing history of trouble

 John Gibbons from Sunderland is still paying £40 a month out of his pension after being fined £2,000 for cutting a few branches from his neighbour's leylandii two years ago. He made a dent in it at the time, he says, but it is still growing and its 18ft height in winter blocks the sunlight from his home. His wife Aline said: "The magistrates did not even come and look. Next door has a garden the size of a football pitch and the trees are miles away from their house. Our house is only 15ft away and the garden is so much in the shade no sunlight penetrates. There has been nothing we can do about it, but it is an injustice."

 A keen gardener appeared in court yesterday charged with the murder of his next door neighbour. Llandis Burdon, 56, was shot in his own home after an alleged dispute over a 6ft- conifer hedge. His neighbour Uri Bowen, 61, was charged with the murder of Mr Burdon, a retired environment agency official. The two men were neighbours in Station Road, in Talybont-on-Usk, near Brecon, Powys, for more than 20 years.

 At least six leylandii blazes in the Bramley area of Leeds in one month last December were begun with lighted newspaper, probably sprinkled with lighter fuel. Leading firefighter Nigel Kitchingman, of West Yorkshire fire brigade, said at the time: "We think someone has a vendetta against the trees and is determined to get rid of them."

 Retired postman Phil Bodenham, 79, lost his life savings - some £15,000 - after trimming leylandii branches which he felt encroached on his garden at Cliffords Mesne, Gloucestershire. He was alleged by neighbour Alan Barnard to have cut off six inches two much, taken to court, fined £200 in damages and ordered to pay £15,000 costs.

 George Whitmill was hit with a bucket of water and a shotgun was fired in Hopwood Green, Newbury, Berkshire, in May this year after a dispute broke out as Mr Whitmill attempted to trim a neighbouring hedge. A man was questioned over the shotgun discharge.
