fields.headline: Increase in failed adoptions
fields.trailText: The number of adopted children who are returned to foster care or children's homes is increasing, according to new research.
fields.body:
The number of adopted children who are returned to foster care or children's homes is increasing, according to new research.

A survey of social workers by Community Care magazine has found that 15% had found a significant increase in the rate of adoption breakdowns. A further 49% said breakdowns had increased slightly.

Most professionals agree the statistics reflect the growing number of difficult children - who would have previously stayed in residential care or foster homes - that are now being adopted.

Despite the trend, the government is encouraging more people to adopt children. More than two-thirds of the social workers questioned in the survey agree that more children should be adopted.

Community Care's campaign aims to acknowledge that adoption is one component of an integrated child care system.

It calls upon social workers to consider a wider variety of families as adopters and the government to find resources to increase post-adoption support.

Vicky Renwick, of Adoption UK, which supports adoptive parents, said there was often a mismatch of adoptive parents' expectations and reality.

She said that some children did not want another family and instead, they should be placed with long-term foster families.

fields.headline: Convicted molesters reprieved from jail
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText:
Two convicted child molesters escaped jail yesterday as judges distanced themselves from anti-paedophile protests prompted by the News of the World's name and shame campaign.

In Manchester, a former teacher already named by the paper was given a suspended sentence after being convicted of sex offences against a former pupil. The judge ruled that he was a "marked man" who had already suffered "considerable adverse publicity''.
fields.body:
Two convicted child molesters escaped jail yesterday as judges distanced themselves from anti-paedophile protests prompted by the News of the World's name and shame campaign.

In Manchester, a former teacher already named by the paper was given a suspended sentence after being convicted of sex offences against a former pupil. The judge ruled that he was a "marked man" who had already suffered "considerable adverse publicity''.

In Newcastle, an 82-year-old Dunkirk veteran who put his hand down the trousers of a nine-year-old girl was placed on probation for two years by a judge who said that it was "punishment itself'' that he had been forced to move away from his home.

The sentences were passed as campaigners in Portsmouth halted their protests after driving out a fifth family from the Paulsgrove estate at the end of a week of night marches which had ended in violence.

Following a meeting with Portsmouth city council and police, the protesters agreed to show the authorities their list of 20 alleged paedophiles they believe are living on the Paulsgrove estate. Roger Ching, the council's acting chief executive, said it was "a significant move forward and a very positive step. We have repeated our offer to move anyone who feels threatened to a place of safety during this period of tension. We have also agreed to meet again on Monday to reassess the situation."

Last night Sara Payne, whose daughter Sarah was found murdered last month, appealed for an end to the violent demonstrations, saying "we won't change the law if this goes on''. Meanwhile Raymond Cullens, 51, was given a 15-month suspended jail sentence at Manchester crown court after being found guilty of four indecent assaults and three charges of indecency with a child. He had been jailed for 30 months in 1992 for indecently assaulting three pupils at a school in Rochdale, Greater Manchester, but was arrested again last year when a fourth victim contacted police.

Cullens's name and photograph featured in the second week of the News of the World's campaign but Judge Stuart Fish did not refer directly to the newspaper as he passed sentence. He told Cullens, who was also ordered to sign the sex offenders' register for 10 years, that he had taken into account the fact the offences had been committed at the same time as others for which he had already been jailed.

"I add to it the fact, I was going to say, [that] you are a marked man,'' said the judge. "That is a little over the top. But you and your family have suffered considerable adverse publicity, although of course it has to be said you are the author of your own misfortune in that respect.''

After the case, Kim Hawksworth, 22, who gave evidence of how she was abused by Cullens when aged eight, described the sentence as "absolutely disgraceful.

"I have spent 14 years serving this sentence and he walks out of court,'' she said after waiving her right to anonymity. "I think naming and shaming paedophiles is a brilliant campaign and every parent should have the right to know if a paedophile is living in their area."

In Newcastle, Charles Varnham, was placed on probation for two years after admitting indecently assaulting a nine-year-old girl at his home in Embleton, Northumberland.

"You have a proud history as a soldier and you have thrown away your good reputation with this offence,'' said judge David Wood. "The girl may not recover from this for a long time, if at all and usually people go to prison for this offending.

"You will be 83 this Sunday and have never been in trouble before. You have lost your home because you will not be permitted to go back to Embleton and will have to find a new life somewhere else and that seems punishment itself."

The suspension of the Portsmouth marches marks a change of heart by protesters, who had previously said they would not stop until all paedophiles on their list, compiled in part from the News of the World reports, had been forced out.

Last night a family told of their horror at returning home from holiday in Spain to find their car a burnt out wreck and their home ransacked. Julie and Gary Legge said they had no idea why anti-paedophile protesters targeted their home next door to that of local MP Syd Rapson.

webTitle: Aston Martins to roll out of Land-Rover site

fields.headline: Aston Martins to roll out of Land-Rover site
fields.trailText: Aston Martin yesterday rode the seemingly unstoppable crest of global demand for luxury sports cars with plans to build a new assembly line in Gaydon, Warwickshire, and take on an extra 400 staff. The company, owned by Ford, said it would produce a new, cheaper model of the sports car favoured by James Bond, executives and royals on the 900-acre Land-Rover test facility just off the M40.
fields.body:
Aston Martin yesterday rode the seemingly unstoppable crest of global demand for luxury sports cars with plans to build a new assembly line in Gaydon, Warwickshire, and take on an extra 400 staff. The company, owned by Ford, said it would produce a new, cheaper model of the sports car favoured by James Bond, executives and royals on the 900-acre Land-Rover test facility just off the M40.

Its plans to expand output underlined the stark contrast between the gloom which has descended upon volume car production in the UK and the boom in the market for luxury models - not only in Britain but around the world, with Bentley, Bugatti, Lamborghini, Porsche and MacLaren Mercedes planning new cars. "There's certainly a whole rash of new entrants into the luxury end of the market while the volume end is treading water and the top of the range end is going gung-ho,'' an Aston Martin spokesman said.

The company, founded in 1913, expects to produce a record 1,000 cars this year, including 900 of the DB7 model, and to raise output to 1500 next year. It sold just 46 cars in 1992 but hopes to overtake Ferrari's annual output of 3500 in three or four years. "If we are to remain successful, increase sales and generate revenue which will make us self-sufficient it is now crucial that we invest in a third product line,'' said Ulrich Bez, the chief executive.

The DB7 retails at around £90,000 and the new model, if Straford-on-Avon district council gives planning permission for the Gaydon expansion, will cost between £60,000 and £90,000. It will be on sale within four years. Aston Martin, which employs 600, said its assembly lines were too small for the new car; 90% of its output is sold in the UK, US and Europe, with the remaining 10% being sold in the Far East.

fields.headline: Seaside scrum, Italian style
fields.trailText: Italians are joyously if carefully unfolding towels on one of the longest and most beautiful coastlines in the world - with a ration of just 15cm of space each.
fields.body:
Italians are joyously if carefully unfolding towels on one of the longest and most beautiful coastlines in the world - with a ration of just 15cm of space each.

The room for lying on some beaches has shrivelled to the length of a pencil as 20m vacationers simultaneously try to get away from it all.

Expanses of Mediterranean and Adriatic sand have vanished beneath forests of suncreamed limbs which must twist to avoid hitting neighbours. "Being slim is not a mere cosmetic benefit but a requirement," said Italy Daily.

Congestion has forced football and volleyball to be abandoned in favour of electronic Playstation versions. Swimmers have found flippers to be unusable. From Liguria and Tuscany in the west, Sicily in the south and Rimini in the east, the average space is under 50cm and narrowing fast as the August 15 holiday approaches, according to Legambiente, Italy's environment watchdog.

Those left behind in near-deserted cities have not been deterred from joining 100-mile traffic jams to the seaside scrum, an August phenomenon which Italians accept as normal.

However this year's crush appears worse than ever. Some towns have drafted in beach police to maintain order, with mixed success. In Amalfi an off-duty policeman decided the price of a rental beach umbrella was extortionate and punched its owner, whose reply landed him in hospital. Prices for ice creams, watches, massages, deck chairs and drinks have soared and unlicensed peddlers have become more aggressive. Roberto Avogadro, mayor of Alassio on the Ligurian coast, calculated beach sellers approached the average visitor 107 times a day, or every four minutes during peak time.

"It's not healthy to have vacations all centred around one month," said Massimo Todisco, who monitors social trends in Milan, which like Rome was yesterday missing half its population, while Rimini swelled to become Italy's second most populous city.

Television pictures yesterday showed sunbathers struggling to escape shadows cast by those standing around them.

Hell, commented one newspaper, is other people.

webTitle: Comment: How polluting planes could pay

fields.headline: How polluting planes could pay
fields.standfirst: Punitive tax is not the best way to reduce airlines' output of greenhouse gases. Emissions-trading is a far more workable alternative
fields.trailText: Flying by plane produces more greenhouse gases for every kilometre each passenger travels than other forms of transport. Total emissions from aviation are small in comparison to those from private cars or power stations, but they are growing. As Ben Rogers complained on these pages on Monday, as well as carbon dioxide, planes emit nitrogen oxides, which may also be contributing to climate change. Even the water vapour trails that cut across our skies are, at that altitude, a greenhouse gas.
fields.body:
Flying by plane produces more greenhouse gases for every kilometre each passenger travels than other forms of transport. Total emissions from aviation are small in comparison to those from private cars or power stations, but they are growing. As Ben Rogers complained on these pages on Monday, as well as carbon dioxide, planes emit nitrogen oxides, which may also be contributing to climate change. Even the water vapour trails that cut across our skies are, at that altitude, a greenhouse gas.

UN scientists recommend greenhouse gas emissions need to be cut by at least 60% in the next 50 years in order to prevent dangerous climate change. But fuel used for aviation is exempt by international treaty from any form of tax. There are no regulations on efficiency of aircraft engines. Although there have been improvements in their fuel efficiency, these have been outstripped by growth in demand for air travel. Emissions from international flights are not even subject to the Kyoto protocol, which set legally binding targets for developed countries to cut greenhouse gases.

The climate, so to speak, is changing. The International Civil Aviation Organisation is due to report to the UN framework convention on climate change in autumn next year. The European Parliament is backing proposals for a charge on aviation emissions and the UK government is to set out its thoughts in a white paper within the next couple of years. So far, the airlines have offered voluntary improvements. The government will need to be wary. It is still thrashing out agreements with industrial firms wanting reductions in their obligations under the climate change levy. These were supposed to be finalised over a year ago. Besides, such voluntary initiatives suffer from lack of transparency. They cannot be enforced and create no incentives for companies to strive for improvements beyond the minimum.

The solution, Ben Rogers argued, has to be punitive taxes. There are precedents: most other forms of transport routinely pay either charges or taxes that take their pollution into account. What would the Automobile Association give for a version of the treaties that protect aviation from fuel taxation? In 1996, the Tory environment secretary, John Gummer, backed calls for a global aviation fuel tax to tackle climate change. This remains official policy. But there are problems. Such a tax would require international agreement, not just on the principle but on the mechanism by which such a tax could be put into effect and on the use to which any revenues were put. Given the sort of rows we have in the EU about allowing Brussels to exercise fiscal powers, it seems unlikely an aviation tax would ever be feasible worldwide.

A much better prospect is emissions-trading, for which the Kyoto protocol did create a legal framework. The concept is as follows. Countries or industries are allocated a certain number of permits to emit (pollute). The total number of permits is fixed and declines over a set period. The permits then become a tradeable commodity, so if it is cheaper to reduce emissions in a part of the economy other than their own, companies can buy permits from there. The price of permits should reflect the lowest cost of delivering cuts in emissions across all those involved. The aim is to give governments maximum certainty over total emissions and give business maximum flexibility in delivering the reductions.

Carbon dioxide emissions from international flights are so far not controlled by Kyoto, so as things stand could not participate in emissions trading. Domestic flying could. Emissions from a flight from, say, London to Edinburgh are part of the UK's total allocation of emissions, which are subject to the legally binding reduction target. Emissions from a flight between London and New York do not count in either UK or American totals. This anomaly has to be addressed. If international aviation were included in the Kyoto totals, it would be subject to a 5% reduction from 1990 levels by between 2008 and 2012.

Of course, such an allocation to international aviation would almost certainly not cover requirements if the projections for passenger growth are to be believed. This is where trading comes in. If the airlines wanted to emit more than their allocated permits allowed, extra would have to be purchased from elsewhere. The airlines (and therefore air passengers) would collectively pay for emissions-reduction somewhere else in the world to compensate for those created by flying. This would implement the polluter-pays principle in such a way that those responsible for pollution paid only the lowest reasonable price. Getting agreement along these lines would take time but would be easier than attempting to legislate a global aviation tax. The UK could even lead the way by including domestic aviation in its own emissions-trading scheme, which is now under construction. To avoid unfair treatment, airlines that accepted fixed permit allocations and participated in emissions-trading could be exempted from air passenger duty for domestic flights.

All sectors will have to do their bit to ameliorate climate change - including the airlines that fly between nations and the passengers who use them.

Chris Hewett is at the Institute for Public Policy Research. His report, "Plane Trading: policies for reducing the climate change effects of international aviation", is out on Monday.

fields.headline: Clintons steal Gore's show
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: What should have been a starry coronation for Al Gore at next week's Democratic convention in Los Angeles is turning into a competition with Bill and Hillary Clinton for the munificence of Hollywood, as the president and his wife seek funding for their own ambitions, to the dismay of the vice-president's camp.
fields.body:
What should have been a starry coronation for Al Gore at next week's Democratic convention in Los Angeles is turning into a competition with Bill and Hillary Clinton for the munificence of Hollywood, as the president and his wife seek funding for their own ambitions, to the dismay of the vice-president's camp.

Los Angeles and its film business have always been a happy hunting ground for Democrats and everyone from Whoopi Goldberg and Steven Spielberg to Barbra Streisand and Jack Lemmon have associated themselves with this year's convention. The Democrats have traditionally used the convention and what star power it attracts for vital fundraising.

Now it appears that the Clintons will be heading home from LA next week with more funds raised for Hillary's senate bid in New York and Bill's ambitions for a $125m (£83m) memorial library in Little Rock, Arkansas, than Mr Gore will be able to put into his own campaign bank. At the centre of the behind the scenes row is a huge fundraiser to be held on Saturday night at a private LA estate. The estimated $4m the event will probably raise will go exclusively towards Hillary Clinton's senatorial campaign. Among the performers are Cher, Diana Ross, Stevie Wonder and Michael Bolton and there will be speeches from John Travolta, Goldie Hawn, new father Michael Douglas and Gregory Peck. Around 1,400 guests will attend, with chequebooks ready. On Sunday Barbra Streisand will hold a fundraising brunch for Bill Clinton's presidential library at her Malibu home, an event likely to raise around $1m.

Mr Gore will have his own big fundraiser at the Shrine auditorium next Thursday with Barbra Streisand singing three songs and performances from Boyz II Men, Gladys Knight and Whoopi Goldberg but it is unlikely that the event will garner anything like as much as Hillary's gala. Some of the tickets in the 6,000-seater auditorium are still unsold and organisers estimate that they will raise at best $2.5m for the Gore-Lieberman ticket.

The two big Clinton fund-raisers and the fact that the Clintons will spend longer in Los Angeles than the Gores are a blow to Mr Gore's hopes of finally throwing off the Clinton shadow. "It's embarrassing for the Gores to have this huge event for the president that will raise money for Hillary,'' a Democratic strategist told the New York Times. "This convention is not about her."

fields.headline: Violence hits Kosovo politicians
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The UN authorities in Kosovo are investigating a series of sometimes fatal attacks on members of the province's biggest political party, the Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK), in the run-up to local elections in October.
fields.body:
The UN authorities in Kosovo are investigating a series of sometimes fatal attacks on members of the province's biggest political party, the Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK), in the run-up to local elections in October.

They have set up an investigative committee with the power to impose fines and ban politicians from standing for election for six years.

The latest victim is Ganimete Salihu, 54, who died in an explosion in her home in town of Dragash on Wednesday. Her husband Avni Salihu, head of the town's department of sport and culture, was injured.

A week ago the charred remains of an LDK politician and prominent lawyer, Shaban Manaj, were found in a northern village where he had been reported kidnapped a fortnight earlier. Two other party members were shot and injured in separate incidents at the beginning of the month. Opinion polls show that the LDK is likely to win the elections, organised by the UN. Its main rival is the Democratic Party of Kosovo, led by Hashim Thaci, formerly the political leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army.

Senior LDK members say they are not being adequately protected by the UN. According to a report by the peacekeeping force, K-For, party members want to be allowed to carry weapons. Permission has been denied.

The UN has not decided whether the attacks are political. A spokeswoman said: "Clearly it is a very delicate situation, and that is why we have set up this new committee to establish whether there is a pattern to these attacks, or whether the same people are behind them."

fields.headline: KS Biomedix
fields.trailText: Kim Tan, Britain's wealthiest biotech entrepreneur, rushed out a statement yesterday denying reports that he was selling his £200m stake in KS Biomedix - the drug development company he has built around the use of sheep antibodies.
fields.body:
Kim Tan, Britain's wealthiest biotech entrepreneur, rushed out a statement yesterday denying reports that he was selling his £200m stake in KS Biomedix - the drug development company he has built around the use of sheep antibodies.

The Malaysian-born businessman insisted there was no truth in suggestions that he had found a buyer willing to pay £10 a share for his 64% stake. The news sent the shares down 15p to 645p. There is little reason to give credence to the rumours. Dr Tan is notoriously frugal - despite a paper fortune of more than £350m, he still potters around Surrey in an eight-year-old Volkswagen Golf. He is unlikely to have a sudden yearning for cash.

The tittle-tattle has probably been triggered by his recent decision to become non-executive chairman, giving up day to day control. This has certainly spooked some analysts, who point out that the company's technology is largely his personal work. KS Biomedix's science is promising. It takes sheep and injects them with antigens - which produce disease- attacking antibodies. The company has found that antibodies from the animals are much more selective, and better able to bind with cancer tumours, than antibodies produced by human beings or by mice. This delivery technique could have huge potential for future cancer treatments but is still in its infancy.

KS Biomedix has two more advanced products, both for arthritis, which have completed phase two clinical trials. Enthusiasm about the company has become a little excessive. The shares have seen a sixfold rise in two years, valuing the business at £313m. The company could make a profit for the first time this year if it can find development partners willing to make up-front payments. However, serious revenue is a good few years away and as sheep antibodies are an unproven technology, the valuation is too high.

webTitle: New book claims Turin Shroud may be genuine after all

fields.headline: Riddle of the relic
fields.standfirst: New book claims Turin Shroud may be genuine after all
fields.trailText: The centuries-old debate over the authenticity of the Turin Shroud, one of the most controversial religious relics in the world, is about to be revived 12 years after scientists thought they had proved it to be a mediaeval forgery.
fields.body:
The centuries-old debate over the authenticity of the Turin Shroud, one of the most controversial religious relics in the world, is about to be revived 12 years after scientists thought they had proved it to be a mediaeval forgery.

A new book claims that the 4.2 metre (14ft) length of linen in which the body of Christ was supposedly wrapped after his crucifixion bears the seeds of plants once growing in Palestine and fragments of wood, blood, muscle tissue and even nasal stains.

If the cloth did once wrap the body of Christ, we may now know what his blood group was: AB, rare among Europeans but much more common among Middle Eastern Jews.

The authors argue that the shadowy negative image of a man's body, bearing wounds similar to those recorded in the Gospels, is much more sophisticated than a 13th century forger could have accomplished.

The Turin Shroud: the Illustrated Evidence, by the veteran British shroudologist Ian Wilson and an American Jewish photographer, Barrie Schwortz, argues that the Catholic church should allow new tests.

The authors, drawing on the evidence of scientists from around the world, claim that the snippets of cloth used in carbon dating tests in the 1980s were affected by a layer of microbiological contamination, possibly because they came from the edge of the shroud, which was often handled by mediaeval bishops.

The claims and counterclaims have had little effect on pilgrims, who are expected to turn up in their thousands this weekend when the shroud goes on display in Turin cathedral for two months as part of the Catholic church's millennium celebrations.

Although venerated for centuries, the possibility of authentication did not emerge until 1898, when it was first photographed, and again in the 1930s, when negatives showed the startling image of a naked, bearded man. The book claims that the image is contorted, as if in rigor mortis, and has a foreshortened appearance of a sort that mediaeval artists would not have been able to copy.

fields.headline: Poland's president not a spy
fields.trailText: The Polish president, Aleksander Kwasniewski, was cleared by a Warsaw court yesterday of collaborating with the old communist regime's secret police, ending a two-week trial which could have prevented him standing for re-election.
fields.body:
The Polish president, Aleksander Kwasniewski, was cleared by a Warsaw court yesterday of collaborating with the old communist regime's secret police, ending a two-week trial which could have prevented him standing for re-election.

The trial resulted from a law which demands that officials declare past links to the secret police. But when the charismatic president was called to the dock after potentially incriminating documents came to light, many said the law had gone too far.

A special vetting court was called to deliver its verdict on documents which claimed that Mr Kwasniewski, a former journalist, was agent 72204, codenamed "Alek", who worked at the newspaper Zycie Warszawy.

Mr Kwasniewski, a former sports minister, has had to fight to clear his name at the same time as his political rival, Lech Walesa.

The former president and founder of the anti-communist movement, Solidarity, is being accused of collaborating with the secret police (SB). Mr Walesa, who is also running in October's elections, faces a verdict on his court case today.

But both Mr Walesa and Mr Kwasniewski, who enjoys almost 80% support, claim that political opponents are attempting to smear them in the run up to the elections.

Witnesses at the trial, most of whom were former SB agents, all denied that Mr Kwasniewski had collaborated. After the verdict Mr Kwasniewski appeared strained but relieved.

"I'm very glad," he said. "Truth and justice has won." But he warned that he would pursue those responsible for "manipulating the evidence".

fields.headline: The interest generator
fields.trailText: Innogy and Regenesys. No, they are not hot biotech start-ups or treatments for life-threatening diseases but the name of a company and the revolutionary technology that yesterday drove National Power up the FTSE 100 performance table.
fields.body:
Innogy and Regenesys. No, they are not hot biotech start-ups or treatments for life-threatening diseases but the name of a company and the revolutionary technology that yesterday drove National Power up the FTSE 100 performance table.

Innogy is of course the strange new name for the soon to be demerged - on October 2 - domestic operations of National Power. Regenesys is the name of its bulk energy storage system which could radically transform the production and trading of electricity throughout the world. Yesterday CSFB, the investment bank that will be Innogy's broker post-demerger, was getting very excited about its prospects.

Put at its most simple, Regenesys is a huge rechargeable battery that potentially solves one of the problems facing the industry - that electricity cannot be stored. Not only can the battery be charged from an existing network but it can also discharge electricity when demand is high or when a network fails. According to CSFB, the market is failing to reflect its value in National Power's share price. It reckons Regenesys is worth at least 93p a share. Together with Innogy's core business (195p) and its international assets (312p share), CSFB reckons National Power is its present form is worth 600p per share, as opposed to last night's closing price of 490p, up 18p. Needless to say, CSFB thinks the stock is a screaming "buy".

 The FTSE 100 index closed the session 26.7 points lower at 6,387.3, undermined by weakness in the leading drug stocks. They tumbled after an American appeals court reversed an earlier ruling and stripped Eli Lilly's blockbuster drug Prozac of three years' worth of patent protection. SmithKline Beecham was judged by analysts to be the most affected by the news. Not only will its leading anti-depressant drug Paxil be exposed to cheap, generic Prozac earlier than expected, but uncertainty will now surround its second patent on antibiotic Augmentin. Shares in SmithKline Beecham ended the day 6p weaker at 859p, while merger partner Glaxo Wellcome dropped 32p to £18.94 in sympathy and AstraZeneca retreated 51p to £29.00.  Elsewhere, bank stocks - Wednesday's star performers - were under pressure as investors booked some profits and decided that the proposed marriage of Woolwich - which was 3.5p weaker at 337.5p - and Barclays, down 34p to £15.81, did not necessarily mean open season had been declared. Investors singled out Alliance & Leicester - down 18.5p to 511.5p - as being too small to be of any interest to the larger players. The takeover favourite now appears to be the larger Abbey National, up 1p to 755p. Meanwhile the "arbs" - the professional punters who try to take bets on differences between share prices - had their fingers crossed that nothing would happen to make the deal between Woolwich and Barclays Bank fall apart at the last minute. In great quantities they have been ploughing into Woolwich stock and getting out of Barclays as this is proving the cheapest way to get a slice of the Barclays action.

 If the deal fails a number of major hedge funds would be likely to suffer. One stock already in pain was internet service provider Freeserve, which fell 13.75p to 276p after report that German firm T-Online is no longer interested in buying it. The news dragged Dixons, which retains an 80.1% stake in Freeserve, 8p lower to 260.5p.

 Takeover speculation continued around business services group Hays, up 9p to 401p, and Marconi, 33p up at £10.88, with Cisco Systems the name being touted by dealers. Meanwhile over on Aim, website services company Totally surged by 6.5p to 28p after it admitted that it was in talks that could lead to a substantial acquisition.

 From Dublin to Tripoli It may have gone unnoticed but Bula Resources, the Dublin based oil and gas exploration and production company, has a new chief executive. The appointment of John Hogan, most recently executive director and chief operating officer of Lasmo, is a seen as coup for Bula, perhaps best know for regular appearances on internet bulletin boards. According to the City gossips, Mr Hogan is expected to use his experience of the international oil industry to help fast track Bula's negotiations in its target exploration and development areas of Libya and Iraq, and discussions with potential strategic partners. Bula has been in talks with oil group Oilinvest since last October. Speculation was that Bula's discussions in Libya are going so well that it has taken 30,000 square feet of office space in Tripoli. Bula shares, a high risk, high reward investment, closed down 0.25p last night at 4.25p.

fields.headline: We've got your number
fields.standfirst: Crop circles... pyramids... aliens... they all make sense if you employ a bit of basic maths. At least that's what tonight's ALT-TV is trying to tell us. Richard Vine (D grade at O-level) belatedly discovers the joy of figures
fields.trailText: Crop circles... pyramids... aliens... they all make sense if you employ a bit of basic maths. At least that's what tonight's ALT-TV is trying to tell us. Richard Vine (D grade at O-level) belatedly discovers the joy of figures.
fields.body:
I am not a number, but I am a confused man. Despite owning several calculators, I have never been able to come to grips with maths. Piles of loose change multiply in my wallet as I avoid the perils of quick addition at checkouts. Credit card bills are a source of mystery, tempting mental excursions into the negative zone ("£1,000 credit - so, that's £1,000 left?"). In short, as a D at O-level testifies, I am several decimal places short of innumerate.

But this doesn't mean that the strings of ones and zeros that fill the world hold no interest. Far from it. I love being blinded by the appliance of counting, seeing patterns emerge from the Fibonacci sequence, discovering that there is an easy(ish) equation lying at the heart of fractals that makes all those trippy graphics on student bedsit posters so easy to create, hearing about the golden section that divides classic paintings into neat pieces. Just don't ask me to do the sums.

There's something so appealing about the cold reality of maths, the essential factness of 1+1=2 that resonates where words can't. When Graham Hancock trotted out the magic date of 10,500BC and tied it all up with pi after measuring a few pyramids around the world during his Mysteries Of Lost Empires series, I was with him all the way. Pi?

Precession? Ancient Egyptian maths? Well, that proves everything. The kooky numerology conspiracies trotted out in Umberto Eco's Foucault's Pendulum, the Wu-Tang Clan's albums and the lo-fi maths thriller Pi ("mathematics is the language of the universe") resonate every time I refuse to take part in the evil research programme known as the supermarket loyalty card.

So it's reassuring to come across Channel 4's Digit. Showing as part of the ALT-TV series - which for the past few weeks has been sneaking interesting, oddball viewing into Friday's early evening viewing alongside Brookie and Country House, instead of being tucked away where you'd expect to find it in the wee hours - tonight's show looks at the power numbers have on our lives. With guests ranging from Astronomer Royal Sir Martin Rees, occultist Nigel Bourne and Jo Guest ("34-22-36 - it's like a prison number") to Director of Maths Year 2000 Barry Lewis ("I make friends with numbers regularly") and George Martin of Gala Bingo, this is exactly the sort of thing to confirm my lingering suspicion that I should have tried to stop nodding off in maths class.

The guests take turns to point out the effects that numbers have on our lives, from the habitual bingo players who insist on sitting in the same "lucky" numbered chair every week before checking off their "lucky" numbers, and the DNA sequencing project which has reduced our chemical make-up to binary code, through to the way we've decided as a culture that seven is a "good" number, while 13 is to be avoided at all costs (something to do with the cycle of the moon, according to Nigel Bourne).

John Lundberg, a crop circle expert, describes how a fairly unspectacular circle, stomped in a field in the middle of the night by some friends of his, was nevertheless responsible for some spooky effects: with three circles each containing three others (666, geddit?), people who walked inside them reported migraines and feeling sick. And then they noticed that the Ordnance Survey map reference was, yes, 666...

In a charitable nod to the innumerate, maths historian Jeremy Gray admits there are times when numbers aren't that useful: "I love you 9.5 today... It doesn't make any sense." As you might expect, it's Astronomer Royal Sir Martin Rees who provides the most crucial bits of information. He's managed to narrow down all the important numbers of the universe to just six, which seems like a reasonable thing to do.

Apparently, omega is a cosmic number which assumes the amount of material in the universe, while n=1036 measures the strength of gravity compared with the forces which hold atoms together. The strength of atomic nuclei is 0.007, showing how all atoms on earth are made, and nothing whatsoever to do with Sean Connery. Lambda assumes the energy constant of empty space (still with me?), Q=1/100.000 is the seed of all cosmic structures, and D=3 represents the three dimensions of space.

With an expectant smile on his face (does he know something we don't?), Sir Rees says that if we ever make contact with an alien race, we will be able to communicate with them using these six numbers, as they are such universal truths that the aliens will have figured them out as well, and so we'll have a basis from which to start building a common culture. Well, some of us will. Maybe it's time to go back to school.

fields.headline: Guatemala admits killings
fields.trailText:
The Guatemalan government has for the first time admitted its responsibility for some of the tens of thousands of killings and kidnappings committed during the country's 36-year civil war.

"We have recognised that the state committed human rights abuses. We are doing this today so that the dramatic history we have lived through isn't repeated," President Alfonso Portillo said on Wednesday.
fields.body:
The Guatemalan government has for the first time admitted its responsibility for some of the tens of thousands of killings and kidnappings committed during the country's 36-year civil war.

"We have recognised that the state committed human rights abuses. We are doing this today so that the dramatic history we have lived through isn't repeated," President Alfonso Portillo said on Wednesday.

Among the cases are two army massacres, in which more than 300 peasants were killed.

An attempt by President Portillo to establish a national day for human rights victims was blocked earlier this year by congressmen from his own rightwing party, led by the former president, General Efrain Rios Montt, whose 1982-83 regime oversaw some of the worst abuses of the conflict that left an estimated 200,000 dead.

fields.headline: Don't lose your head
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: Secret History: The Duchess And The Headless Man
fields.body:
"I was temporarily over-excited by the sight of the Duchess of Atholl," said Norris contritely in Coronation Street. Norris, I should mention, is a trainspotter. But this was very much the effect that the Duchess of Argyll always had on susceptible gentlemen.

I remember seeing her towards the end of her life in Piccadilly. Outside the Ritz, naturally. She was so beautifully groomed, she seemed to be cut out with scissors. Her hair was so smoothly sculpted, I suspected a wig. Her twig-thin legs seemed fit to snap. She clutched a black poodle, Alphonse, protectively.

She looked rather as the Duchess of Windsor did in distracted old age. A steady stream of metal flowed down Piccadilly. She hesitated on the pavement as if expecting it to part and let her pass.

There was a time when the mighty roar of London's traffic would have stopped for Margaret Sweeny. She used to be, as Cole Porter indicated with his tongue in his cheek, a big cheese: "You're the nimble tread Of the feet of Fred Astaire You're Mussolini You're Mrs Sweeny You're Camembert." How much do I have to tell you? How much can I assume you know?

Margaret Whigham was the most celebrated deb of 1930. Aly Khan was instantly smitten. The depression howled around but, in her charmed social circle, she said, "It was heaven, undiluted heaven. Not a serious thought in my head. Featherbrained. Blissful." In a hundred photos she rises like Venus from a foam of tulle or ostrich feathers or arctic fox. A 30s Venus with a tiny, Cupid's bow mouth, lipsticked crimson. In her most notorious photographs she wears only her triple-string pearl necklace. These were taken on a Polaroid camera while she was performing oral sex on a man whose face was not in the picture. With a head, they are pornography. Without, they are a puzzle. Nearly half a century on, Secret History: The Duchess And The Headless Man (C4) believes it has the answer.

These pictures were the most sensational evidence when her second husband, the Duke of Argyll, sued for divorce. He had evidently sold his story to a sensational Sunday, and the evidence of their reporter, Ken Gardner, came like a lungful of fresh air in a perfumed room. "The Duke was a right old toff," said Ken. "He was dour. Not very attractive. I remember, when he gave evidence, the atmosphere changed from the solemn to the hilarious." At the rear of the court the Duchess was shaking with silent laughter. "All eyes were on her. Her head was bowed over and buried in her hands and the brim of her hat was flapping up and down like a raven's wing. We all felt the judge must have led a very sheltered sort of life because he was clearly shocked by the evidence that was being given. There he was, very straight-faced, looking down from his throne, and there was the rest of the court, stifling laughter. It was sheer pantomime." And then, as Browning put it in My Last Duchess, "all smiling stopped".

The judge found for the Duke and delivered what he himself called harsh strictures on the Duchess. "Harsh strictures" sounds all the more abrasive when repeated outside the court with rolling Scottish r's. The Duchess's chief failing seems to me an inability even to spell perjury. Fighting as dirty as the Duke, she concocted several plots, which collapsed in expensive slander suits. Her deep, treacle-well of money was beginning to run dry. To do her justice, she never, to her lonely and impoverished dying day, revealed the name of the headless man. Or men.

When Duncan Sandys, the Minister of Defence, came under suspicion, Lord Denning looked into the matter for the Macmillan government, already shaken by the Profumo scandal. He concluded confidentially that the headless man was Douglas Fairbanks jnr, but a prudent punter might risk an each-way flutter on Duncan Sandys. As the Duchess once said teasingly, "Of course, sweetie, the only Polaroid in the country at the time had been lent to the Ministry of Defence."

Sandys mutated into Lord Duncan-Sandys. I last saw Douglas Fairbanks at a royal wedding. The duchess, however, went down in social and financial flames. You might say she behaved like a perfect gentleman.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Two Mandolins/The format of Straw Poll
fields.body:
Raffaele Calace joined his father's Neapolitan workshop in 1877, aged 14. Within years he was astounding audiences with his extraordinary virtuosity on the mandolin, not previously held in great esteem. By the time he died at 71 in 1934, he had a worldwide reputation as a performer, had written a six-volume manual teaching previously unknown techniques, composed more than 200 mandolin works, and run a business producing some of the world's finest instruments. Alison Stephens remembers him in The Two Mandolins (11.0am, Radio 4).

The format of Straw Poll (8.0pm, Radio 4) is pretty much the same as the regular programme in this Friday slot. With Any Questions taking its summer break, Nick Clarke (pictured) now presides over four panellists facing an invited audience in different parts of the country. So far, so familiar, except this team is restricted to one subject a week. The first is whether winning elections has become more important than political philosophy.

webTitle: Lauder to shift RSL's base to London

fields.headline: Lauder to shift RSL's base to London
fields.trailText: Ronald Lauder, scion of the cosmetics dynasty Estée Lauder, is planning to shift the head office of his telecoms group RSL Communications to London, and may consider a local listing of the company.
fields.body:
Ronald Lauder, scion of the cosmetics dynasty Estée Lauder, is planning to shift the head office of his telecoms group RSL Communications to London, and may consider a local listing of the company.

The Nasdaq-listed telecoms firm, with a market capitalisation of $285m, said the move was forced by the growing importance of Europe to its revenues and profits. Paul Domorski, president of BT's Syncordia Solutions division, will start work as RSL's new chief executive based in London on August 21. Current chief executive and co-founder Itzhak Fisher will remain as a consultant and member of the company's board.

RSL is the UK's fourth largest international carrier of voice traffic - according to telecoms regulator Oftel - after BT, Cable & Wireless and MCI WorldCom. It also has plans to establish 14 web-hosting and data centres throughout the UK to provide data, software and internet services to its clients - who include TNT, Sega, the Bank of England and Walkers Snack Foods. Europe accounts for two-thirds of the company's turnover, which amounted to $390.5m during the second quarter. The group's earnings slipped into the red during the same period, however.

Ronald Lauder is chairman of RSL, owning 28% of the company and controlling 57% of the group's voting stock. Gary Sheppard, the group business director of RSL, said the move would allow management to respond faster to clients' needs and the market changes in Europe. webTitle: Hungary lays on pit stop for grand prix punters

fields.headline: Hungary lays on pit stop for grand prix punters
fields.trailText: Hungary's first legal open-air brothel opened yesterday in woodland next to the Formula 1 race track outside Budapest: a row of 20 hardboard booths, each with a red carpet, a bed covered with a grey blanket, and a neat stack of four toilet rolls. At the end of the row are portable toilets and showers.
fields.body:
Hungary's first legal open-air brothel opened yesterday in woodland next to the Formula 1 race track outside Budapest: a row of 20 hardboard booths, each with a red carpet, a bed covered with a grey blanket, and a neat stack of four toilet rolls. At the end of the row are portable toilets and showers.

The sign outside says "Erotik Camping". Officially it is a "tolerance zone".

The anti-mafia law passed by the Hungarian parliament in December instructs local authorities to declare red-light areas wherever "mass prostitution" exists.

The village council of Mogyorod, nine miles from Budapest, is the first to take advantage of it, albeit only for the five days of the race meeting.

A quarter of a million visitors are expected, more than half of them foreigners. Estimates of the number of prostitutes on hand range from 100 to 500.

As 4pm approached there was a tense atmosphere at the entrance to the site. Well-built young men in black T-shirts and dark glasses from a security firm called Iron Dwarf tried to bustle a crowd of journalists from the scene.

Out of nowhere a line of girls with variously coloured shoulder-length hair, wearing pedal pushers or short skirts, was marshalled into the area by more men with mobile phones.

On the hour a woman stretched a tricoloured Hungarian ribbon across the entrance. But there were no scissors, no official opening and, for the first hour at least, no clients either.

"To tell you the truth this is not what they led us to expect," said a 21-year-old girl from Budapest, who explained that she normally worked as "a model" in Budapest.

She wore a long black skirt, a white T-shirt, and golden earrings, and her brown eyes looked deeply vulnerable.

"I thought I would come for fun, for a joke. I used to think I enjoyed this work, but now I'm not sure."

A session in a booth would cost 300 German marks (£100), she said. "We were expecting normal surroundings, and normal people. We all feel desperate."

The mayor's office in Mogyorod is a single storey, pale yellow 19th-century building with a gateway through which horses would once have driven with their carriages.

The mayor, Sandor Toth, used to be a member of the Independent Smallholders party, but won the post in 1998 as an independent.

"People here do not fear the grand prix," he said, "they look forward to it - as to the silence which follows."

The idea of the tolerance zone came originally from the interior ministry in Budapest, he said. In past years open prostitution in the streets and alleys of the village had grown to scandalous proportions.

To deal with it the local police proposed, and his council accepted by 10 votes to two, the idea of putting aside 1.6 hectares (4 acres) of young acacia forest bordering the track.

Budapest entrepreneurs rapidly appeared to lay on the booths - and the girls.

Most local people appear to be in favour.

"The zone is a necessary evil," said Erzsebet Juhasz, 49, an accountant, who lives on the main street. She has 17 visitors - mostly Dutch - camping in her garden or staying in her house. In previous years the prostitutes annoyed her guests, so she supports the new arrangement.

"I'm against all prostitution," said another woman, with a "rooms to let" sign near the main gate. "But I'm glad they've put them all away this year, out of sight."

fields.headline: Cable TV firm's losses at $1bn
fields.trailText: Losses at NTL, the cable television and telephony group, widened to more than $1bn (£666m) in the first half of the year as the cost of introducing digital services and investment in the internet began to bite. The company said it has signed up 230,000 digital TV customers so far and is on track for 500,000 by year end - although most of those have been acquired through its takeover of the Cable & Wireless Communications residential business.
fields.body:
Losses at NTL, the cable television and telephony group, widened to more than $1bn (£666m) in the first half of the year as the cost of introducing digital services and investment in the internet began to bite. The company said it has signed up 230,000 digital TV customers so far and is on track for 500,000 by year end - although most of those have been acquired through its takeover of the Cable & Wireless Communications residential business.

John Gregg, NTL's finance director, said the company had warehoused enough of the settop boxes needed to unscramble the digital signal to avoid the problems experienced by rival Telewest. The shortage of a key component in the boxes has forced Telewest to suspend marketing its service, causing its share price to nosedive. "We have no problems with set-top boxes or with the roll out of digital services," Mr Gregg said.

NTL is still a long way behind BSkyB which has converted 80% of its 4.5m strong customer base to digital. But Mr Gregg played down suggestions that a merger with Telewest to counter BSkyB is on the cards. He said NTL, which has just under 2m cable television customers in Britain and Ireland was "very comfortable" with its assets. Revenues increased from $674m to $1.2bn in the six months to the beginning of July while the losses grew from $607m.

webTitle: IMF urges Ireland to restrain soaring economy

fields.headline: IMF urges Ireland to restrain soaring economy
fields.trailText: The world's top financial authority, the International Monetary Fund, yesterday urged the Irish government to tighten fiscal policy to prevent its booming economy from overheating. While praising the country's "spectacular economic performance" and acknowledging that membership of the eurozone conveyed "permanent economic benefits", the IMF said there was a short-term danger that average growth of around 8% a year since 1994 would lead to higher inflation.
fields.body:
The world's top financial authority, the International Monetary Fund, yesterday urged the Irish government to tighten fiscal policy to prevent its booming economy from overheating. While praising the country's "spectacular economic performance" and acknowledging that membership of the eurozone conveyed "permanent economic benefits", the IMF said there was a short-term danger that average growth of around 8% a year since 1994 would lead to higher inflation.

Given that interest rates, now set on a euro area-wide basis, were too low for the country's cyclical position, the Washington-based organisation called on Bertie Ahern's government to use alternative instruments to damp down demand. These included tightening fiscal policy, ensuring public sector pay deals were strictly adhered to and doing more to restrain the run-away property market.

The fund's report had been keenly awaited in the UK, where Ireland's experience inside the eurozone is seen as a test case for Britain's membership. While sceptics say the country's plight points to the folly of surrendering control of monetary policy to the European central bank, europhiles say membership of the eurozone has been a key ingredient in Ireland's economic success. The IMF, which said that full membership of the single European market had been key to attracting foreign investment and promoting efficiency, appears to provide ammunition for both sides of the debate.

Kitty Ussher, chief economist of Britain in Europe, the pro-EMU lobby group, said the IMF report exploded the myth that Ireland was a failing economy. She said: "The anti-Europeans in Britain should accept the truth about Ireland rather than attempting to misrepresent it for their own ideological purposes." Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, the anti-EMU lobby group, said: "The report does point to the dangers of losing control of your own interest rates. That plainly has contributed to the inflation problem in Ireland and Britain would be in a very uncomfortable position had it joined EMU last year."

fields.headline: Celebrities arrested for child porn
fields.trailText: The South African government has ordered a crackdown on child pornography following the arrest of two Afrikaans-speaking television celebrities for possession of large amounts of "repulsive" material.
fields.body:
The South African government has ordered a crackdown on child pornography following the arrest of two Afrikaans-speaking television celebrities for possession of large amounts of "repulsive" material.

The arrests and two other shocking cases this week - a murder charge against a convicted sex offender who escaped from a mental hospital and then raped and killed his 15-year-old niece, and the conviction of parents who prostituted their three young daughters for as little as 50p - has focused attention on inadequate laws and policing in child sex abuses cases.

If, as expected, the arrested television personalities are charged, the police say theirs would be the first child pornography prosecutions in South Africa. The two men, a leading film critic and broadcaster, Leon van Nierop, 47, and his companion, Tascoe Luc de Reuck, 27, were detained after allegedly importing child pornography ordered on the internet. The police called the material found in their home as a "large collection of shocking, hardcore child pornography presented in its most extreme form".

They said they are also investigating other celebrities, a high profile judge and a senior lawyer on similar charges. Child abuse officers are probing allegations that some of the same people were involved in luring schoolboys to participate in sex films.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A piece on the restoration of the Great Western hotel at Paddington station (page 10 yesterday) said that a drastic remodelling by British Rail in the 1930s had destroyed much period detail. The company involved was actually the Great Western Railway. Not until 1948 was British Railways founded (it, too, altered the hotel extensively).

A piece on the restoration of the Great Western hotel at Paddington station (page 10 yesterday) said that a drastic remodelling by British Rail in the 1930s had destroyed much period detail. The company involved was actually the Great Western Railway. Not until 1948 was British Railways founded (it, too, altered the hotel extensively).

Real Lives, page 4, G2, on August 9, wondered what high-priced football import Christian Karembeu and the glamorous "girlfriend" he was bringing with him - Wonderbra model Adriana Sklenarikova - would make of their new home, Middlesbrough. Ms Sklenarikova is the player's wife.

The John Lewis Partnership was reported on page 22, Finance, yesterday as having stopped printing weekly sales figures in its staff magazine, for fear these told competitors too much. In fact, most of the data pages will go on. It is the performance details of all the group's 62 central department-store buyers that are being eliminated.

Maurice Kinn, who owned and published the New Musical Express from 1952-63, died last week aged 66, rather than 76 as reported in some editions of the Obituaries, page 20, yesterday.

Lawyers for Middlesbrough's suspended "zero tolerance" police chief, Ray Mallon, have written to the home secretary conveying their client's accusations that senior colleagues worked to pervert the course of justice, we reported on page 8, August 9. But the letter is likely to be referred not to Cleveland police for a possible inquiry, as we said, but to the Cleveland Police Authority.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Brinagar bomb blast kills 10

A bomb killed 10 people and wounded 24 in Kashmir yesterday as a guerrilla group which offered peace talks with New Delhi last week returned to violence.

Hizbul Mojahedin, which ended an unprecedented ceasefire earlier this week, claimed responsibility for the bomb in Srinagar. A government official said eight police officers, a photojournalist and a shopkeeper died in the blast.

Politician held at ETA protest

A Basque politician linked to ETA was arrested after scuffling with the police in Pamplona yesterday as protesters holding a vigil for the separatist movement's latest supposed victim screamed "murderers" and "scum".

Uganda rebels attack refugees

Rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army attacked a refugee camp in northern Uganda, killing two people, and eight died when a bus hit a mine elsewhere in the north, an Italian-based missionary news service said yesterday.

First woman PM bows out

Sirimavo Bandaranaike, who became the world's first woman prime minister when she was elected head of Sri Lanka's government 40 years ago, retired yesterday at the age of 84. She is the mother of President Chandrika Kumaratunga.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Country House/Big Brother/Room 101/Badger
fields.body:
Country House 8pm, BBC2 PG Wodehouse once noted that his novels were "a sort of musical comedy without the music". Nonsense. Judging by the eccentricity on display at Woburn Abbey, Pelham Grenville was practically a social realist. Tonight, young Lord Howland tries his best to find a rave site for the local Exodus community, much to Lord and Lady Tavistock's dismay. Lady T, in particular, has trouble with the idea of a party where nobody pays to get in. "What is the incentive to arrange them?" she asks. The indomitable Lady T is also unconvinced about her newly-built coffin, crafted on the estate. Commenting on its lack of "solidity", she decides: "I'd put that in a nursery."

Big Brother 8.30pm & 11.05pm, Channel 4 Another week of life in the house, another eviction. Depending on your perspective, Channel 4's experiment in Truman Show-like fly-on-the-wall TV is either inanely compelling or simply inane - qualities you'd more usually associate with daytime telly than a series that's been touted as revolutionary.

Room 101 9pm, BBC2 Former England manager Terry Venables chooses his pet hates, and enjoys himself as he nominates "uninformed journalists", people who disguise their background, football club chairmen and cyclists. But as ever, it's host Paul Merton who's the true star of the show. Looking back at when El Tel-managed Gary Lineker, the footballer turned They Think It's All Over panellist, Merton asks: "Were you aware he was such a funny man?"

Badger 9.30pm, BBC1 The eco-friendly cop drama starring Jerome Flynn (Soldier, Soldier) might have migrated from Sunday to Friday, but that doesn't mean it's got any better. Tonight, McCabe and Claire (Rebecca Lacey) hunt for the organisers of a cock-fighting syndicate. A series where characterisation comes a poor second to contriving a plot that involves cute critters.

webTitle: Reform party split by right's takeover

fields.headline: Reform party split by right's takeover
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The Reform party began  its convention in Long Beach yesterday in the middle of a battle for the presidential nomination that could end in court, as two factions battle for control of the US's most successful third party in decades.
fields.body:
The Reform party began its convention in Long Beach yesterday in the middle of a battle for the presidential nomination that could end in court, as two factions battle for control of the US's most successful third party in decades.

The farcical situation is the result of a split between supporters of Pat Buchanan, the rightwing former Republican who only joined the party last autumn, and those who accuse the 'Buchanan Brigaders' of hijacking the movement set up by the Texas millionaire, Ross Perot.

Mr Buchanan's supporters were claiming victory yesterday, saying they had the backing of 410 of the 600 delegates. Mr Buchanan claimed that "these little tiffs, these disputes, will be behind us by Sunday".

But as delegates arrived in Long Beach yesterday, they found two separate tables set up by rival committees. Each faction held its own press conference, claiming to be the "real" Reform party.

Police were standing by outside as proceedings began. On Tuesday afternoon they had to intervene when the party's national committee split into factions and there were scuffles and screaming matches in the convention hotel.

The Buchanan supporters were called "stormtroopers" and "brownshirts" by their opponents, who claim that Mr Buchanan's extreme conservatism misrepresents the party and will lose them their support among libertarians.

Mr Buchanan, 61, a former Nixon speechwriter, has the backing of the party chairman, Gerry Moan, which gives him the upper hand when it comes to controlling the convention and securing $12.5m (£8.3m) in federal campaign funds. If Mr Buchanan claims the money, his opponents say, they will go to court.

Jim Mangia, the party secretary who has been leading the anti-Buchanan faction, said: "The party is united together against Pat Buchanan" whom he accused of being "corrupt" in the way he has pursued the nomination.

The anti-Buchanan faction supports an Iowa physicist, John Hagelin, who is also the Natural Law party's candidate.

The row has highlighted the way the party's fortunes have slumped since 1992, when Mr Perot took 19% of the vote and was credited with helping Bill Clinton beat George Bush.

The latest polls show Mr Buchanan has around 2% of the vote. With the Green party's Ralph Nader polling at around 8% nationally, the Reform party may have already lost its claim to be the third party alternative.

The split may help George W Bush who had feared that Mr Buchanan might lure away conservative Republicans unhappy with the idea of "compassionate conservatism".

On Tuesday afternoon they had to intervene when the party's national committee split into factions and there were scuffles and screaming matches in the convention hotel. The Buchanan supporters were called "stormtroopers" and "brownshirts" by their opponents, who claim that Mr Buchanan's extreme conservatism misrepresents the party and will lose them their support among libertarians. Mr Buchanan, 61, a former Nixon speechwriter, has the backing of the party chairman, Gerry Moan, which gives him the upper hand when it comes to controlling the convention and securing $12.5m (£8.3m) in federal campaign funds. If Mr Buchanan claims the money, his opponents say, they will go to court. Jim Mangia, the party secretary who has been leading the anti-Buchanan faction, said: "The party is united together against Pat Buchanan" whom he accused of being "corrupt" in the way he has pursued the nomination. The anti-Buchanan faction supports an Iowa physicist, John Hagelin, who is also the Natural Law party's candidate. The row has highlighted the way the party's fortunes have slumped since 1992, when Mr Perot took 19% of the vote and was credited with helping Bill Clinton beat George Bush. The latest polls show Mr Buchanan has around 2% of the vote. With the Green party's Ralph Nader polling at around 8% nationally, the Reform party may have already lost its claim to be the third party alternative. The split may help George W Bush who had feared that Mr Buchanan might lure away conservative Republicans unhappy with the idea of "compassionate conservatism".

webTitle: America toys with the joy of judicial killing

fields.headline: America toys with the joy of judicial killing
fields.trailText: The condemned man is fastened to an electric chair by leather straps and wears a steel headplate with two coiled wires. He sits with his head against the back.
fields.body:
The condemned man is fastened to an electric chair by leather straps and wears a steel headplate with two coiled wires. He sits with his head against the back.

When the switch is thrown, the current pulses through the wires and the body convulses. The eyes dissolve into red sockets. Through clenched teeth he utters:"That the best you can do, you pansies?"

Death Row Marv is a toy. It costs $29.95 (about £20),and aimed at the 14-45, mainly male market. And it would be in a shop near you were it not so popular that there is waiting list in shops throughout the United States.

Opinion polls may have begun to register a decline in support for the death penalty, but the American love affair with judicial execution - real or fantasy - shows no sign of abating.

As stocks of Death Row Marv temporarily ran out, the Texas prison authorities executed two convicted murderers late on Wednesday after the federal supreme court voted not to intervene.They brought the number executed in Texas this year to 28.

Tens of thousands of Marvs went on sale, mainly in comic shops and music stores, in June, and the initial run has sold out. Although it is mainly aimed at teenage comic readers, some of the advertising targets are more mature, if that is the right word.

"Pretend it's your boss," is the catchy slogan on one ad.

"Some parents start to get the look of horror after they let their kids play with it," Joel Pollack, a Maryland toyshop owner, told the Washington Post, "but I think everyone sees it as harmless. "I won't say I wouldn't sell it to kids, but I wouldn't without a parent's consent."

webTitle: £13.8m lottery winner looks to a life of luxury

fields.headline: £13.8m lottery winner looks to a life of luxury
fields.trailText: Lottery winner Dean Allen was yesterday looking forward to a life of luxury as he planned how to spend his £13.8m jackpot.
fields.body:
Lottery winner Dean Allen was yesterday looking forward to a life of luxury as he planned how to spend his £13.8m jackpot.

Britain's 10th highest lottery winner, Mr Allen, 26, from Tilbury, Essex, has quit his job as a printer and is planning a holiday in the Seychelles.

He also wants to buy a Porsche, a top of the range Ducati motorcycle and "somewhere nice to live" with his £13,861,061 from Saturday's rollover draw.

Mr Allen vowed that his father, Barry, a printer at the same firm, and mother, Dawn, a personal assistant, would never have to work again. Some of the cash will also go to a charity to help sick children.

He did not know that he had won until three days after the draw when he finally bothered to check his ticket using the information service on his mobile phone.

Hampshire-born Mr Allen, who used to earn £30,000 a year, had been saving up to buy carpets for his first home - a £57,000 two bedroom house. He only moved in six weeks ago and at present drives a four-year-old Ford Fiesta.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Field Of Dreams/The Lavender Hill Mob/Eraserhead/Quatermass And The Pit
fields.body:
Field Of Dreams (Phil Alden Robinson, 1989) 11.45am, Sky Premier

Iowa farmer Ray Kinsella (Kevin Costner) follows a disembodied voice's instructions to turn his land into a pitch for spectral baseball players. The neighbours think he's a base short of a home run but, ploughing on, Kinsella enters a magical world where he finally comes to terms with his dead father. It might have been a field of corn, or just daft, but Costner's honest-Joe performance, with excellent support from the likes of James Earl Jones, makes this a marvellous, heart-warming fantasy.

The Lavender Hill Mob (Charles Crichton, 1951) 5pm, Carlton Cinema

Sublime Ealing comedy with an Oscar-winning script by TEB Clarke. Alec Guinness is the worm who turns, a lowly bank clerk who teams up with hefty Stanley Holloway to pull off an outrageous bullion robbery. Crichton directs with a deft touch, and among the usual suspects are happy henchmen Alfie Bass and Sid James.

Eraserhead (David Lynch, 1976) 12midnight, FilmFour

Lynch's debut is a thoroughly nasty sci-fi horror, set in an unremittingly gloomy dystopia. Traipsing through the benighted city is poor, forever gobsmacked Jack Nance, sporting the world's first flat-top and spawning, with his girlfriend, an utterly revolting little creature. Believed to have been inspired by the birth of Lynch's daughter and by a childhood visit to Philadeplhia, it's rather fascinating to watch, if not exactly enjoyable...

Quatermass And The Pit (Roy Ward Baker, 1967) 12midnight, Carlton Cinema

More late-night chills, with this scary sign-off to the Quatermass series, 10 years on from the original films. Nigel Kneale's script, inspired by his TV series, has Prof Q (Andrew Keir) digging up traces of aliens who tried to inhabit the Earth five million years ago, but the excavations act as an alarm clock for the long dormant visitor. Shot for about sixpence, but the intelligent script and fine performances - James Donald, Barbara Shelley, Julian Glover - make it a Hammer horror to savour.

webTitle: Motor neurone man, 19, wins the right to die

fields.headline: Motor neurone man, 19, wins the right to die
fields.trailText: A young victim of motor neurone disease was yesterday granted his wish to be allowed to die when he loses his final means of communication - the blinking of his left eye.
fields.body:
A young victim of motor neurone disease was yesterday granted his wish to be allowed to die when he loses his final means of communication - the blinking of his left eye.

The 19-year-old man has indicated to doctors and carers by a tiny "yes or no" movement of his eyelid that he wants his artificial ventilation turned off if he loses all ability to communicate with the world around him.

He has asked doctors to wait for two weeks to make sure his ability to make contact does not return.

A high court family division judge in London yesterday granted doctors a declaration that they will not be acting unlawfully in withdrawing life support from the man, referred to only as "AK", so that his illness can take its inevitable course.

Mr Justice Hughes said it would, in fact, be unlawful not to respect his wishes.

The judge heard that AK, born in February 1981, was a normal youngster until he was struck down by the disease in 1998.

MND was extremely rare in one so young. The usual cause of death was respiratory failure. Although a cure was likely to be found in the future, it was extremely unlikely to reverse existing damage.

After losing his ability to speak and most of his physical movements, AK was reduced to eye movement and operating a computer with his big toe. He then lost eye and toe movement.

Within a few weeks from now, the power to move his left eyelid would cease, leaving him "locked into" his body, totally unable to communicate.

The hospital trust responsible for AK, who is being looked after at home by his mother and carers with the support of his father and the guidance of doctors, had sought a court ruling because the doctor in charge of his case had been given conflicting advice on whether it would be legal to allow him to die.

AK was unusual among MND patients in that he had been kept on artificial ventilation since a breathing tube was inserted at a time when doctors were unsure about the nature of his illness.

The judge said that he was satisfied that AK had clearly and independently indicated that he no longer wished to be kept alive once his last means of communication had gone.
