fields.headline: Brewer who hates party invitations
fields.standfirst: Shepherd Neame chief is looking at a warehouse full of booze and it makes him very angry indeed
fields.trailText: Stuart Neame is a very angry brewer. The deputy chairman of Shepherd Neame, the Kent real ale specialist, is waging a highly personal war on the great British pastime of "booze cruising".
fields.body:
Stuart Neame is a very angry brewer. The deputy chairman of Shepherd Neame, the Kent real ale specialist, is waging a highly personal war on the great British pastime of "booze cruising".

A dapper, Rugby-educated 54-year-old, Neame is an unlikely crusader. However, he is deeply worried that his family business is under threat - the cross-Channel drinks trade is wrecking trade at Shepherd Neame's south-eastern pubs.

Neame has a taste for confrontation - he likes to meet the enemy face-to-face on "reconnaissance" visits to the cavernous, cut-price drinks warehouses of Calais. He invited the Guardian on one of his regular excursions to France, in an attempt to expose the organised world of the "white van men".

Standing in the morning sunshine in the car park of Dover's Eastern Docks, Neame looks around furtively. He is watching for suspects. "They don't use white vans any more," he says. "They became too conspicuous, so the professionals switched to coloured vans. Customs are on to that too, though, so most these days use open-backed trucks or estate cars." A few battered Toyota Landcruisers attract his attention but he concedes that 10am is hardly peak time for smugglers, most of whom cross at night. An hour later, Neame is snuggling into a sofa in the executive lounge of one of P&O's ferries. The lounge is almost empty - few business travellers use the ferries these days - but Neame dislikes mixing with the shell-suited masses on his reconnaisance missions. Sipping a complimentary coffee, he outlines his case: "Our Kent pubs have lost a quarter of their business because of imported beer from Calais. Traditional farmworkers and locals used to go to the pub five or six times a week. Now they have a stock of cheap beer at home and drink it in front of the television."

The law allows travellers within the European Union to bring back as many drinks as they like for personal consumption. A benchmark has been set, however, of 110 litres of beer, or 90 litres of wine. Above that level, Customs can ask questions - and the easiest way to answer them is to prove that you are having a party. Neame says it is common practice for the professionals to make fake bookings for "wedding parties" at church halls, to show customs as evidence that their hoards are for personal use. "It's incredible, the lengths they go to," he says.

Arriving in Calais, the first stop is EastEnders - one of the largest and best known of the Calais booze emporiums. Located on the town's ringroad, EastEnders is the size of an aircraft hangar, with sawdust on the floor and forklift trucks shuttling around crates of lager. EastEnders is owned by Dave West, a burly character who styles himself as the consumer's champion against rip-off Britain. Neame and West make an odd couple and there is obvious tension between them - West is in the process of suing Shepherd Neame, which is trying to stop him selling its beer. "I'm a firm believer that duty should be put down," says West. "I'm doing all I can to ensure people break the law - like they did with the poll tax." West's top selling lines include crates of cheap French wine packaged as "The Dog's Bollocks". He has just branched out into washing powder - Persil, apparently, is much cheaper in France than in Britain. "I'm after a knighthood," announces West. "Freddie Laker got a knighthood for getting air fares down. I'm doing what I can to get taxes down."

Neame is unimpressed, and the pair launch into a debate in the middle of the shop floor. West says: "You'd do more by selling your beers in Calais than by launching a £6m advertising campaign. You're a little old country brewer and you'd have products all over the country if you let us sell them." Customers push trolleys around the warehouse with tottering stacks of boxes, containing enough booze for a royal wedding. So, does West really believe his customers are buying purely for personal consumption? His response is to walk up to a woman wheeling a tottering stack of 400 bottles of lager through the checkout, and demand: "Are you going to drink all that, love?" "Of course," she replies, with the usual line: "I'm having a huge party."

Outside EastEnders, two men are loading up a brand new car. Robert, a decorators' merchant, and Dave, a retired firemen, are on the continent for two days. They have bought a car, a crateload of cigarettes from Belgium (the tobacco trade is far more liberal there than in France) and a boot-load of wine. "A job well done," they conclude - their total saving runs to several thousand of pounds. Next stop is Tesco - a store little more than the size of two tennis courts in one of Calais' out-of-town shopping arcades. The manager, Matt Collins, is described as "president directeur général of Tesco France" - although his responsibilities amount to one store. Collins says business has surged since the introduction of a new Eurotunnel offer - vehicles travelling to Calais after 6pm pay just £12 for a return ticket. Hardened alcohol traffickers have been known to travel there and back three times a night. On its best day, Tesco's Calais store clocked up sales of £560,000 and typically the shop accounts for about 15% of the Tesco group's entire revenue from wines and spirits. Collins reckons that means the store supplies nearly 4% of all the wines and spirits consumed in Britain.

So how does he feel about putting Shepherd Neame's pubs out of business? "If it's keeping people home from the pub, then personally I would feel maybe a little bit guilty. But business is business." Collins says Tesco does what it can to put off professional traffickers, who are likely to sell on their purchases. One customer asked for 40 cases of Bacardi, which the store supplied. But when the same man returned the following week for another 40 cases, Collins refused. "Morally, I won't sell in that kind of situation," he says.

Leaving Tesco, Neame follows a home-made sign off the ringroad to another booze warehouse. This one is located down a dirt track, just outside a tatty village, and the prices are even lower. The place is clearly not aimed at holidaymakers - it consists of several warehouses large enough for lorries to enter, and the prices are given in crates, rather than bottles. We are watched suspiciously by staff as we wander around. The brewers are fighting back; the Independent Family Brewers of Britain organises regular watches of Dover docks, to look out for overloaded cars and vans sagging unusually low over their wheels. Neame says accidents are common because some drivers adjust the suspension from their vehicles to fit more booze in, making them more difficult to steer.

However, the problem is not going to disappear. Customs reckons £215m of revenue was lost to Britain through alcohol smuggling last year. The future looks bright for EastEnders.

In the van of the battle On the front line in the war against smugglers are several thousand "excise verification officers", customs officials with the task of stopping and searching suspicious vehicles. They can only hope to make a modest impact: they are pitched against an estimated 27,000 people involved in smuggling. Of the 1.4m pints of beer brought across the Channel every day, 75% is destined for illegal resale. A customs spokeswoman says: "Our job is to pull people over, question them and try to establish whether their hoards are for personal use." If vehicles are carrying more than the "statutory limit" of 800 cigarettes and 110 litres of beer, drivers will be asked for evidence that they are planning a party or special event. Customs keeps an eye out for vans which have been across the Channel several times a day.

The thin blue line was strengthened recently by more money from the Treasury. The March Budget committed £209m for recruitment of 1,000 officers. Overseeing all is the former Barclays Bank chief Martin Taylor, the government's unofficial "smuggling tsar". Measures to deter smuggling are increasingly imaginative. One recent initiative was to punish newsagents selling bootleg beer and tobacco by taking away their National Lottery machines, often the most lucrative part of their business.

The chase extends beyond Channel ports. The Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association reckons about 15% of white vans head straight for the Midlands, with 4,000 a year targeting Birmingham. It has hired private invest- igators to carry out covert surveillance, to prove to the Treasury that the problem is greater than official figures suggest.

webTitle: Toyota tries to pass the currency buck

fields.headline: Toyota tries to pass the currency buck
fields.standfirst: Move shifts the short-term risk
fields.trailText: Toyota's decision to ask new UK suppliers to bill it in euros rather than sterling does have a commercial rationale - although one which appears to have dawned on the Japanese car maker rather late in the day.
fields.body:
Toyota's decision to ask new UK suppliers to bill it in euros rather than sterling does have a commercial rationale - although one which appears to have dawned on the Japanese car maker rather late in the day. It is understandable that, as a big exporter to euroland, the company wants to bring its cost base as closely into line with its competitors as possible. A 16% depreciation in the euro's value against the pound over the past 18 months is certainly no help.

But while the Toyota move would have been a smart one last year today the decision only really makes sense if Toyota believes the euro is going to continue falling against sterling - and that, to be frank, seems unlikely. Asking suppliers to invoice in euros is not the same as fixing the exchange rate. When the euro recovers, as it almost certainly will, Toyota will fall victim to the exchange rate risk it thought it was passing on to suppliers.

The significance of the announcement goes beyond the way in which a multi-national asks to be invoiced by its sub-contractors. It says quite a bit about the way in which the big and powerful can shift commercial risks on to the vulnerable. It speaks volumes about the way in which firms in certain industries are being forced to find cost savings as a result of global over-production, and it feeds straight into the dialogue of the deaf going on about Britain's membership of the single currency.

At one level, Toyota's move will certainly have an impact on the debate. Just as British consumers may warm to the single currency once they start to handle euro notes and coins in Spain and France, so there may be a drip-drip effect on companies as well. There is a risk that parts of the UK economy may move towards becoming de facto members of the single currency zone even if the rest of the country stays out. So far any evidence of that happening is sketchy. Over the longer term there are firms which may find it more convenient, because of the profile of their business, to deal in euros. It will be interesting to see, too, how London-based cross-border share dealing settles down, if the merger with Frankfurt ever gets off the ground.

Will the pound or the euro be the currency of choice? Initially it will be the former, but for how long? That is for the future, however. To draw the conclusion that Britain should join the euro simply because life at present is uncomfortable for a relatively small number of Japanese investors would be a mistake. Toyota, Nissan, and some other big names would definitely benefit from a fixed exchange rate with the euro, provided it was lower than today's, but every firm in Britain would suffer if the UK economy was labouring under the wrong interest rate.

Economically, what matters is that Britain has the right overall business climate. Japan accounts for only 4% of inward investment and it has been noticeable that American companies - a much bigger proportion of the total - and those operating in the hi-tech field put Britain's membership of the single currency well down their list of concerns. Yesterday Ford promised a new Aston Martin R&D centre and Nasdaq-listed RSL said it was moving to Britain.

Politically, what matters is that we have a proper exercise in democracy. We should not allow a decision as big as this to be made by a few multinationals. Even those who support British entry into the euro should be concerned about the impact on voters if the perception takes hold that Britain is being bounced into membership by big firms with their own, narrow, economic agenda.

Market share

"If investors see a stock's price change dramatically but are given access to critical market-moving information only much later, we risk nothing less than the public's faith and confidence in America's capital markets." That was US securities and exchange commission chairman Arthur Levitt yesterday on the decision to give small shareholders the same access to price-sensitive information as big shareholders and analysts. The decision will not be an easy one for the investment community.

Analysts' forecasts of company performance can themselves be market-moving. Will a company which reckons an analyst is getting his or her sums wrong be able to drop a quiet word about a rethink? Journalists, too, might find executives inclined to avoid answering awkward questions by pleading the SEC amendment - whether or not they would be in contravention of the rule change. But although the practicalities may be difficult, they do not constitute an insurmountable obstacle. The SEC will no doubt consider the way in which its new regime is working and make appropriate amendments. But the underlying principle, that all shareholders must be treated equally, must be right. Exchange officials and executives of publicly quoted firms round the world should have Mr Levitt's words framed on their office walls where they can be read, regularly.

fields.headline: Should I try to win back the friends scared off by my disability?
fields.trailText: Next week: "I have been my brother's mother for a year and feel compelled to help him."
fields.body:
Clear the air

When I was in my early 20s, a close friend of mine became severely ill. As in your case, her family offered support whilst most of her friends let her down, myself included. She was furious that the world kept turning round whilst her life had stopped. The fact that we lived in different countries didn't help. How could I share my own trite preoccupations with her when she lived in a realm of life and death issues? I was told that my letters provoked anger and disgust. I felt guilty for carrying on with my life and resented her for this guilt. I simply didn't have a clue how to be a good friend to her.

I now judge my behaviour as at worst selfish and insensitive, and at best desperately out of touch. Sadly, most of us are not equipped to handle illness in others. Most problems in other people's lives enable us to give advice and thus feel useful. Illness is unfair and unexplainable, and leaves us feeling powerless. Your friends might feel embarrassed to mention things you can no longer do. Their good health might strike them as an insult to you. Ignoring the issue is both the easiest response to slip into and the most damaging.

My friend later pointed out to me that I should have looked into how her illness was affecting me. Indeed, this is where the yoke hurt. Instead of the lofty, altruistic feelings one imagines should flow naturally, her illness brought into focus the messy issues in our relationship. My friend eventually confronted me with recriminations. This came as a great relief: her aggression allowed me to air my own ugly feelings. We gradually came to understand, and accept, each other's side of the story.

Perhaps your friends also need to hear how disappointed you are with them and how much you miss them. Chances are they are guilt-ridden and will, eventually, welcome the opportunity to own up to this. If they don't, at least you will have let them know what terrible friends they are. Name and address withheld

Time will tell

I have been disabled from birth but have managed to lead a normal life. I have made many friends over the years but am sure I must have met many people who couldn't cope with my disability and dropped the acquaintance at an early stage.

I have never found it much use to try to "educate" people about my disability as, if you give them too much information, some people come to see you as a symbol of your condition rather than the unique individual that you are. Perhaps it is better to ask for help when the need arises, have a laugh over clumsy mishaps ("Drunk again!") and hope people get the picture eventually. However, you obviously can't do this with friends who won't see you.

Meeting new people through voluntary work has helped a little and I am sure you will make new friends too. Perhaps you could keep track of your old friends for a time via the third parties you mention. When they get over the shock and hear how well you are coping, maybe they will come back to you. Name and address withheld

It's your call

I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis two years ago. While most of my friends were supportive, others found it so awkward that they avoid mentioning it even now and a few simply lost touch.

You say you miss your friends terribly, even though they have felt unable to support you when you need them most. If so, you should get in touch as your happiness is more important than anything else at the present time. It may be that some of your former friends are missing you but waiting for you to make the first move and, sadly, it is you who will have to be strong enough to contact them rather than the other way round.

You may find that some will not want to renew the friendship. However, if you re-establish contact with only one of these people, you will have gained something. While I can see your partner's view, I have found that with so many changes in my life I have desperately wanted to hold on to my old friends. It will make you feel stronger if you take the difficult but positive step of contacting them and letting them see that you are still the same person that they once knew. I wish you luck. L Thomson, London

Safety in numbers

My first reaction when I read your letter was that these people were never your friends at all, but of course they were. You have deep affection for them, you've shared all sorts of confidences with them, perhaps you've helped each other through rough patches. But now they're being called upon for support that they feel ill-equipped to provide.

Perhaps this was the kind of fairweather friendship which is based on having fun together, and you were just as shallow as them. But often in those kinds of friendships there is a quieter, wiser member who stabilises the group. It sounds as if you might have been in that role: the one to whom the others turned when things weren't going so well. If so, your friends are in a quandary - the very person to whom they would turn for advice on how to provide support is the person who needs that support.

You may well be in a better position than them, at least as far as friendships go. You'll find that going for treatment, etc, will give you access to a whole new range of people, some of whom you may bond with just as closely as your old set.

But if you don't want to lose that original group, why not invite them all round together? They will feel less uncomfortable and if you can make the effort to be as cheerful as possible you might break the ice and allow them to overcome their fears. Just because you have a disability does not mean you are needy with nothing to give: the most supportive and giving friend I ever had died of her disability 15 years ago, and I still miss her friendship and wisdom. Kate Viscardi, Herts

Next week

Last year my mother died and I moved home to look after my two younger brothers, who were 15 and 18. I was 26. My father remarried after he and my mother divorced 17 years ago and lives in another city. We thought it best that I move in to see the boys through their education - the youngest was in his final GSCE year and the elder had just finished his A levels. I, therefore, crossed the bridge from being sister to mother overnight.

This summer, after his exams, my youngest brother moved in with our dad and is having a terrible time settling in. I desperately want to call him all the time to see how he is and about his concerns with our dad. However, I'm aware that I shouldn't step on our dad's toes now that he's the parent, but at the same time I have been my brother's mother for a year and feel compelled to help him.

Ordinarily, I would be the sister and so would step back and let my father sort things out, but through tragic circumstances, I was forced into a parenting role. I have no children of my own: my only experience is with my brothers. I feel confused about my role now: should I stand back or help my brother?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020 7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: Fayed champions Leeds over Delhi
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al Fayed, the colourful owner of Harrods, is styling himself as a champion of the British worker by objecting to plans by the store's charge card operator to deal with customers' inquiries from a call centre in Delhi.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed, the colourful owner of Harrods, is styling himself as a champion of the British worker by objecting to plans by the store's charge card operator to deal with customers' inquiries from a call centre in Delhi.

The department store yesterday said it was "reviewing its relationship" with financial services company GE Capital, which issues bills and statements for Harrods' 500,000 gold card-holders. It said it was worried about job losses under plans by GE to move some accounts from a call centre in Leeds, which employs 1,700 people, to India. A Harrods spokesman said: "Harrods places customer care as its highest priority. It is concerned with the loss of any jobs in Britain as a result of this plan."

GE Capital also handles store cards for Debenhams and the Arcadia Group, which owns chains including Top Shop, Dorothy Perkins and Burton Menswear. The financial services company responded angrily yesterday, saying it was "a courteous and considered organisation" and did not approve of discussing business relationships in public. Craig Kershaw, a spokesman for GE, said: "We abide by certain ethical business standards. We have respect for our clients and partners."

Mr Kershaw said there were proposals to deal with some inquiries from Delhi. However, he refused to say whether any job losses were likely in Leeds. "Our Leeds centre is a significant, large call centre and it will continue to be." Both Debenhams and Arcadia distanced themselves from the controversy, saying the location of call centres was a matter for GE, provided service was not affected.

webTitle: Landmine charity that won royal recognition

fields.headline: Landmine charity that won royal recognition
fields.standfirst: Aid workers rally to organisation's defence
fields.trailText: For the Halo Trust, a British based charity, yesterday's allegations by the Russians that four of its workers had been spying while in Chechnya were an unwelcome distraction from its mine clearing around the world.
fields.body:
For the Halo Trust, a British based charity, yesterday's allegations by the Russians that four of its workers had been spying while in Chechnya were an unwelcome distraction from its mine clearing around the world.

The trust had gained little public attention until the publicity generated by Princess Diana's campaign against landmines shone a light on the work it had been carrying out.

The cameras and attention followed the princess to Huambo in Angola where she went in 1997 in support of the Red Cross campaign against mines.

She picked her way through a minefield and the world saw this glamorous woman watching personnel from the Halo Trust clearing the topsoil to reveal the mines that had left Angola a wreck of walking wounded after a bitter civil war.

Last year the Diana, Princess of Wales, memorial fund gave the Halo Trust a £153,000 grant for its work in two war-ravaged areas, Cambodia and Afghanistan. Shelley-Anne Claircourt, a spokeswoman for the fund, last night paid this tribute to the mine clearance charity: "The Halo Trust has a fine track record in clearing land mines, which is why we supported them."

It was founded in 1988 by Colin "Mad Mitch" Mitchell. His nickname came from the conflict in Aden in 1967.

After leaving the army, Lieutenant Colonel Mitchell became a Tory MP and served as parliamentary private secretary to the secretary of state for Scotland in the Heath government.

He set up Halo, which stands for "hazardous areas life-support organisation", after several forays into Soviet-occupied Afghanistan.

Together with another former British army officer, Guy Willoughby, Mr Mitchell made Halo the largest mine-clearing charity in the world. He died four years ago.

Halo has conducted mine clearance operations in Angola, Mozambique, Cambodia, Nagorno-Karabakh, and the Balkans, as well as having an office in Abkhazia, the breakaway part of Georgia which borders Chechnya on the south.

Halo operates across nine countries and has 3,000 people defusing mines, most of whom are locals.

Halo's de-miners face dangers on top of those posed by mines exploding and injuring them.

In June, John Fulford of Halo was released after being abducted in the remote Georgian region of Abkhazia. Rebels seeking independence had demanded a ransom of £180,000, but his freedom came without this being paid.

The allegations that four of the trust's staff were spies were dismissed by fellow charity workers.

Last night aid workers with experience of the dangerous conditions in Chechnya rallied to Halo's defence.

They praised the trust's professionalism and courage in conducting mine clearance operations that no one else would take on.

"The Halo Trust did a very good job in Chechnya,'' said Mary Wareham, of Human Rights Watch in Washington. "They were working there at a time when no other organisation was prepared to, carrying out work which was essential.''

Chris Hunter, director of the centre for peacemaking and community development, which operates in Chechnya, said that Halo was the only agency working in Chechnya with the skills needed to carry out mine-clearing.

"It was obviously a high-risk situation which was inevitably going to lead to problems with the Russian authorities,'' he said.

One aid worker said innocent actions by the Halo team could have been misconstrued by the Russians.

"Mine clearing is a sensitive area,'' said the official. "The way groups like this defuse mines is to gather a lot of them together and trigger a controlled explosion. You can see how this might be twisted and described as training people in explosives. They also have to make detailed maps of the mined areas and have a good database of information about the region. This could also be twisted and described as surveillance.''

Russian planes showered mines on Chechnya during its attacks on the rebellious region, and have mined areas surrounding military installations. Halo said it recorded 296 mined areas in Chechnya after the 1994-96 war, and said these were frightening refugees from returning home.

"We then stopped mine clearing when the Russians started the war again in Chechnya. But the Russians fired rockets into the minefields and killed three of our de-miners, and four of our de-miners also died in a Russian rocket attack," Mr Willoughby said yesterday.

Halo receives money from governments, including those of Canada, the Czech Republic, Germany, and Britain, as well as from the United Nations.

It latest accounts lodged with Companies House show that in 1998-99 it had an income of £8.7m, made a loss of £81,000, and held assets of £4m, mostly in cash.

Its mine clearers' wages make up the bulk of the charity's costs. Each de-miner wears protective clothing and a face visor, and uses sophisticated detectors with the ability to detect plastic mines, which have a low metal content.

"The Halo Trust did a very good job in Chechnya,'' said Mary Wareham, of Human Rights Watch in Washington. "They were working there at a time when no other organisation was prepared to, carrying out work which was essential.'' Chris Hunter, director of the centre for peacemaking and community development, which operates in Chechnya, said that Halo was the only agency working in Chechnya with the skills needed to carry out mine-clearing. "It was obviously a high-risk situation which was inevitably going to lead to problems with the Russian authorities,'' he said. One aid worker said innocent actions by the Halo team could have been misconstrued by the Russians. "Mine clearing is a sensitive area,'' said the official. "The way groups like this defuse mines is to gather a lot of them together and trigger a controlled explosion. You can see how this might be twisted and described as training people in explosives. They also have to make detailed maps of the mined areas and have a good database of information about the region. This could also be twisted and described as surveillance.'' Russian planes showered mines on Chechnya during its attacks on the rebellious region, and have mined areas surrounding military installations. Halo said it recorded 296 mined areas in Chechnya after the 1994-96 war, and said these were frightening refugees from returning home. "We then stopped mine clearing when the Russians started the war again in Chechnya. But the Russians fired rockets into the minefields and killed three of our de-miners, and four of our de-miners also died in a Russian rocket attack," Mr Willoughby said yesterday. Halo receives money from governments, including those of Canada, the Czech Republic, Germany, and Britain, as well as from the United Nations. It latest accounts lodged with Companies House show that in 1998-99 it had an income of £8.7m, made a loss of £81,000, and held assets of £4m, mostly in cash. Its mine clearers' wages make up the bulk of the charity's costs. Each de-miner wears protective clothing and a face visor, and uses sophisticated detectors with the ability to detect plastic mines, which have a low metal content.

webTitle: Games stadium 'may not be ready in time'

fields.headline: Games stadium 'may not be ready in time'
fields.trailText: The main stadium of the 2002 Commonwealth Games in Manchester will overshoot its budget by up to £12m and may not be completed in time, a stadium designer has warned.
fields.body:
The main stadium of the 2002 Commonwealth Games in Manchester will overshoot its budget by up to £12m and may not be completed in time, a stadium designer has warned.

The 38,000-seater Sportcity stadium in east Manchester will cost far more than the projected £91m and will "struggle to complete on programme", according to a confidential report for building contractor Taylor Woodrow by Bill Reid, a stadium design specialist.

The report, leaked to the trade journal Construction News, said the city council had "seriously undervalued" the costs of the giant stadium.

The Sportcity stadium, which will house four separate sports venues, is intended to host athletics events during the games as well as the opening and closing ceremonies. From 2003, it is expected to become home for Manchester City football club, currently based in Maine Road. But the project has been beset by contractual problems, with the first contractor, Amec, quitting after six months amid disputes with Manchester council over costs.

Building contractor Laing has since taken over construction, but has yet to reach an agreement with the council on the eventual bill.

The report - commissioned two years ago by Taylor Woodrow, which lost a bid to build the stadium - singles out for criticism the complexity of the stadium's dramatic cantilevered steel roof, supported by a network of cables suspended from a dozen 60-metre steel masts. "A saving of at least £3m to £5m should be achieved by simplifying the roof structure," wrote Mr Reid, of the Thorburn Colquhoun design consultancy.

Manchester council's deputy chief executive, Howard Bernstein, said: "This is another example of London scaremongering ... The great news is that the stadium is on programme and meeting all its targets."

webTitle: Abuser speaks out over mob fury

fields.headline: Abuser speaks out over mob fury
fields.standfirst:
Vigilantes are driving offenders underground, warns Portsmouth paedophile on run for his life

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Victor Burnett is terrified. He does not expect sympathy for his predicament, nor forgiveness for his crimes. He does not expect people to understand why he was sexually attracted to boys as young as eleven - "I thought it was natural" - or how he managed to abuse so many without feeling the slightest remorse.
fields.body:
Victor Burnett is terrified. He does not expect sympathy for his predicament, nor forgiveness for his crimes. He does not expect people to understand why he was sexually attracted to boys as young as eleven - "I thought it was natural" - or how he managed to abuse so many without feeling the slightest remorse.

But as a serial paedophile, and the man at the centre of the "name and shame" furore in Portsmouth, he believes his voice must be heard before untold damage is done.

In an interview with the Guardian, Burnett, 55, said the "mindless, stupid vigilantes" who had terrorised him out of his home were driving scores of paedophiles underground.

"When the police know where the offenders are there is some measure of control, but if they go underground, the authorities will never see or hear from them. Not until they offend again, that is.

"Paedophiles who disappear from one estate will turn up on another. To say the vigilantes are behaving like animals would be unfair to animals.

"What do they really hope to achieve? If they lynched me, what good would that do? This is the madness of the mob."

Burnett has been in hiding since last Friday, when the police escorted him out of his flat on the Paulsgrove estate, in north Portsmouth, hours before a demonstration which erupted into violence.

Since then, he has considered suicide. He believes he will be killed if the mob ever discovers his whereabouts.

"I've had death threat phone calls. One woman left a message saying 'I'm going to cut you up and give the bits to the kids... sex case, sex case, hang him, hang him'."

Although Burnett admits he was responsible for "terrible, terrible" abuses, he insists he has not reoffended since he was released from Maidstone prison six years ago and that, through extensive sexual therapy, he has "taught" himself not to be aroused by children.

Like many paedophiles, he was abused as a child. He was eight and the paedophile was a Franciscan monk who taught at his boarding school.

"I was a bit confused, but it didn't hurt and, to be honest, I ended up enjoying it. The relationship lasted for five years and I had sex with other boys as well, which also seemed natural. I thought it was quite normal. For me, it was always boys, never girls."

He added: "As I went through puberty and adolescence, my body changed but my taste in boys did not. I grew up, but my sexual preference stayed the same."

Burnett has spent 14 and a half years in jail for sex offences since he was 16, and admits he has abused up to 40 children, aged between 11 and 15.

Electric shock treatment did not stop him from offending.

"I also took a course of women's hormones. All that does is make your breasts grow and increase your sexual frustration.

"Nothing worked. At the time nobody could have have convinced me I was doing wrong. I thought, they are enjoying it and I am enjoying it, so how can that be wrong?

"I didn't think of the children as sex objects, I thought of them as friends. And if a child didn't want to have sex, I would stop. I wanted them to enjoy themselves, not have a bad experience."

Burnett says he did not find his victims by "hanging round parks, public toilets or public swimming pools". His modus operandi was, he concedes, in many ways worse. "All the children I was involved with were friends of people I knew. Getting to know a boy could take months, it could take years. If a boy didn't want to have sex, I wouldn't force him. I wasn't violent, good God, no."

It took two and a half years of sex therapy with a psychiatrist at Maidstone prison in the early 1990s to make Burnett realise the harm he was doing.

"She made me write down every sexual experience I had ever had, from the first to the last. "I was made to remember horrible experiences that I had had as a child. Then she took me through all the things I had done to children. I began to realise the impact I had had on those kids.

"One still looks, but in the past I used to think, yes, I'd like to. But not now. I don't see children as sex objects. I see them as vulnerable children.

"After I had been shown the pain I had caused, I began to understand what I was doing was wrong. When I see children now I do not get aroused. I think how the hell could I put a kid through that again.

"Being a paedophile is not a weakness, it is part of you, it's always there.

"I have been teaching myself to go with older people. You have to programme yourself to say no. I will always be a gay man. But as far as the underage sex is concerned, I now know it's wrong. When the News of the World said I was on the verge of reoffending, they were talking rubbish. There have been no boys since I left prison. I have been clean."

Burnett has met two of his victims in recent years. One rang him and asked: "Do you remember me?"

"He said the word chimney, which is one I had taught him. He asked to meet me outside a pub in Middlesex. It was an emotional experience. I wondered if he would get violent, but he didn't. He said 'if you promise never to do it again, I will remain friends with you.

"This man is still seeing a psychiatrist and is on medication. His wife doesn't know he came to see me. I don't know if she knows anything about me.

"I feel very, very guilty. I said to myself, 'look what you have done'."

Burnett thinks the News of the World should be prosecuted for inciting violence. He blames the newspaper for the suicide of two alleged paedophiles, and for ruining what chance he had of breaking away from the past.

Burnett has two sons, but has not seen them in years.

"One is 25 and he has a degree. I hope my ex-wife hasn't told him who his father is.

"I went to Portsmouth to get away, to start again. Of course I didn't tell anyone there about my convictions.

"But there is no future for me there. I will probably live the rest of my life on the run or until I am killed. I dare not look ahead."

 News of the World

fields.headline: QXL.com partner wavers
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: QXL.com last night took a battering from one of its long-term supporters after the online auctioneer stunned the market by announcing it was re-evaluating the terms of its merger with a German competitor and burning cash faster than analysts expected.
fields.body:
QXL.com last night took a battering from one of its long-term supporters after the online auctioneer stunned the market by announcing it was re-evaluating the terms of its merger with a German competitor and burning cash faster than analysts expected.

Shares in QXL are this morning expected to come under pressure after one of the City's most bullish adherents said he was "throwing in the towel" and advising clients to sell the shares after calculating that QXL would run out of money by the middle of next year unless it significantly narrows its losses. Peter Misek, senior e-commerce analyst at Chase H&Q, warned that if QXL could not complete its merger with Ricardo.de it would be potentially crippling for the firm.

QXL had earlier said "certain information" had forced it to re-evaluate the deal. Mr Misek said QXL could not afford to not be one of the dominant players in Germany, Europe's largest market. "Doubt over the proposed merger with Ricardo puts QXL's viability versus EBay [the US auction company] totally in doubt," Mr Misek said. "The cash pile is diminishing faster than we forecasted due to acquisition costs, and we believe the company will have to refinance in 12 to 18 months. "We believed that QXL out of all of the B2C e-commerce in Europe could be a winner, given the fact that EBay has proven the model can work and can make real money. But we feel totally let down. We recommend clients sell the stock."

QXL's shares firmed 1.25p to 63p yesterday after management insisted the Ricardo deal was not necessarily off and hoped to clarify their position next week. Buying from arbitrageurs who were closing short positions also supported the stock. Ricardo shares fell 16% to Û32.15 (£20). Mr Misek said that he believed QXL shares could fall as low as 40p. "At that point we believe the company becomes susceptible to takeover. We are taking the view that the reason you would now hold this stock is that you believe someone will buy the company, although the likelihood of that is a guess, at best." He said he was slashing his revenue estimate for the full year of 2001 by 30%, and increasing forecast operating loss for the same period by more than 30% to $85.6m (£57m). Geoff Ruddell, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, said: "Until today our caution on QXL has been based primarily on its cash position. "Today, however, has caused us to begin to question the company's strategy and execution for the first time."

QXL chief executive Jim Rose refused to elaborate on the reasons for the re-evaluation of the Ricardo merger but stressed he still wanted it to go ahead - as long as it was in the interest of shareholders - and hoped positive news could be published soon. In the three months to June 30, losses widened from £3.4m last year to £15.5m, leaving £60.7m cash in the bank. Revenues of £2.1m were down £300,000 on the previous quarter, due to seasonality. Gross auction value per member was also lower than analysts had expected.

webTitle: Hyder bid war goes down to the wire

fields.headline: Hyder bid war goes down to the wire
fields.trailText: The bidding war for Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, will go down to the wire later today after the takeover panel last night insisted the two rivals, Japanese bank Nomura and US group Western Power Distribution, submit final sealed bids.
fields.body:
The bidding war for Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, will go down to the wire later today after the takeover panel last night insisted the two rivals, Japanese bank Nomura and US group Western Power Distribution, submit final sealed bids.

It is the first time the panel has used this procedure in a takeover battle. It is understood that the rivals have until 1pm to put in their bids and the winner will be declared at or around the closing of the market at 4.30pm. Nomura, with its third offer of 360p a share or £557m, edged in front this week of WPD which had put in a £526m offer recommended by the embattled Hyder board. But, with shares in the debt-ridden Welsh group closing at 384p, analysts expect an offer of around 400p to win the day.

Sources close to the deal said Nomura was unimpressed by the move. The Japanese bank did not think the procedure was the "right way" to conclude the battle for Hyder and was "wholly inappropriate" for Wales' biggest plc. The panel said it was intervening in order to allow the bidding war to come to an orderly conclusion today, the last day for bids under its rules. Though it refused to divulge details it was likened to an auction.

Some two years ago the full panel imposed the same procedure in the battle for control of the Energy Group, including Eastern Electricity, between rival American bidders Texas Utilities and PacifiCorp. But the procedure lapsed when PacifiCorp withdrew at the last minute. Neither bidder for Hyder, which owns Welsh Water, the Swalec electricity distribution business and a business services and infrastructure divisions, has so far indicated a willingness to drop out. Nomura entered the lists at 260p, a substantial premium on the 189.25p price of Hyder on March 27, the day before Wales's biggest plc said it was in talks with other groups about its future. But subsequent bids have pushed the offer price to 360p.

The Japanese bank has won political and union backing for its approach because it has promised to keep the group, which has debts of £1.6bn, intact and retain Welsh Water for five years and Swalec for at least three years.

fields.headline: Blue-chip order boosts Autonomy
fields.trailText: Autonomy is this morning expected to announce that pharmaceutical group AstraZeneca is the latest multinational to license its "intelligent software", which automatically sifts and archives corporate data.
fields.body:
Autonomy is this morning expected to announce that pharmaceutical group AstraZeneca is the latest multinational to license its "intelligent software", which automatically sifts and archives corporate data.

The value of the deal is relatively small - no more than £1m - but AstraZeneca's blue-chip status will be a useful selling point for Autonomy as it tries to achieve universal adoption of its software. The "intelligent" software looks at the contents of information sources such as the web, intranet, internal memos and emails, then decides to which people and departments they are most relevant and automatically sends the information to them.

All AstraZeneca, departments, from research and development to business management, will use the product. Autonomy claims the volume of unstructured data on the web is doubling every three months. One in five firms has had to increase its network resources by 75% to manage the growth in corporate data. Duncan Fyfe, AstraZeneca's director of product strategy and licensing, said: "By using Autonomy we can ensure that the right material reaches the right person at the right time. "It means our staff are better informed, our research decisions better supported and the costs typically associated with managing information significantly reduced."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Headmistress to appeal

Marjorie Evans, the headmistress convicted at Abergavenny, south Wales, of slapping a 10-year-old boy, is to appeal against conviction before a high court judge at Cardiff crown court at the end of August.

British Gas gets real

British Gas is to phase out the unpopular system of estimating many of its 70m bills a year and have all meters read every three months, it said yesterday.

Balloon pole record refused

Adventurer David Hempleman-Adams, who flew 1,500 miles in a hot air ballon attempt to cross the north pole, has been refused a world record title because he went 15 miles wide of the pole's exact location. The rules set a one metre maximum for deviation.

Hotel victim's funeral

More than 300 family and friends of Gary Sutton, 24, who died in the Australian backpackers hotel fire seven weeks ago, attended his funeral in Bath yesterday.

A story of love, drink and court

Filming of a Bollywood love story near the Eros statue in Piccadilly circus on Christmas Day was disrupted when drunks joined in and a fight broke out. Ian Ireland, 20, was sentenced to four months' youth custody at Southwark crown court yesterday after admitted using threatening behaviour.

Balloon pole record refused Adventurer David Hempleman-Adams, who flew 1,500 miles in a hot air ballon attempt to cross the north pole, has been refused a world record title because he went 15 miles wide of the pole's exact location. The rules set a one metre maximum for deviation. Hotel victim's funeral More than 300 family and friends of Gary Sutton, 24, who died in the Australian backpackers hotel fire seven weeks ago, attended his funeral in Bath yesterday. A story of love, drink and court Filming of a Bollywood love story near the Eros statue in Piccadilly circus on Christmas Day was disrupted when drunks joined in and a fight broke out. Ian Ireland, 20, was sentenced to four months' youth custody at Southwark crown court yesterday after admitted using threatening behaviour.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
BMW insider dealing inquiry

An insider dealing inquiry focusing on BMW's sale of Rover was yesterday described as routine by the company and "an absolutely normal procedure" by the German watchdog involved. Both said suggestions of 30 senior BMW staff being investigated were media speculation.
fields.body:
BMW insider dealing inquiry

An insider dealing inquiry focusing on BMW's sale of Rover was yesterday described as routine by the company and "an absolutely normal procedure" by the German watchdog involved. Both said suggestions of 30 senior BMW staff being investigated were media speculation.

The preliminary inquiry also covers a possible breach of rules on how companies publish information likely to affect their share price. There were wild fluctuations in the BMW price before the March 16 board meeting that agreed the sale to Ford.

Harry Potter plays games

Computer games firm Electronic Arts said yesterday it had won the worldwide rights to develop games based on the popular Harry Potter series of children's books. The company, based in Britain and listed on Nasdaq, said it had also secured the rights to develop and publish Harry Potter internet games. The terms of the deal with Warner Bros were not disclosed.

United News in £6m deal

United News & Media said yesterday it had bought British health care information company Healthcare Data for £6m as part of its drive to build a market information powerhouse. After announcing a new strategy last week to build a leading market information group following the sale of the bulk of its television assets, United News said the purchase of Healthcare Data, which manages a database of more than 250,000 British health care professionals, would boost one of its core publishing markets.

US signals slowdown

The US economy showed signs of slowing in June and July, the federal reserve said yesterday. The central bank's summary of business conditions reported that easing consumer demand for goods and services appeared to be restraining price increases but job markets remained tight, forcing firms to raise pay.

Cannons lifts profits 60%

Cannons Group, the health and fitness club operator, is considering expansion into several European markets but said it would adopt a cautious approach, after reporting a 60% rise in half-year pre-tax profits from £6.3m to £10.1m. Turnover jumped 61% to £47m. Cannons shares ended 6.5p down at 124.5p

Redstone spends £11.6m

Redstone Telecom yesterday accelerated its battle for market share in the competitive small to medium-sized firms sector with the acquisition of two small companies for £11.6m. Graham Cove, chief executive of Redstone, said the company had bought Pure Group for £5.6m, which gives it another 3,000 customers and sales and engineering staff. It also bought Isomatrix, a voice interactive services firm, for £6m.

webTitle: Victims of sex abuse march on cathedral

fields.headline: Victims of sex abuse march on cathedral
fields.trailText: Survivors of sexual and other abuse by the Catholic Church are to march on Westminster Cathedral to seek redress from Archbishop Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, in a sign of the church's problem with reassuring congregations that it is dealing with abusers.
fields.body:
Survivors of sexual and other abuse by the Catholic Church are to march on Westminster Cathedral to seek redress from Archbishop Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, in a sign of the church's problem with reassuring congregations that it is dealing with abusers.

A month ago the archbishop faced widespread criticism for his own handling of the case of Father Michael Hill, a priest in his former diocese in Sussex who was moved to new posts in the 1980s despite recurrent complaints that he was abusing boys. The archbishop, who was only appointed in March, has apologised publicly.

The march, on August bank holiday, is organised by an organisation called Survivors of Spiritual Abuse, and will include victims of sexual abuse and emotional bullying by priests and nuns in parishes and church-run institutions, such as schools. Several hundred people are expected. They want complaints of abuse to be referred in future to outside help agencies.

Susan Ni Rahilly, one of the organisers, said: "The church is still referring people who complain to their own organisations, but that is extremely dangerous because they are putting people back into the hands of their abusers."

A letter from the group to the archbishop claims the church hierarchy has acted incompetently and negligently with an increasing number of allegations of abuse.

There have been accusations that the church was more concerned with shielding abusers than protecting children. Fr Hill was eventually jailed for five years in 1997 and the church has paid compensation to two of his victims.

webTitle: Road map sailor agrees to set a new course

fields.headline: Road map sailor agrees to set a new course
fields.trailText: A hopeless yachtsman who was rescued by lifeboat crews for the 11th time yesterday after he was comprehensively derided for his irresponsible attitude has agreed to learn how to navigate his boat.
fields.body:
A hopeless yachtsman who was rescued by lifeboat crews for the 11th time yesterday after he was comprehensively derided for his irresponsible attitude has agreed to learn how to navigate his boat.

Eric Abbott, 56, who had previously used only AA road maps to navigate the Irish Sea, cost an estimated £55,000 in coastguard and lifeboat bills in the past year.

Although he claims to have gone to sea to find himself, he tends to frequently get lost and has acquired the moniker of Captain Calamity.

The retired painter, from Northwich, Cheshire, once told a coastguard watch manager that he could see the Welsh hills when he was actually off the coast of Northern Ireland.

The offer of a free basic navigation course was made yesterday morning by the Royal Yachting Association shortly after Mr Abbott caused more problems for the coastguard when he ran aground in his 24ft boat Plus Vat off Rhyl. He had misjudged a narrow harbour channel.

A lifeboat was sent to assist him in the Rhyl estuary after he made yet another SOS call. The lifeboat crew spent more than an hour refloating his vessel.

The Royal National Lifeboat Institution condemned his irresponsible attitude. "He should be made aware that the RNLI is supported entirely by voluntary contributions and the volunteer crews go out in their own time," said Michael Vlasto, chief of operations. "Putting volunteers' lives at risk in this way is unforgiveable."

But an unrepentant Mr Abbott said: "It was a bit hair-raising. But I am thick-skinned."

He said it was "absolute rubbish" to suggest that he had been irresponsible.

Ray Carson, deputy district controller at Holyhead Coastguard, expressed relief that he had taken up the offer of the Royal Yachting Association's basic navigation course.

"We are delighted that the Royal Yachting Association has made such a generous offer," he said. "We have every sympathy for Mr Abbott's predicament and we wish to help him in any way practicable."

Mr Abbott denied that he had been a menace to the coastguard service. "My boat is seaworthy but if you come to a point in the dark and it isn't easy to see your way, then you need help. That's the job of the RNLI," he said.

Penny Haire, the RYA's chief cruising instructor, said the course, which normally costs £500, would teach Mr Abbott to be aware of his limitations and have a healthy respect for the sea.

It would also give him an understanding of navigation and improve his boat handling ability.

The course will include five days of theory where he will learn charting skills and a further five days of intensive practical training.

No doubt the coastguard and lifeboat crews will breathe a collective sigh of relief when he finishes it.

webTitle: Gibraltar may take legal action on nuclear sub

fields.headline: Gibraltar may take legal action on nuclear sub
fields.standfirst: Anger grows over radioactive risk posed by HMS Tireless as MoD seeks to play down 'minor defect'
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence faces the prospect of unprecedented legal action to force it to remove a damaged nuclear-powered submarine from Gibraltar.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence faces the prospect of unprecedented legal action to force it to remove a damaged nuclear-powered submarine from Gibraltar.

Its decision to try to repair HMS Tireless, which has been tied up since May 19 in full view of populated areas, has provoked protest in the British overseas territory.

Though the ministry yesterday dismissed the submarine's problem as a "minor defect", sources with direct knowledge of the leak from the nuclear reactor describe it as serious.

They say the fault is located above valves controlling pressure to the submarine's steam generators and is close to the reactor itself.

"The problem cannot be isolated," said one source, who declined to be identified. HMS Tireless limped into Gibraltar after radioactive coolant started leaking from the reactor when on patrol in the Mediterranean.

In an indication of the gravity of the problem, the MoD has decided not to try to tow the submarine back to Britain. The defect is said to be the first of its kind in Britain's fleet of nuclear-powered submarines.

The ministry said yesterday that it was examining results of an inspection by the defence nuclear safety committee. The ministry said it hoped that the repairs could be accomplished by the autumn.

A coalition of six groups representing a broad cross-section of Gibraltar's population of 28,000 yesterday sought legal advice from Hassans, a leading Gibraltar law firm. They include the campaigning Voice of Gibraltar Group, the Self Determination for Gibraltar Group, teachers' unions, the local United Nations Association, and the Gibraltar Federation of Small Businesses.

They are planning a demonstration next Tuesday against the MoD's plans to repair the submarine on the Rock.

A recent telephone poll which was carried out by Gibraltar television showed 79% of people against repairs taking place locally.

"There is a constitutional question whether a faulty nuclear submarine is a domestic or foreign issue," said Levi Attias of the Voice of Gibraltar Group yesterday.

"My argument is that it is domestic, and thus it is a matter of prime importance."

The Gibraltar Labour-Liberal opposition blamed the Rock's government for failing to take a stand on the principle of "whether the repairs to the nuclear submarine should be carried out in Gibraltar or not".

It also accused the MoD of giving evasive answers to the House of Commons.

A leading Gibraltarian unaligned to any party described it as an "issue of Gibraltarians' confidence in the Ministry of Defence".

He said that the submarine was lit up all night, 400 metres from the shore. "People are very worried," he said. The ministry initially said HMS Tireless would be berthed at Gibraltar for no more than a few days, suggesting that it would then be towed back to Britain.

John Spellar, the armed forces minister, described the protests as a "local campaign" which did not reflect the "considerable number of Gibraltarians who actually work in the dockyard and depend on it for their living".

The submarine was becoming caught up in the wider question of the future of Gibraltar, he said, "It is about 1,000 miles, by sea, to tow it back, so that would not necessarily be the most sensible option." He added that the reactor had been shut down and the problem had been like "a dripping tap".

A source said yesterday the MoD had decided not to tow the submarine back to Britain because of the danger of more radioactive fuel leaking from the vessel.

fields.headline: Rail franchise rejig yields extra £600m
fields.trailText: An extra £600m is to be invested in railway services running along the M1 and M40 corridors as a result of the first renegotiation of train operating company franchises, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
An extra £600m is to be invested in railway services running along the M1 and M40 corridors as a result of the first renegotiation of train operating company franchises, it was revealed yesterday.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, said the money would provide better services, improved safety and new trains. Chiltern Railways' 12-year contract for the London to West Midlands franchise along the M40 corridor will now last for up to 20 years. In return the company, which is 84% owned by the John Laing construction group, has agreed to deliver a £370m investment programme in conjunction with Railtrack and train leasing companies. For the contract to run the full 20 years, Chiltern Railways will also have to implement a £1bn plan to expand its network - with construction of new lines or reopening of old ones linking Oxford, Bletchley, Aylesbury and Princes Risborough.

The shadow strategic rail authority, the body responsible for renegotiating the franchises, also announced that the Midland Mainline franchise serving the M1 corridor from London to the East Midlands and Yorkshire is being extended by two years to 2008, opening the way for an extra £238m investment. Of this, £135m will be spent on new trains, £60m on infrastructure, and £22m on station improvements. In addition a new £17m "parkway" station, near the M1 and East Midlands airport, will be opened in 2002.

Chiltern Railways' £370m scheme includes:

 two new platforms at London's Marylebone station;  extra tracks between South and West Ruislip, at Beaconsfield and between Bicester and Aynho junction;  extending London to Birmingham train services to Stourbridge by 2001 and Kidderminster by 2002;  reopening of the Moor Street terminus near Birmingham's Bull Ring;  all Chiltern trains to be new or refurbished by 2004, and fitted with Automatic Train Protection safety equipment;  reduced journey times on certain routes.

John Laing Investments, which controls Chiltern Railways, is involved in a number of the government's private finance initiatives, including trams, schools and hospitals. Such projects typically involve a 10% equity stake by the company and 90% debt financing. Mr Prescott - who is the driving force behind the decision to renegotiate the franchise agreements well ahead of their expiry dates - said they had set a new benchmark for the rail industry. The deals were the first step towards securing the £60bn of investment needed to modernise the railways over the next 10 years to cope with an expected 50% growth in demand, he said. The plans, which involved additional stations near motorways and better station facilities for cyclists and motorists, showed rail companies were becoming part of a truly integrated transport system.

Go-ahead Group, which failed to secure the new Chiltern franchise, said it was making progress in its talks with the shadow Strategic Rail Authority for the South Central franchise, for which it had also been shortlisted.

fields.headline: Dome goes for business money
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome is planning a series of corporate bookings to boost visitor figures.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome is planning a series of corporate bookings to boost visitor figures.

A spokeswoman for the New Millennium Experience Company yesterday said the businesses could be charged up to £240,000 to hire the dome for a day, though she would not reveal an exact figure.

First in a string of exclusive access deals will be the 150th anniversary celebrations for the American investment bank Lehman Brothers on September 16. The bank has bought up 25,000 tickets to the Greenwich attraction in south-east London, and an estimated 20,000 to 25,000 members of the public will be turned away.

The NMEC spokeswoman refused to say how much the dome would lose in ticket sales to the public.

A spokeswoman for the NMEC's national programme department hinted that reductions could be available on exclusive access deals. She added that most dates next month were still available for exclusive bookings. "We can always fit something in." The shadow culture spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, said: "I think it is astonishing, but money talks. Presumably they have negotiated a lucrative deal.

"Some people travel substantial distances to visit the dome. How are they going to be told they will not be allowed in?"

The dome must attract 21,600 visitors a day if it is to meet its target of 6m by the end of the year.

fields.headline: Vive les Eurobeanz
fields.standfirst: Tetbury
fields.trailText: During the spring, I was telling you about my international crop testing experiment, the Eurobeanz trial, which had seen batches of Dodger Norris's Uley-germinated runner bean seedlings sown both here in the courtyard back garden and in the vegetable patch of our Breton fastness at Plougasnou.
fields.body:
During the spring, I was telling you about my international crop testing experiment, the Eurobeanz trial, which had seen batches of Dodger Norris's Uley-germinated runner bean seedlings sown both here in the courtyard back garden and in the vegetable patch of our Breton fastness at Plougasnou.

Both plantings have been regularly monitored, but Tetbury crop has probably had slightly more tender loving care. Both crops have contributed servings to main meals. There is little doubt, however, about the winner in this international comparison - the Plougasnou beans, despite neglect and irregular watering, overhanging gorse and bramble, win hands down, and my daughter and family who are there for a bucket-and-spade fortnight will, I am sure, be harvesting some beans for dinner.

Although quite well concealed, which is accidental rather than intentional, the Breton crop have excited some local admiration. Paul and Monique, neighbours in for an aperitif, looked over the privet hedge at the Eurobeanz, well up their canes and with plentiful red flowers. "Ah," said Monique, "les haricots anglaises.'' Not quite, would have been the answer, but I was interested that she recognised them as beans for the French seem to grow only the short-stemmed haricot vert which I find a perfectly acceptable vegetable but in no way superior to our runner bean.

I reported on the outcome thus far of these trials to Dodger on Stinchcombe Hill, where we often find ourselves in the same group of golfers competing with extraordinary keenness for remarkably small sums of money. He was pleased to hear of the success of the French crop, and nodded sagely when I pointed out that the warmer conditions must be responsible for the French victory. He revealed that his father had bought the original seed, clearly many years ago, from which annual generations of crops have enabled him to select the most vigorous and prolific for the following year's planting, and that the packet had been of Scottish origin.

He was pleased to hear of the success of the French crop, and nodded sagely when I pointed out that the warmer conditions must be responsible for the French victory. He revealed that his father had bought the original seed, clearly many years ago, from which annual generations of crops have enabled him to select the most vigorous and prolific for the following year's planting, and that the packet had been of Scottish origin.

fields.headline: Flying kites on fuel tax
fields.trailText: Ben Rogers (Comment, August 7) wrongly implies that taxation of aviation fuel will cut demand for air travel, reducing emissions and noise. Aviation, a vital part of modern society, is an efficient and responsible industry and is constantly improving its environmental performance - airlines have doubled their fuel efficiency over the last 30 years and aircraft today are typically 75% quieter.
fields.body:
Ben Rogers (Comment, August 7) wrongly implies that taxation of aviation fuel will cut demand for air travel, reducing emissions and noise. Aviation, a vital part of modern society, is an efficient and responsible industry and is constantly improving its environmental performance - airlines have doubled their fuel efficiency over the last 30 years and aircraft today are typically 75% quieter. Aviation consumes approximately 12% of the oil supplies used by the entire transport sector; jet aircraft produce 2-3% of global man-made nitrogen oxide emissions and only 2.5% of the carbon dioxide produced by the burning of fossil fuels. Yet, Mr Rogers would have us believe air travel is the most environmentally damaging form of transport. Solutions to the environmental challenges of increasing demand for air travel will be found in a combination of new technology and better management of operations, both in the air and on the ground. Simple demand management through taxation will not bring the relief sought by Mr Rogers.
John McClarty
Society of British Aerospace Companies

 Full marks to John Prescott for further travel concessions (Pensioners to get cheap bus travel, August 9). However, some of us are out of reach of bus or rail altogether. Is it beyond the wit of government to give the pensioner-motorist, crippled by the current cost of petrol, a comparable concession at the pump?
Richard Leigh Perkins
Lastingham, N Yorks

fields.headline: Hard news
fields.trailText: There are two issues to note over News 24's viewing figures (Have I got news for you, August 9).
fields.body:
There are two issues to note over News 24's viewing figures (Have I got news for you, August 9).

First, transparency. It is clearly detailed in the BBC annual report that we count News 24's viewers - more than 6m a week - across all platforms. Sky News seldom notes that its audience figures include analogue satellite homes where BBC and ITN 24 hour news services aren't available. Second, the overnight News 24 service via BBC1 is paid for from the channel's budget - and viewers are watching News 24 programming. There is a choice of channels through the night, as there is through the day, so to imply they're captive viewers and to discount them - while still including the cost of what they're watching - is bizarre.
Rachel Attwell
Head of BBC News 24

fields.headline: On the menu: cricket
fields.body:
I feel faint. Eat an insect?! Why not? We scoff down its close cousins the shrimp and the prawn, which are non-vegetarian scavengers that feed on marine carrion, unlike the clean-living, veggie cricket.

So who eats them? Diners in restaurants that specialise in the more outr forms of fusion cooking, and folk in other places where crickets are more numerous than people. How do you cook them? Dry 'em, fry 'em, roast 'em or cover 'em in chocolate.

Are they nutritious and healthy? They could hardly be more so. No nasty animal fats, growth-promoting chemicals or routinely dosed anti-biotics. A useful source of protein. What do they taste like? Crunchy, with a slight taste of prawn.

fields.headline: Home truth
fields.trailText: It's a shame that Jim White didn't actually talk to French soccer international Christian Karembeu before penning the usual stereotypical rubbish Middlesbrough fans have come to expect every time we sign a world-class player (Paris, Milan... Middlesbrough, G2, August 9).
fields.body:
It's a shame that Jim White didn't actually talk to French soccer international Christian Karembeu before penning the usual stereotypical rubbish Middlesbrough fans have come to expect every time we sign a world-class player (Paris, Milan... Middlesbrough, G2, August 9). For he would have discovered that Karembeu actually has a brain (as well as a World Cup winners medal, a Euro 2000 winners medal and a European Champions' League medal). On his native island of New Caledonia, he led a campaign against French nuclear testing - which will go down well on Teesside, where concern over local environmental pollution has always been strong. Whether his supermodel wife will ever appear in the town's Bongo Club remains to be seen. But that other francophile, David Shayler, is due here for the Leeds United game at the end of the month - a homecoming even more welcome than Juninho's.
David Carter
Middlesbrough

fields.headline: False icon
fields.trailText: Scott Capurro likes to see himself as an "iconoclast" with his use of comedy (Festival joke on Holocaust provokes outrage, August 10). Sadly, to his audience he merely comes across as a bigot with no idea what he's talking about.  What makes his comments about the Holocaust even more insulting is his attempt on stage to justify them.
fields.body:
Scott Capurro likes to see himself as an "iconoclast" with his use of comedy (Festival joke on Holocaust provokes outrage, August 10). Sadly, to his audience he merely comes across as a bigot with no idea what he's talking about. What makes his comments about the Holocaust even more insulting is his attempt on stage to justify them. Having a Jewish great-grandmother doesn't make any difference; bleating that "it's a joke" doesn't make it funny either. I'm afraid I missed his suggestion that I should "die of Aids" as I walked out of his show. But since that's no funnier than the rest of his bitter ranting, I didn't miss much.
Simon Brilliant
London

fields.headline: Caudillos with a cause
fields.trailText: Ian Campbell's belief that presidents Hugo Chavez of Venezuela and Alberto Fujimori of Peru have much in common because they are the latest in a line of caudillo strongmen is a gross oversimplification (The strongman's return, August 9).
fields.body:
Ian Campbell's belief that presidents Hugo Chavez of Venezuela and Alberto Fujimori of Peru have much in common because they are the latest in a line of caudillo strongmen is a gross oversimplification (The strongman's return, August 9). Chavez draws on a tradition of reformist military leaders who justified military intervention in politics to effect reform rather than to defend conservative elites. His anti-politics rhetoric is strongly nationalistic and highly critical of neo-liberal policies that he perceives to have robbed Venezuela of its sovereignty, notably the privatisation of the state-owned oil company. By contrast, Fujimori has embraced IMF-imposed neo-liberal economic policy, with catastrophic consequences for an already impoverished population. The roots of Latin American poverty lie in the continued exploitation of the region's natural resources by western transnational companies, aided and abetted by the international financial institutions. The unequal distribution of land exacerbates the huge disparity between rich and poor. Until these problems are tackled the future looks bleak. Campbell is wrong to suggest that the only way ahead lies in "respect for the rules" when they are written in Washington and the financial centres of Europe. The caudillo is but a symptom of Latin America's difficulties.
Bert Schouwenburg
London

fields.headline: Last meal - till later
fields.trailText: George W Bush's decision not to pardon Oliver Cruz, executed in Texas despite having a learning disability, is unfortunately hardly surprising (Bush allows execution for murderer with low IQ, August 10). Research funded by the Kennedy Foundation and carried out by William Edwards, a lawyer who represents people with learning disabilities on death row, showed that since the US reinstated the death penalty in 1979, 10% of those executed have had learning disabilities.

Research funded by the Kennedy Foundation and carried out by William Edwards, a lawyer who represents people with learning disabilities on death row, showed that since the US reinstated the death penalty in 1979, 10% of those executed have had learning disabilities. One man had so little understanding of what was going to happen to him that he left the pudding from his last meal "for later".
Christina Schwabenland
The Elfrida Society

 The popularity of victim-led criminal justice policies can be traced to the pervasive influence of America (Victims' siren voices, August 9). The chain of events that led to the passing of "three strikes and you're out" legislation in California tells its own story. In 1993, Polly Klaas, 12, was raped and murdered by a man on parole. Huge media coverage influenced citizens and victims' groups to lobby for the legislation, which was signed into law by the governor in record time. California continues to be unimpressed by arguments that mandatory sentencing is both costly and ineffective. People who commit violent crime should be punished severely. But the evidence is clear: unharnessed raw emotion leads to thoughtless crime policies.
Nick Flynn
Prison Reform Trust
